content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												Too ruggedly professional to die, 2008 sleeper hit Sins of a Solar Empire has returned. Titled Rebellion, this third expansion comes in a new, expandalone format, and adds just about everything except actual rebellion. Silly developers!Sins has aged well, partly because its only competitor, Sword of the Stars II, flopped harder than a snake slipping off a diving board, but also because its appeal is still intact. As you develop your empire, swinging from planet to planet, tumbling down the tech tree, stringing together fleets and levelling up your capital ships, the game simply gives you a bit too much to think about.It’s uncanny. As a beginner, you’ll have your hands (and head) full developing trade routes and continuing the electric push of your culture across the solar system, perhaps with one eye on your prize fleet, making sure it’s still winning some 20-minute pitched battle. But experts will be kept just as busy micromanaging the powers on individual ships, perhaps leaping home to oversee the construction of a Maginot Line-like array of turrets, before snapping up the diplomacy menu to offer a job, a ceasefire, a demand, then back to the fight. Sins’ sweet spot is that it always threatens to overwhelm, but rarely does. This isn’t the riptide real-time strategy of StarCraft II. It’s more sedate than that. But the game simply has so much going on, its every element rewarding not just attention but obsession, that you’re able to sink into it like a hot bath. Want to fling armadas around as if they were plastic toys? You’ll have a great time. Want to orchestrate your fleets like an interplanetary Rommel? You’ll see the rewards instantly.Which brings us to what Rebellion adds. Perhaps most notably, it still doesn’t add a singleplayer campaign, leaving you to fool around either online or in the excellently robust skirmish mode. Which is fine. There’s also a whole new suite of tutorials, which prepare you for everything – except how to deal with this much content.Sins’ three relatively asymmetrical races have been further rent into Rebel and Loyalist variants, each of which holds a new teasing selection of powerful abilities and a unique Titan. We’ll get to those. Loyalist TEC, for example, are a turtle’s dream, with one tech that increases experience gained fighting in their own space and another that lowers the cost of the horrible Novalith Cannon (which lets them slam-dunk nukes into distant gravity wells). Meanwhile, the nomadic Vasari Loyalists gain the power to summon NPC vagabonds and devour planets like so many Mars Bars.There are new corvettes and capital ships for each faction, too, but the Titans are the stars of the show. Monstrously expensive and perfectly suited to a long-form game like Sins, it’s likely the fiercest fighting these behemoths will see will be attacks by wary players on their sprawling dockyard before they’re completed.As with everything else in the game, however, they strike a thoughtful balance. Completing a Titan is by no means a ‘win’ button, but the automated report that another player has finished one still instils a gentle dread.Outside of the lack of a singleplayer campaign, about the only criticism that could be levelled at Rebellion is that it’s not much of a looker anymore. But you know what? When you jump some 50 ships on top of an enemy fleet, announcing your presence in a flutter of missiles and hot burps of laser fire, you just can’t tear your eyes away.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2013
												I still consider this game from Stardock to be one of, if not the best of the 4X space genre! I started with the original game and have purchased each of it's successors and, or DLC's. I have never felt let down in any game from this gaming series. I've always enjoyed playing each and everyone of the releases. Many, many games have brought themselves into this 4X space genre and I've tried out many demos from the competition. I've also purchased many other games in this genre, yet to date none have compared to Sins of a Solar Empire, in my humble opinion. The gameplay is smooth and extremely beautiful, even when you zoom in as close as you can. And have literally hundreds to thousands of ships in the grips of warfare (including the AI or enemy player's ships). I highly recommend that you purchase the DLC, especially for this release. Because it brings a lot more options and most importantly; Tons mo' fun to the table.There's also a lot of depth in this game, if you so choose to dig deeper. From planetary upgrades, fleet upgrades, starbases and the awe inspiring Titan Class. There's always something to do and MM is easily tamed if that's your play style, and the game moves fast or slow. You decide -- there are so many options before dropping into battle as to what could possibly happen. Don't like pirates? Fine, simply disable them or better yet choose a faction that harnesses the pirates to do your bidding. Don't like playing with diplomatic measures influencing the game? You can disable or bend these options to your will as well. Truly, the options are endless. This game gives you so much control, whether it be through the options menu and, or the faction you choose to play as. I could go on, but I think you have a firm grip on the gist of what I'm spraying. Not to mention the fact I've babbled on and this review is long enough as is.

number of helpful: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25
												So, before getting into this review I have to say I am a big space and empire building nerd, so when those two are put together I'm already partial to it, so fair warning.General Info:-Sins is a space building empire where you pick one of three factions (with two subfactions each) and conquer the galaxy. Each of the six subclasses feels unique, with gimics from turtling and economy to psionic warfare.  Maps can range from single star systems or maps with up to 3 star systems (could be more, I mostly play on the 3 star systems, apologies if i'm incorrect on this one). You can play diplomatically or militarilly, although really you'll almost find yourself exclusively military, as it's nigh impossible to get everyone alligned together, although it's not hard to get one or two AI allies to join you for tagteaming. -Gameplay is real time, not turn based. This adds a unique element to the late game, when most factions have hundreds of ships moving in different parts of the galaxy. This can keep you on your toes, constantly watching everywhere for what the others are doing.-Game is entirely based in space, no land combat (only thing you do on land is upgrade the planet's overall population and other things like bomb shelters for defense).Pros:-Fleet combat: Real time combat with hundreds or even thousands of ships duking it out in real time is amazing, and the graphics and spectacle is amazing (especially considering the game's small download size).-Extensive tech tree and decent pool of ship classes to give you enough to play with different fleet builds.-Capital Ships and Titans are essentially heroes that level as they are in combat. Every class is unique, and each faction has 6 capital ships, and each subfaction has a unique titan that fits their play style.-Amazing Mod Support: ModDB has some pretty amazing conversion mods for this game. I've personally tried Halo, Star Wars, Star Trek, and one of the older Mass Effect conersion mods and they are amazing, especially if you find yourself tiring of the base factions.-Multiplayer support still works at the time of this review (even for most of those mods I just listed).Cons:-Extreme learning curve, even if you are used to these kinds of games you'll find yourself feeling slightly overwhelmed or really overwhelmed depending on experience with these types of games. (Pirates are the main issue, as if you very inexperienced and not paying attention to the pirate bribery meter, you might find yourself losing a planet early on to a large pirate fleet, although you can use the pirates to your advantage as well if you have the money for it).-AI Isnt that bright, and generally doesn't start amassing large fleets until late game, if at all depending on ai difficulty. Mostly the AI like to spam superweapons and harass your planets.Overall I give this game a 8.75/10. If you like space combat or empire building this game is definitely worth checking out, although the standard price is very steep, I definitely recommend waiting for a sale, as 50% and 75% sales happen fairly regularly.

content:
Posted: January 21
												Sins of a Solar Empire. A relatively obscure 4X game that my brother showed me nearly 8 years ago... evidently, this was for the best as it opened my eyes to the medium of gaming and I would not be myself without it and for that, I owe it everything and have spent probably around 3,000 hours across all versions of the game, on and off steam. At heart, it's pretty simple for a 4X game, much more focused on combat and not empire building compared to others such as Endless Space and Masters of Orion although this is not a bad thing. My personal favorite part of SoaSE:R is the mod scene, it's an amazing game and is well worth the full price umodded, but it truly shines when modded, everything from slight changes to entire overhauls consisting of just about every popular Sci-Fi universe including Halo, Star Wars, Star Trek, Eve, Stargate, even Battlestar Galactica (Sadly, no Warhammer 40,000). This fact, along with the infinite replayability will keep me playing Sins of a Solar Empire for many years to come. (Until the release of Sins 2? Please...)

Posted: June 6, 2014
												I, personally, enjoy this game, and if you are into space combat games at all, you will enjoy Sins of a Solar Empire. The original game was fantastic, and with Rebellion, comes even more fun! Take command of one of three factions, and choose whether you are a Loyalist or a Rebel. Each faction has their own backstory and reasons for why they are fighting, and the sins they are paying for.The technology trees have been expanded ever so slightly, and the tech from before has been reworked. Perhaps you want to upgrade how effecient your mining is or maybe you want to start broadcasting how amazing your civilization is across space. Choose whether you want to upgrade your ships' weaponry or armor, to field more variations or ships, or build your defenses.Speaking of ships, they have added in two new classifications: the Corvette and the Titan. The Corvette is a fast little attack ship, sporting a few weapons, and a debilitating effect. They take only a research upgrade to start producing. And then comes the Titan. These behemoths take several research upgrades, not-to-mention an arm and a leg worth of resources to start producing. You can only field one at a time, but these monsters are devastating.Each faction has one new capital ship as well, which can be of varying use in certain aspects of the game. The original five capital ships have been revamped, with their abilities being reworked and revamped. Not everything has been changed, but a few tweaks have been made, to make sure they are still viable and fun to use.This is the only part that I still have a problem with: the planetary upgrades. Planets can be upgraded in a handful of different areas, and different types of planets can receive a different number of upgrades, up to a maximum of four. These upgrades can allow a larger planetary population or increasing the number of tactical (defensive structures and the like) or logistical (research platforms, broadcasting stations, shipyards). It could increase the health of the planet (and thus how much damage it can take from enemy bombardment), or explore the planet. This could lead to planetary anomalies that could be beneficial or penalize the planet, or even discover a long-lost artifact, which would have beneficial affects for your empire as a whole. The reason I have a problem with this is because it is too streamlined. Once a planet is upgraded, there is no reason to keep coming back to it, unless it is being attack.That being said, do I recommend the game? Yes. Absolutely. Gameplay is almost never stale, as the game changes every time you start it again. Anyone that enjoys the aspect of large naval space engagements would positively love Sins of a Solar Empire. And with this 75% off deal going on for this weekend, I would jump at the opportunity.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2016
												Fantastic series of games - the whole Sins of a Solar Empire series, I mean. Great scale and a very casual pace, that allows you to weigh your options and think through the game. There is a rich and challenging technology tree, and there's variety in the gameplay and situations. Perhaps one fault is the lack of a good single player campaign or story of some kind. The game mechanics could also have taken into consideration things like orbits for planets, to make it a bit nicer. Overall, fresh even after 8+ years, and very fun.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2016
												This game has given me hundreds of hours of enjoyment to the extent that I actually payed for the game twice. First time I got it was DRM free playing local multiplayer with 4 friends in my college dorm. My favorite memory was teaming up with 2 of them on our first very hard lard random map. I quietly built up my culture as Advent reminding tham that they do in fact recieve the culture bonuses from an ally. The last AI was about to die, friends' fleets are dwindled and and their economy in the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ from fleet upkeep. Tell team that it is time to start the pvp and end the ceasefire. Proceed to max out all my starbases in asteroid belts for max culture. Friends start fighting eachother because I was objectively "weaker." I wasnt until they lost most of thier planets from the sheer force of the Advent cultre machine. They grouped up against me but failed to hold even planet even with maxed culture buildings on their homeworlds and domination victory was achieved. 8 hours of long con never felt so good.5/7 would purchase again.

Posted: April 6, 2016
												First of all, what a brilliant game. This is by far the best 4X Space RTS game on the market. Nothing does massive space battles better then this game. Theres nothing better then building a massive fleet and laying waste to your enemies.For first-timers the learning curve is like a mountain but after an hour or two you'll climb that leg cramping, AI dominating mountain and begin kicking some AI butt, strategies will become more apparent and the game becomes so much greater.Only downside occasionally, very occasionally will a ship try to fly between gravity wells without slipspacing, its not going to get there but its going to give it a try. The modding for this game is fantastic, easy to install (check those checksums) and adds hours upon hours of fun to this stellar game. Want to play as the UNSC, theres a mod. Want to play as the Federation, theres a mod. Want to play as the Tau'ri, theres a mod. Want to play as the Empire, there's not just a mod there's a handful of mods.

content:
Posted: April 8
												I've played this game since it was first released god knows how long ago, I still have my original CD somewhere (who am I kidding?  It's in the drawer beside me.).IMO this is the single best Space RTS ever published.  Why?In short:1. Support - the development team are STILL providing updates, patches, improvements and super-cheap DLC.  This is not a cash-cow, you geuinely get the idea they are supporting it because they want to  play it.2. Depth - the depth of this game is ridiculous... titans to fighters in a way which is easy to understand.  Okay it lacks customisation as a trade off, but that brings us on to the next point...3. Refinement - as the game doesn't provide customisation, it allows the game to be smoother, less "glitchy", have better quality models and run smoother and simpler than many other games, even at huge scales.4. Role playing and replay - the ability to role play as a faction is key to this game.  I don't know anyone who hasn't stuck with one faction the entire way through and gets a little offended when someone hurts their budies.If you've never played this and you're about to play the limited MoO, the unfinished Stardrive, the fun-but-no-replay Endless Space or the "we updated it but didn't really improve it" Gal Civ 3 think again.  You're playing this instead now.You're welcome.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22, 2016
												This game is an interesting blend of 4X and RTS, on one hand you have to capture chokepoint planets and deny resources to your opponent all the while making careful decisions about which research to go into next, on the other hand you have to micromanage unit abilities in order to win any sort of competitive combat. The learning curve for this game is indeed high if only because which race variant you play impacts the strategies you can effectively use. Thankfully there are many good articles online to help you understand the concepts and advanced strategies possible in this game.For lovers of RTS, this game is a must. The graphics are beautiful, the AI punishing, and the multiplayer grueling.                                                        Expect competition.        Expect to be challenged.ENVOY RATED: 9/10

content:
Posted: April 12, 2016
												For a space RTS game, this is definitely where it's at. Although it doesn't hone the capabilities of taking control of a single ship, it does give a good space fun their fill of fun. Be careful as you can get caught and quickly start pouring hours into single player missions or playing against your friends online! If you are looking for me to expand on the personal story of Sins of a Solar Empire I cannot do it. Why? I don't have enough background information to tell you exactly what the story is but I can tell you how the game holds up! Even if you're not a hardcore space fan, you could most likely easily put 10 hours into the game. This may be in part in how the game develops to play style.Sins of a Solar Empire is described as an 4X type of game (explore, expand, exploit and exterminate). There is quite a bit to do and manage. To begin, there are three races that the player is able to choose from : the (industrial) TEC, the (psychics) Advent and the (alien zergish looking) Vasari. Each race has it's own unique distinctions and units but all sort of share the same build options regarding ships and buildings alike. The TEC (human race) is not as good technologically as the other races but is good at poking away at opponents slowly (attrition warfare). The Advent race has great energy weapons but lack armor and prefer shields. They also can use their cultural influence on other planets in an attempt to shift opinion. The Vasari beat both the humans and the Advent regarding their technological and ship abilities. However, these high quality ships come at a steep price!The game play itself is actually pretty good. It's easy to keep track of what's going on from planet to planet and they made it extremely easy to upgrade/build. If you are wanting to upgrade an aspect of a planet (say civilian infrastructure, emergency shelters, exploring more of the planet and (not limited to) industry or social focus), it can be done easily. Managing planets was made with ease while managing fleets takes a bit of work. There are lot of commands in games that the keyboard can take care of. It will take a while to figure out what is what but as long as you know what the icons mean, you're gold. Research and diplomacy can be taken care of by clicking the tabs up top. Research is broken into a few categories in which focuses on either military, defense, diplomatic, civilian infrastructure and fleet upgrades. New units, abilities or even additional damage can added to your arsenal. Be wary though! To create capitol ships or titan units (mega ships), you will need "command" staff and will have to upgrade not a unit amount, but the command slot amount.I'm a bit confused regarding single player as there doesn't seem to be a campaign mode. Rather, it seems they took the approach of single individual missions against the AI. This might irritate a lot of players but may also entice a lot of players into playing single missions. Multiplayer saved games are a bit tricky (see : link discussion). All players must have their own save file but the save file cannot be sent player to player (as one player may be using your race/units). The diplomacy portion of the game is a little weary as well. It's good but nothing too outstanding. Missions can be given to factions and vice versa (as well as trade options and the sort). Completing these missions reflects on your relations with factions. Pirates can also be hired within the game in case you don't want to attack your opponent directly. It can cost you a pretty penny though!There are a few things you can tweak in-game considering winning conditions. Default mission settings uses domination, which means that you basically have to take over the map. There is a diplomatic victory in which you need to acquire the most diplomatic points to win. Research victory where (obviously) you need to complete the most research or reach a specific tier. There is an occupation victory in which special militia will keep spawning at a certain planet and players must control (occupy) this planet for a certain amount of time. Reaching this time means victory. There are other winning conditions such as capitol planet and capitol ship in which both (or one - your choice) have to stay alive. If your capitol planet becomes occupied, you lose. If your capitol ship gets destroyed, you lose. Within this menu you can also change how many planets are within the map and starting conditions. They give you a decent amount of options to customize your game so you can enjoy how you wish.The game's currency system is quite simple and has some nice additions. Coins are your basic income and will need it to buy majority of things. (NOTICE : if you are losing coins and do not know why, you do not have enough civilian infrastructure on your planets)! Crystals are the next and finally metal. Metal and crystal are harvested from asteroids and can be traded if you build a trade system (increasing your economy). Metal and crystal can be sold or bought. They attempted an interactive market where the prices will drop and rise. The game will give you a small heads-up but it's always a good idea to keep an eye on the prices.The visuals themselves are actually decently good. They is a lot of attention to detail and most phaser/ion cannon shots are noticeable. Ships taking damage is also apparent as well as when ships attack planets (you can see mini explosions on the surface)! In addition, you can see traffic moving about the planet and cities. Sounds are pretty good (explosion sounds could vary a bit) and you can hear ships jump from planet to planet. The dialogue in game is good but as most RTS games, you'll start hearing the same voices in your head.Overall, a pretty good space RTS game. I would recommend it for die-hard space fans and would recommend the casual gamer to buy on sale so there is no love lost. After playing for 10+ hours and playing different game modes (victory conditions), it is beginning to be redundant. Like I said, I can see a lot of gamers immersing themselves into this game. I would love to see some individual control given to the player as well as maybe adding a campaign? All the space RTS stuff is right, maybe it's now time to take it an extra step?RATING : 7.5/10Gameplay B Story / Campaign C+ Visuals / User Interface B Sounds / Music B Replay-ability C+ Overall  B-ScreenShots : (to come) What one Titan looks like What another Titan looks like Some levels have a distinct color that'll hit your eyes consistently There is a magic button you should be aware of

content:
Posted: May 27, 2016
												Ok so lets start.  First off, the time listed played, is one match + the tutorial.  I played only one single player map.  The smallest one.  The time it took me to finish it was over 8 hours.  Again this was the first single player map and listed as tiny.  Now I will admit.  Part of that was cause I was still getting use to the game.  I also kinda limited my self to only upgrading war and defensive upgrades.  Leaving out anything that was trade or peace related.  This makes it hard cause those upgrades I did not use would help capture some planet types, give better material gathering, give more money, and allow peaceful relations with others in the system so that they did not attack you or even might help ya.So ya, 8 hours for one tiny map.  This game is fun for anyone who like strategy and long game play.  Do not get this game thinking it will be a quick run.  There are ways to change the victory setting and not sure how the competitive play fairs.  I would imagine there might be some ways to make it go faster.Also, as far as I can see.  There is no storyline or quest line.  This is not like Starcraft.  You are not doing RTS with a rich story about 3 different races.  Your basically playing a glorified chess game.  A MASSIVE, BEAUTIFUL, not really that close to chess, chess game.  I was listening to a coworker talk about it and the vids I saw made it look good enough to try.  It is, but it is really only good for eating up your time.  Need something to just throw countless hours at were there is no story and just plotting and building your forces in hopes you can take out your enemies.  Then go for it.  Though if you are not absolutely sure then do what I did and get it at 75% or more off.

												If you like RTS games like StarCraft, WarCraft, and Command & Conquer, but always thought, "I wish the maps were bigger," then this is your game. Massive maps, fairly decent variety of combat ships (And support vessels) are just a couple of items in this game. Worth the money, plus there's a Star Trek Armada mod out for it, so that's always a plus, too.

content:
Posted: April 11, 2016
												It kind of reminds me of Star Wars: Empire at War, except no ground battles and everything happens in real time. There isn't much of a story to it except what's told in the intro video. So, there's no story mode, it's just like a skirmish mode, choose a map and go. That kind of sucks but the gameplay makes up for it, there's a lot you can do once you start a game. The game tries to make diplomacy a big concept but fails because diplomacy can largely be ignored. At least for me, diplomacy could have been done better.It comes with a "map editor." I use quotes because it's not really a map editor. It gives you a screen with various settings that you can modify and it auto-creates a map based on those settings. It's essentially just a fancy random map mode.Not really much else to say... If you want a detailed story mode then this isn't going to be very fun for you. But if you like galactic RTS games then this works great.

content:
Posted: June 12, 2014
												Probably my current favorite game of all time, alongside empire at war. Absolutely gorgeous graphics, gameplay is perfect for new video gamers, as well as long time gamers. It has minimalistic control, so you dont need to micro everyone and everything. However, if you so desire, this is an option, and will greatly improve results from battles. All factions are pretty much balanced, however they do depend on your playstyle. All races have a few OP researches they can do at the end. Last but not least, the modding community. It's absolutely stunning. There are mods for almost everything for this game, and more are on the way. Only downside I see is possibly price, however that does not factor into the actual gameplay. I give this a 10/10. Best game ever.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2016
												If you noticed the game on a sale and you are either struggling to pay the required amount of money or just looking down the comment section to see if it's worth it... BUY IT. Like a great person and an ultimate memelord once said: "JUST DO IT!". This is an RTS video game which main goal is to rule a growing space empire. The game is filled with content, it features real time combat (the unit limit is seriously high, so the battles are not only challenging and exciting but also huge and spectacular) which requires input from the player since you can manage every single ship on the battlefield separately, especially capital ships that will level up after gaining enough XP points and require the player to put some input in the direction of where the upgrade points go. However the game is not only focused on combat unlike the majority of other RTS games with such massive battles. While the battle is going on you can just zoom out and control your empire, send reinforcements or either start an another battle in a different spot. As I mentioned before, not only you have to fight and conquer, but also do research, gather resources, manage the planetary and orbital infrastructure of each planet you own, run a diplomacy between you and other players, give missions to factions or pirates, bribe pirates to strike empires other than yours and do other stuff that a space emperor would do. The point is, there is so much content, such a huge game world (if you feel like a single solar system of 30+ planets isn't enough for you, there is an option to play on a map based on several solar system each one with tens of planets ) with so many planets/sectors to rule and various ways of victory (diplomatic,total annihilation etc.) that it's hard to put everything into a smal steam review. Even though it is an RTS game, the matches can stay up to several hours or days as it is in Civilization V. It makes the game a fun multiplayer production with an option to host a multiplayer lobby and save the game progress so it can get loaded next time you want to play, that's why the game plays the best if you have friends who are willing to play it with you.In a nutshell - it is a fun RTS game with many gameplay possibilities and a great multiplayer module. If you are a fan of RTS games you should definitely get it !

content:
Posted: September 25, 2015
												This game offers a lot more tactical depth then what you'd expect from from a real-time version of popular turn-based 4X games. With an enormous tech tree, a flexible - well designed diplomatic system and 6 factions (3x2) that play very differently this game offers more than enough content to keep you occupied for months (given the sky-high replay value and dozen hour-long matches)While reading the negative reviews i came to realize that they mostly cover the following:-the "expansion" hasn't got enough new content (with which I highly disagree, besides, it's a standalone title)-Master of orion and Gal Civ are better (to people who say this: real-time strategies are obviously not your thing, no matter how much content they pack)The game is as good as flawless when you look at it at a standalone viewpoint.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2015
												Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion is a sequel of sorts for Sins of a Solar Empire. Rebellion adds many things to the game, but its primary additions are the Titans, which are massive Mothershipesque monstrosities which dwarf the capital ships.There are still the three primary factions: Vasari, TEC, Advent. This game, however, splits those factions into Loyalist and Rebel factions that the player can choose. These factions diversify the choices and play styles of the factions. The Vasari are still, in general, very war and destruction focused (you get cool gravely voices and get to strip planets). The TEC are still pretty trade and defense focused. The Advent are still rather culture focused. The factions do add a little difference to the play style. The primary reason to play this game is the feeling of power as you conquer planets and then galaxies. The game is very long with even a one galaxy game taking hours. It is loads of fun in multiplayer, but you might find that you have to dedicate an entire weekend to a good multi-galaxy 3-5 player game. My and my buds in college did this more often than we probably should have! The story for this game is essentially the context of the races. Make up your own story! Are you the TEC turned aggressive? Do you want to be constantly quoting "Join the Unity" or "I am the Unity's Servant" with your friends? Play the Advent and be annoying! Are you the Vasari who have decided to like trade and culture (if so, you're playing them wrong. Play the advent). DO YOU WANT TO CONSUME ALL THE PLANETS? PLAY VASARI. For example: 


The fully consumed Galaxy. What Galaxy will the Vasari devour next? 
A Screenshot of Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion
By: Yankee Spotts




Seriously though, get the game on sale. Force your friends to get the game. Practice more than them. Consume their planets.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18
												Sins of a Solar Empire Rebellion incorporates all the outstanding aspects of the previous games in the series and abolishes most of its past flaws. Although $40 is a steep price, the game is worth its weight in gold if you enjoy 4X and grand strategy games that are dynamic and offer endless hours of entertainment. The DLC adds some flare and more strategic options to the mix. I have played every Sins of a Solar Empire since the first one was released back in 2008 and I assure you this is by far the best installment in the series.  Pros: Enormous space battles – Upwards of 3000+ ships within one gravity well can be quite the site to behold, especially in cinematic modeOnline multiplayer – You must make an account, which doesn't take long and then you can play with your friends vs. AI or against other playersCustom map designer – Allows you to make absolutely massive maps, even to the scale of an entire galaxy and it is an essential tool to help you acquire achievements Grand strategy - Diplomacy, Trade, Pirates, Fleets, Research and much moreMultiple races each with their own unique tech trees, specialties and titansMod friendly – There are mods that allow you completely overhaul the game, such as Star Wars, Star Trek and Mass Effect themed mods and smaller more particular mods that allow you to change a tech tree or add a wider variety of planets + I recommend using Mod DBGame speed management in single-player, which gives you the freedom to play at your desired paceCinematic button to help you sit back and enjoy grand battles Cons: Multiplayer games can be quite sluggish and take very long periods of time to finish so be sure to save between play sessions Limitations of the engine and poor connections from time-to-time can sometimes make it difficult to enjoy online gameplay No campaign or rich backstory - The lore is quite interesting, but they never expanded upon it, which could have made the game ever betterDated graphics – I imagine there is a mod to fix this issue if you don't enjoy the current graphical qualityNot a large player base for online multiplayer so I highly recommend playing with a friend Note: Give this game a solid chance, even if it seems overwhelming at first.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												Sins of a Solar Empire has to be one of the most diversified Real Time Strategy Games that I have played within the last Decade of my Life. I have yet to complete very much research into the back story, and lore of each faction, but there is not much of a campaign to speak of either with the Game, so it's up to you to explore which faction you most identify with. There are Three primary Factions which are playable, while each Faction is divided into the primary Faction, and the Extremist Factions each providing their own unique bonuses and strategies. Did I mention there were Pirates in the game, and  they love to collect Bounty. You will have Tons of opportunities to explore the Game during Solo Play with a couple AI Enemies, I would highly encourage this to learn the Ropes of the Game before full immersion into a Multilayer Game. Have you ever felt like creating your own Galaxy, and then try to Conquer it in its entirety? You can do that with a decent Computer and Sins of a Solar Empire. Did I mention how great all the DLC Expansions compliment the Game, and allow for a much more diversified and unique Galaxy each time you begin a new Game? One time I thought it would be Awesome if I could Control an entire Fleet during a space battle after watching Star Wars for the first time in my life, after purchasing Sins of a Solar Empire, my Dreams became a Reality. Would you like your fellow Clan or Guild Members to hail you as the Galactic Emperor? This could be a Reality for you too with this Game, a little practice, and possibly a couple personal pointers from yours truly.. One aspect that I felt was missing from the Game was the ability to Control each Ship yourself, which I think would be fricken Awesome. Ultimately the Game will be as vast as your Imagination, and Free Time will allow; Many games can be finished within Two to Three hours, I also have some on-going Games which might never end. If I were to describe the Game to you from here on through the rest of this Review, I would make sure to include the Fact that you start out with a Home Planet, and through Military Skill, Intelligent Research, swift Expansion to surrounding Planets, dominating your Local Star, Cultural Assimilation, Diplomatic Relations, and Teamwork, you gradually Conquer the Solar System, Planet by Planet. You will eradicate all Competition, punishing Pirates, or placing Bounty on other Players, hiring said Pirates to do your Dirty Work. Did I mention that you can develop each Planet, and harvest the necessary Resources to Build up and Expand your Armada, and Empire? I heard that the Black Market can always provide a quick Economic Stimulus when you're in a Financial Bind, I've never uttered a more true to Life Statement. Don't forget to do your Research, because there are Multiple Tech Trees to Explore and unlock, which provide great Offensive, or Defensive Bonuses, as well as♥♥♥♥♥♥that helps your Empire expand. Your Fleet may consist of a vast array of unique Ships, each with their own Strengths, depending on your Research Levels, you can quickly Constrict your Opponents to close Proximity Conflicts. One other thing I thought to mention would be the great Modding Community, remember when I was so into Star Wars earlier? There's a Mod for that... Yea when I think of the ultimate Futuristic Space Real Time Strategy Game, Sins of A Solar Empire has become my number One, so go ahead and purchase this game next time you see it on sale, because it is a Great Game, which I feel I have gotten the value of what I had paid for it initially, Ten Fold after my First successful Galactic Conquest. Remember Space is Mankind's final Frontier; Look to the Stars for they are the Future.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												This is one of the best games of the sapce RTS genre.3 races are available humans in the form of the TEC, upgraded humans called the advent and the alien race known as the vasari, each race is divided between loyalist and rebel faction, so a total of 6 factions are available each factions has its own specific cons and pros.The game is just beautiful, you can see wonderfull planets, asteroids and stars, zoom in/out from seeing just stars to a single fighter flying around, watch how your planets come to life whith ships flying around trading and all, its just amazing.The game functions as many RTS with resource gathering, create buildings, research tech and build units, there is a black market where you can buy/sell extra metal or crystal, there are pirates that attack players who have a bounty on there empire and make a random attack on their space holdings.You get general control of the planets and of its civilian aspect and a much finer control over military aspects. asteroids  and planets colonized have a limited number of upgrade points and building slots all dependent on the type of world it is, this allows you to gear some worlds as defense points, fleet builders or resource gathering depending on their base capacity.your fleet is made of a mixture of capital ships, frigates, cruisers, fighters and one titan (if you can get it on space). Capital ships and the titan have a certain rpg element, they get experience and can unlock powers that can then be leveled up as they destroy stuff or if they are present at the destruction of an enemy. The rest of the ships are just cannon fodder or muscle to augment your big ships power. there is a fleet cap, but you can upgrade the cap so you can field more ships, the con of having bigger fleets is the upkeep cost, which becomes a more severe penalty as you get bigger fleets.There is something that has to be said about gameplay and that is this games is only a skirmish and multiplayer game, there is no storyline campaing, i have not found this to make this game any less enjoyable but if you are into just the lore of things then it is a factor to consider.

Posted: January 8, 2016
												This game is kind of a tough call. While I do really like it, I also started getting annoyed by it very suddenly. If you play against AI, and have multiple AI, they end up ganging up on you, and not fighting eachother. Which may not be a big problem at fist glance, but then the real problem occurs. Super weapons. The AI spams them to no end. And it's incredibly frustrating after a short time. Once the game goes on for a while, you end up bogged down in a boring defend against wave after wave of enemies while rebuilding your rear planets over and over due to super weapon attacks war of attrition. And not one of material/money, but of patience.I'd love to recomend the game because it is fun, but this fatal flaw for anyone who doesn't want to just rush every single game, leads me little choice but to vote no. Had I known of this issue before I bought the game, I wouldn't have bought it at all.The AI issue you can fix somewhat, by locking the teams. But the super weapon issue, there is no fix for, as the mods I've found that allow them to be disabled either don't work at all, or cause the game to crash every 10 minutes or so.If all you want to do is rush constantly, every single game, then by all means get the game. But if you prefer longer, but still winable games against 5+ AI, play something else.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												It's certainly become one of the most enjoyable Space RTS games out there, and serves as a solid RTS in general. Do be warned that the pacing is quite slow (though there are plenty of options, both during the game and in the set-up, to circumvent that) and multiplayer isn't exactly a crowning feature. The touted 4X elements are certainly more present here than they were in the vanilla game, but you'll need the moderately priced DLC to really achieve the advertised combination. Alternatively, you can use mods, which are fairly easy to install.Also, there is no campaign, and there likely won't be one. The backstory, while interesting, is all you get. So, you'd better enjoy skirmish mode.For those of you who owned the vanilla game (and only vanilla) this is a significant improvement, as it comes bundled with the two other expansions, Entrenchment and Diplomacy. If you owned the Trilogy edition...not so much. The core Rebellion content mainly focuses on faction diversification. There are now six total factions, consisting of two sects of each of the three vanilla factions. They play very differently, especially in the late game when their tech trees begin to diverge. The TEC Loyalists, for example, are centered around an impenetrable defense and long-range bombardment, whereas the Vasari Loyalists become extremely devoted to mobility and attritive tactics (as in, they operate without terrestrial holdings and can cannibalize conquered worlds). New means of attaining victory have been added, from Diplomatic to KotH and more. The graphics are enhanced, and two new ship classes (super-massive, incredibly powerful Titans and "just-barely-larger-than-a-squadron-unit, Titan-slaying Corvettes) are included as well.But, I'm really starting to ramble and repeat the description, so, yeah, consider purchasing this game if you're a fan of the 4X genre. The scale is literally massive (hundreds of planets, several star systems) and the lasers are pretty.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2016
												This game is almost good, but there are a few unpolished aspects of it that make the experience less enjoyable. Mostly just minor shortcomings in rules and coherence, but also some major aspects of gameplay. Some examples:-You cant view maps before playing them in singleplayer-Your own ships wander stupidly into minefields even when you tell them to hold position-There is only skirmish mode in singleplayer, despite the misleading cinematic trailer-Pirates continue to launch raids after youve decimated their entire base-Build times are painfully slow for everything, and there are constant deadlocks where your only option is just to wait and watch your resources tick upwards at an agonizing rate (this can probably be resolved on larger maps with more planets)-Along a similar vein, upgrades are weak (5-10% bonuses, maybe 25% when maxed out) which is fine if you like the RPG style gameplay, but if you like shorter matches (smaller maps), you can only get fractional increases in power before you are at the endgame.-Upgrades have very minor visual effects (if any) and battle amount to just watching ships stand in place repeatedly firing little uneventful beams at each other for minutes on endetc..I would hold off on this one unless you get it in a sale.

Posted: November 25, 2013
												Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion is an incredibly in-depth flower shop simulator. The many different flower types and themes will keep you coming back for more and the fact that competing flower shops will send their flowers at you to destroy your flowers makes the game a fast-paced flower shop simulator - something all other simulators to this day have thoroughly failed at accomplishing. If I had to say one thing that was bad about this, it would be the flower production. I liked how the space theme fits very well in this game - you send flowers to others in space and they send some back to you but I find it hard to believe that you'd need so much resourses to make flowers. However, that must have been a design choice that I just don't understand yet.I give this game 2 fertilizers out of 1 sprout.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 18, 2014
												So the game was on sale, it was set in space, and was listed as a Multiplayer, stratagy game.. 'Worth a look' I thought. I watched the trailer, and was bored half way through.. But, it does boast some impressive stuff sooo 'Lets watch some in-game vids on youtube' I thought to myself. 2 mins in, I had purchased a 4 pack for me and some buddies. I was actually sat on the edge of my sofa waiting for the game to install.. It looked complex from what I could see.. but hey, that makes the game better!Now as much as I want to recommend the tutorials..  it did take me 3 hours to run through all the tutorials, just because they're are as boring as hell to do. They did however prepare me for some basic gameplay so in I jumped ready for some action! Now skipping past my first few games, or the learning phase, as I call it. I put myself against 3 Ai and no word of a lie, it lasted over 9 hours. The game took so many turns it was untrue.. one moment I was winning hands down, then it all collapsed around me as my culture was taken over! I then brought it back again only to have the Ai turn things around again.. It all sounds horrible but infact it was incredible fun! For a game to be so well built that you can turn your hand to something different to bring it all back again is great. Multiplayer is also great fun.. you can team up or go FFA.. Even during FFA you can raise your diplomacy with your friends, and/or your enemies. While your friend and you are teaming together to bring an enemy faction down, you can be employing other races to form against your friend, leaving them defenceless for when you decide to declare war again ;)For fans of older games like 'Birth of the Federation' 'Star wars Supremacy' 'Homeworld' or Civilisation, then be prepared to lose yourself inan absolutely incredible stratagy game! I was only made aware of this game due to a steam sale, but it is well worth the £29.99 price tag.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												An unprecedentedly complex strategy game that has sucked an impressive amount of my time into its machinations.As a fervent player of strategy games, I know more than most about the quality and standard of modern strategy games. Thus, it was to my pleasure to find that the gameplay of this game took me completely by surprise. When I purchased this game (due to a passing recommendation by a friend) I was expecting a mediocre 'annihilate-and-win' type of strategy game. What I found instead was a game that truly catered for just about any type of strategy player. One can win via a multiple of ways spanning from cultural domination to research to the common exterminate victory to name just a few. The cultural element of the game was a particularly impressive feature. As a strategist who prefers to punch my enemies into submission, I realized that the threat posed by a culturally superior race only too late in my first few games, where I believed I was winning the game through annihilation. Hence, unlike most strategy games, those who prefer to fortify and dig into their defences can technically still win the game without firing a single shot into the enemy ranks.The resource accumilation and the ship upkeep features tends to keep most players in check, ensuring that no particular player can expand so quickly that he should overwhelm a coalition of players teaming up against him. This is a neat feature, as it forces players to think cunningly, lest too many of his enemies turn against him united in hate or paranoia.Amongst other notable features, I also found the time taken to travel between planets to be a key feature of this game. I had not originally known that travelling between say... 4 planets would take a decent amount of time. This means by the time my main fleet arrives to defend a planet under siege, it has probably already been raised to the ground. Hence, players are forced to pre-empt incoming attacks or opt to divide and conquer.The multiplayer experience is quite enjoyable as this game seems to have a relatively small but extremely friendly following. I was pleasantly surprised to find there are plenty of new players to the multiplayer experience as well as veterans who can teach a newcomer a thing or two.Overall, Sins of a Solar Empire ranks very, very highly amongst my favourite strategy games. While the visuals of the game is not entirely awe-inspiring, it is very obvious the developers paid a significant portion of their time working on the mechanics of the game. I am happy to say that personally for me, their hard work has paid off and left a very satisfied player in their wake.Overall Score: 9/10 - Extremely satisfying to play, would highly recommend.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2014
												First of all this is the first RTS game that I have ever played so I had no idea what I was getting into. I saw the trailer and thought, "Wow this is pretty cool looking I think I'll get it." What it turned out to be was the best descision of my gaming life. I started up the game and playedthe tutorials to get used to the gameplay. The tutorials were very user friendly in my opinion and the game have easy to grasp concepts while always having something new for me to find about the gameplay. I started a game on a tiny map and played until I won. Only then did I realize that I just played for 4 hours straight. The game really grasps your imaginiation and does not limit what you can do in the game. If you want to go on the offensive go for it, The defensive? Do that also! But your not only limited to this you are able to do diplomatic solutions and trade during the game with other players. Not only all of this but this game has one the best modding communities I have ever seen. There are so many great mods out there for this game that are constantly being made and updated. A few of my favorites are Star Trek Armada 3, Sins of the Prophets, and Sins of a Galactic Empire. All of these great mods have dedicated modders that are able to answer your questions at any point and this game has a loyal fan base. After all of my playing, winning, and losing only then did I realize I did not know anything about the storyline. When I read the wiki on it I was amazed and the amount of lore this game has accumalated over the different games and after reading it I see the game in whole new light. I have about 200 hours logged and I am planning to log another 200.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
												If you love strategy, compiling of unique races and factions, and wide variety of territory to conquer, this is the Game for you. You even control the rate at which things get built, resources earned, how fast ships travel, and speed of many other attributes to the game, using settings, if you choose. If you love random replayability where one game you can win, but the next with all the same settings, but game developed differently from beginning, becomes a little more difficult and you lose; this game is for you!If you enjoy production genre of space shows, like; Star Trek, Star Wars, Battlestar Gallactica, and other scifi shows/movies about Galactic control, this game is for you. Everything I mentioned, I enjoy! I also enjoy Sid Meier's Civilization Series, Empire Earth, Command and Conquer, Galactic Civilization II, Age of Empires series, Master of Orion series, Star Craft the original, and many more. To give you an idea of this game compared to some of my favorites I listed... SoaSE:R (or SINS for short), has kind of a Star Craft three different races feel, mixed with the massive galactic control and Diplomacy of Master of Orion, and a fast pace strategy set of Empire Earth and Age of Empires, however to experience the unique faction diversity set between each of the three main Races, their is no real comparison... you just have to Experience Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion for your self.I personally love the Vasari Loyalist; Their unique ability to create their own phase lanes and travel between stars as they see fit, with their Kostura Cannon attack of defenses on a target leaving its own Phase Node behind, matched with the Titan's powerful warship and ability to terrorize enemy forces jumping around inside planet's Gravity Wells, as well as around the different planets, are some reasons why I enjoy the Vasari Loyalist! However, nothing can match the Cultural power of the Advent, and their ability to manipulate the culture across the Galaxy with their super weapon Deliverance engine casting a massive culture bomb behind enemy lines. If timed right, having a powerful armada close to a target for culture bomb, and the right research, Advent forces can get a huge combat bonus within your own culture, in side the enemy bases if fighting within the culture bomb influence. They also have many power mind control abilities to take away many ships! Nothing compares to the Massive economic power of the TEC (Trader Emergency Coalition), and their ability to expand fast and cover the cost, and earn much more power through commerce compared to the other two. TEC also can coerce the Pirates factions, and all natives across the Galaxy to side with them, creating an unwavering force of friendly support  across the map, and cause relentless waves of mild assaults by unforeseen pirate raids among different Enemy bases! If played right, any of the three races, and the split factions within, can become a powerful force to be reconned with! Can YOU build an Empire, to Stand the Test of SPACE and TIME?If still interested, feel free to check my steam profile... I have many screenshots, already posted... and more going up all the time!

content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												I had heard of Sins of a Solar Empire several years ago through a few mod creators I knew, and I finally decided I needed to buy it about a couple months ago. Needless to say based on my play time alone it has quickly rose the ranks of some of my favorite RTS games, and has even eclipsed some in replay value. The competetive play, and straightforward gameplay make this game an absolute must buy.My thoughts on the game are mostly positive, but like all games there's a few downfalls... The largest of which would have to be the fact that it's not compatible with hyper-threading, and even refuses to use more than a couple of gigs of RAM which makes it minidump quite often. There's several fixes to this, and I personally have not experienced a crash on this game for a month after using certain software that most mod makers use for this game to make thier mods less susceptible to crashing.Once again, I HIGHLY recommend this game, and even further recommend playing it with mods due to how much support there is in its community to make them.

I did get it on sale, which I would reccommend if you can manage, but truth be told I would have happily paid full price for such a great game.

content:
Posted: June 12, 2012
												Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion includes all the previous expansions and the core game, whisked and combined into a standalone which is astounding value for money.RTS4X stands for "Real Time Strategy; eXplore, eXpand, eXploit, eXterminate", simply put: It is a strategy game that has a huge overlay of space-empire micromanagement and birds-eye-view strategy, whilst keeping the real time battles simultaneously active.This game truly is a space opera, as huge battles take place whilst perhaps your strike-fleet is sneaking around the back to hit the enemy where they least expect it. Maybe you are sending your spaceships to different solar-systems or plunging into the depths of a worm-hole, to seek the treasures (or dangers) on the recieving end.The game has similar aspects of the game Galactic Civilisations and Star Trek Armada, mixed and refined into a stunning, heart-pounding, yet relaxing game.If you love space games, empire games and RTS games, this is going to tickle you.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												This is a 4x game. There are 3 races and with the DLC 1 new faction for each race is added, bringing the total 'races' you can play up to 6. For a single player game it takes me around 3.5 hours, and thats with 2 hard bots one easy bot and me. Multiplayer is even more fun, since u can colab and even help move each other around (the vasari rebels share their phase tech). I dont think ive ever uninstalled this game. This is my default time sink game, and its fun every time. If you like Sword of the Stars, you will like this, only difference is the smaller tech pool and you cant modify your ships hardpoints. I just wish that the publisher would release more dlc (like this is a really bad complaint). If you like 4x, the idea of having ships so big that they are the size of planets, and commanding multiple fleets in realtime to own the galaxy, then this is a game for YOU! ^_^eXplore: planets for artifacts, the galaxy for planets and your enemyeXperiment: research your titan your factions ultra-flagship, can macross missles with lasers!eXpand: that oceanic world would be perfect to house the seat of your propganda machine!eXtermanate: TITANS dont change the flow of the battle, titans are a wave that assure victory.tl;dr compare other 4X to this.

The cultural element of the game was a particularly impressive feature. As a strategist who prefers to punch my enemies into submission, I realized that the threat posed by a culturally superior race only too late in my first few games, where I believed I was winning the game through annihilation. Hence, unlike most strategy games, those who prefer to fortify and dig into their defences can technically still win the game without firing a single shot into the enemy ranks.The resource accumilation and the ship upkeep features tends to keep most players in check, ensuring that no particular player can expand so quickly that he should overwhelm a coalition of players teaming up against him. This is a neat feature, as it forces players to think cunningly, lest too many of his enemies turn against him united in hate or paranoia.Amongst other notable features, I also found the time taken to travel between planets to be a key feature of this game. I had not originally known that travelling between say... 4 planets would take a decent amount of time. This means by the time my main fleet arrives to defend a planet under siege, it has probably already been raised to the ground. Hence, players are forced to pre-empt incoming attacks or opt to divide and conquer.The multiplayer experience is quite enjoyable as this game seems to have a relatively small but extremely friendly following. I was pleasantly surprised to find there are plenty of new players to the multiplayer experience as well as veterans who can teach a newcomer a thing or two.Overall, Sins of a Solar Empire ranks very, very highly amongst my favourite strategy games. While the visuals of the game is not entirely awe-inspiring, it is very obvious the developers paid a significant portion of their time working on the mechanics of the game. I am happy to say that personally for me, their hard work has paid off and left a very satisfied player in their wake.Overall Score: 9/10 - Extremely satisfying to play, would highly recommend.

												An unprecedentedly complex strategy game that has sucked an impressive amount of my time into its machinations.As a fervent player of strategy games, I know more than most about the quality and standard of modern strategy games. One can win via a multiple of ways spanning from cultural domination to research to the common exterminate victory to name just a few. The cultural element of the game was a particularly impressive feature. As a strategist who prefers to punch my enemies into submission, I realized that the threat posed by a culturally superior race only too late in my first few games, where I believed I was winning the game through annihilation. Hence, unlike most strategy games, those who prefer to fortify and dig into their defences can technically still win the game without firing a single shot into the enemy ranks.The resource accumilation and the ship upkeep features tends to keep most players in check, ensuring that no particular player can expand so quickly that he should overwhelm a coalition of players teaming up against him. I had not originally known that travelling between say... 4 planets would take a decent amount of time. This means by the time my main fleet arrives to defend a planet under siege, it has probably already been raised to the ground. Hence, players are forced to pre-empt incoming attacks or opt to divide and conquer.The multiplayer experience is quite enjoyable as this game seems to have a relatively small but extremely friendly following. I was pleasantly surprised to find there are plenty of new players to the multiplayer experience as well as veterans who can teach a newcomer a thing or two.Overall, Sins of a Solar Empire ranks very, very highly amongst my favourite strategy games. content:
Posted: December 31, 2012
												Stardock built a monster of a space strategy game with Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion. The definitive space 4X title, Sins leaves nothing to be desired: massive space battles, capital ships and Titans gaining levels and abilities, lots of maps, random generated maps, discoverable artifacts, orbital weapons, starbases, etc, etc, etc.. The game is brutal, yet offers multiple paths to victory and defeat. The tech trees are huge, the races are different but balanced, the carnage is massive. The first edition came out in 2008, and Stardock has made an already great game even better. The real deal.9/10

content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												I had prepped the largest fleet in the system for an invasion of the final enemy's homeworld. Including ships that could take on full fleets by themselves. And sent them to the planet. When they arrived, a giant ♥♥♥♥off space station, armed to the bloody teeth, began slaughtering my fleet from the bottom up, first the corvettes, then the frigates, then the cruisers, etc. Then their titan warped in to engage my own, and with that, I had to order my last few ships into retreat. Only my titan managed to, on about 1% hp, limp back to my forward base, the enemy fleet right behind it.Then I got mad and fired my two planet-destroyer nuclear cannons hidden on the other side of the star system as a backup plan, in case the glorious frontal assault didn't work, and genocided the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of them, destroying an entire culture in just 2 shots. 8/10 would space againActual review: Large scale, slooooow paced RTS with some nice space battles, easy to use interface (one you learn where everything is), some nice variety in the factions, and an interesting dynamic with the neutral fleets of militia and pirates that will launch their own periodic assaults on your worlds and trade routes. Graphics understandably look a little rough up close, and it requires a significant time investment per game, and the ability to form fleet formations would be nice, but overall, a damn solid space RTS.Think of a mix between Civ/similar and Supreme Commander/similar. That's about what you get here. Well worth picking up the next time you see it on sale.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												PEWPEWPEWSpace-based-RTS. you build up your planets, you build up your fleet, and then there are a few big engagements and then you win. There are enough different methods you can use to get there, earlygame strats mostly revolve around either getting a fast fleet out to harass enemies or expanding as fast as possible to secore more income. Midgame is where all the big fleet engagements start, with fleets of around 30 ships on each side. balancing production with research and your spead of culture is  difficult, as lagging behind in any one of these will make the lategame painful. Finally, you have the massive engagements. a few hundred ships, 3 or 4 will die in the initial volleys. you can't lose a fight or else all your planets will be bombarded and you will die.I like this game.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
												Well, what can I say? Sins of a Solar Empire is brilliant. 9/10The gameplay mechanics do take experience to master, but that's all part of what makes the game so wonderful; there are so many aspects of gameplay to take into consideration when you are in a match, such as culture, research topics, and etcetera. If you think that all you have to do to prevail in a match of Sins is to build a thousand ships and spam orbital cannons, you are sorely mistaken.One thing that appeals to me personally about Sins is the fact that, right from the beginning, you have to meticulously plan out each detail of your empire's expansion, taking into consideration events that could potentially happen hours later.That planet with only one phase lane leading into enemy territory? Chances are your enemy will eventually try to punch through. You'll need to plan for that. The world on the other side of the map that's just starting to produce culture? It will spread to your planets quickly. You'll need to plan for that.That TEC Loyalist player on the other side of the map whose planet pings up for a second with a superweapon alert? You'll especially need to plan for that.The one and only downside for me about Sins is, and I'm sure this is a common one, there's no campaign! The franchise has gone into a good deal of detail creating a backstory, seriously, there's a whole bunch of story content out there. What I would really like to see is an actual in-game campaign in which you can follow one of the three main empires on their quests within this storyline. Another little want of mine is to have a campaign constructor. That would be amazing. If these things were there, a 10/10 game.It's pretty much impossible to get bored of Sins, each game turns out differently from the last. But if, however, you somehow manage to get bored, there's but one thing for that: mods. This game has a Star Trek mod, and subsequently has my seal of approval.This game is amazing. I myself have had endless hours of fun with Sins, and reccommend this entirely to everybody. Get this game right now.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												Before I say anything, I want you people to know that the supposed 2 hours I have in this game are on ONLINE mode. I use mods and play offline a lot, so there should be like 324 hours logged up, but steam doesn't log offline gameplay. Anyway, let me get on with it.This game is absolutely stunning. The graphics are amazing, the AI is very well balanced and smart, and the overall gameplay is absolutely mindblowing. There are hundreds and hundreds of hours worth of gameplay sitting right there waiting for you to buy it. At first, you start off at one planet, your capital planet, and you working on your economy and researching as much as you can. You send off small fleets to neighboring planets to gain control of them and wipe out the garrisons. This cycle continues for around 20 minutes, where you slowly expand your control and research tons of new ships and technology. Eventually, you are able to amass HUGE fleets and hunt down the hostile faction. This is just a small example of how incredibly fun the gameplay is. I have NEVER gotten bored.So what're you waiting for? Buy it.20/10

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2016
												A bit of a mix between a 4X and an RTS game. You can even speed it up.Basically you're going to colonize new planets, research new ships, weapons, policies, bonuses, whatever. Just like you would in Endless Space for example. But everything is in real time and combat is more interesting, like in Homeworld.Unlike in Homeworld though, there is far less micro management of your fleets. There are not fighter and bomber squads to worry about, only different sizes of capital ships, the smalles being frigates and cruisers I think, up to the very deadly Titan class warship, of wich you can only have 1.SoaSE has 3 races (with 3 rebel factions each). Each has different ships, policies and research trees. The DLC is ok, but only on discount.There's also pirates, bounty hunters and other shenanigans. In my first game I was destroyed slowly but surely by my enemy's "anti planet" weapons, which could basically shoot across the whole system.It's a fun game and has great mod support, while not looking or running terribly, but the lack of a dedicated campaign mode makes it a bit dull in my opinion. If you like Multiplayer or Skirmish modes, however, and you love Space RTS games with DEEP mechanics, this might just be for you.

content:
Posted: January 21
												If you've played Trinity, Rebellion is not too much different than Diplomacy, but the extras are more than enough reason for a seasoned Sins player to pick this game up when it goes on sale.If you haven't played Sins before, you're missing out on one of the most engrossing, complex RTS games out there. Word of warning, if you want to finish an entire game in one sitting, be prepared for several hours, and the learning curve for multiplayer is steep, but if you put in a few hours to really learn the game, you'll love it as much as I do. For a casual player, you can play smaller games and save your progress and pick up a half-finished game whenever you please.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 28, 2015
												:THIS REVIEW IS SOMEWHAT BIAS:This game provides you the thrill of controlling an empire that listens to every command you make. Whether it is wiping an entire race from it's existence, or building a giant cannon that shoots the image of god to an enemy home world, either way it's really fun.  You get to choose between three factions, each containing the Loyalists(True Empire) or the Rebels, with various ways of winning the game.The factions are and contain the following empires:T.E.C. : Loyalists and RebelsVasari: Loyalists and RebelsAdvent:Loyalists and RebelsEach faction has their own personal upgrades that shared between the the two empires in that faction, along  with their own personal ships, star bases, culture, and more. And depending the empire you choose you have to use different victory options and strategies. And one common thing that all players have to deal with are space pirates. Although they are annoying, they can be dealt with pretty easily especially late game. Your currency for all empires are called credits, along with metal and crystals. In order to have a good functioning empire you need all the three in order to purchase ships, research new technologies, and to grow.Positives:Intelligent A.I. (especially in combat)Detailed ships,planets, and structuresAllows mods (Star Trek, Star Wars, Battle Star Galactica,etc)High replayabilityEasy to learn with helpful tutorialNegatives:Ships and structures can sometimes use auto use (Which makes them use a special ability) even after disabledPirates generally attack only one empire the whole game, very hard to pay offConstant connection and save problems when playing onlineConstant supervision of planets, ships,etcThat is all I can really remember at this time, note that this review is somewhat incomplete due to my bias opinion and my inexperience in the game. I recommend this game to anyone who enjoys awesome space battles, hardcore strategy, and management.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 10, 2013
												Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion is a fantastic example of what can be done with a 4X RTS. It excels in so many ways it’s difficult to narrow them all down, but in short, its main pull is that it provides the depth and time not seen in many of the other RTS games out there. That being said, the games in Sins tend to take anywhere from 40 minutes, to 4 hours, so anyone who wants a shorter, more fast paced experience should look elsewhere. On a very important side note, the multitude of mods out there can REALLY improve the experience. Three I'd personally recommend are: Sins of a Galactic Empire (A Star Wars based mod), Enhanced 4X, and Sins of the Prophets (Halo based).

content:
Posted: February 21
												I dabbled a little in the game and all of it against tougher ai opponents, while most of it is a really great game, one or two little things kind of ruins the mood of what i am doing. for example i like to prolong the fighting over a long duration and make the ai come to me while i grind their forces down to the point i can launch attacks on their systems when the chance presents itself. i never leave myself exposed to an attack.when i finally whittle out a colony belonging to one of the ai enemies and take it over, suddenly every superweapon from every other ai targets that new acquisition and rends it uninhabitable, it not only slows down progress to a crawl, but how can ai's from all the way across the galaxy that has no beef with me or even knows i setup a colony there suddenly have this idea to launch their super weapons at it? i mean all of them?so while there are some questionable AI actions that ruins the mood a bit, there are also the super weapons themselves;The novalith warhead attacks a single target causing minimal disruption, now a colony with a planetary shield can take a few novalith hits, which severely limits it's ability to be a superweapon. frankly it's underpowered and absurdly so.the deliverance signal on the other end is significantly overpowered in comparison and it does far more damage to several colonies with it's overwhelming signal strength and duration. now unless you got a cultural rate over something like 200 over these multiple planets to make it very difficult for the signal to persist for long, otherwise repeated hits is far more devastating than a fleet of ships could evr provide, not only that, but if you kept launching signals against their former worlds after them losing control and you kill off their colonizer ships and colonizer cap ships as well. you won't even need to face the rest of their forces. it should get a bit of a nerf to it.the last one of the list is a warhead that explodes at a planet, causing all projects to be suspended in planetary orbit until it wears off. if the colony is not under any threat at all, it makes this weapon useless to have and not only that but it don't effect starbases. it's only use is in advance of your main attack force but still is just as uneffective as the novalith.as it is, there needs to be a balance check there. anyway, these are the one or two little problems i have with the game, the rest of it is very enjoyable to get into and play.

content:
Posted: June 12, 2014
												I'll admit, I was one of those people who played the original for about 30 minutes and became confused at how technical and fiddly it all seemed, so gave up. However when SoaSE : R was put on a hefty sale, I decided to do some research and after watching some YT videos of mods and other awesome moments, and with copious positive reviews both on and offline, I decided to pick it up. I'll say right now, that it's still a very fiddly game, but I've sunk about 2 evenings worth of time playing it and even more time thinking about it. It's easily one of the most proficient games when it comes to Fleet management and empire building in a Sci-Fi genre. Solid mechanics, excellent economy system and fantastic battle simulations (could still be better with more animated battles, but the particle effects and light shows are still great to watch). If you need a good comparison of a game, think Supreme Commander fused with Civilization. Definitely worth a buy. =D
