content:
Posted: July 13, 2013
												This is a very fun game. I can't believe I didn't recommend it sooner. The replayability of this game is superior to virtually all space-based rts games. There's no real campaign to speak of, but the beauty lies in the co-op and versus maps which you can generate according to your own preferences. I prefer large universes that takes days to dominate, while others prefer universes you can conquer in an hour. The graphis are superb and and the balance is expertly done. I highly recommend this game to any fan of space-based real time strategy games. If you get it, give me a shout so we can play! I'd give it an 8 out of 10 (-2 points for the lack of a single player campaign).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												The game itself is fantastic. I run it at the highest graphics settings because I can, so maybe I'm jaded in that respect. However, upon entering the game, I was asked to make a stardock account. Im not a fan of games that dont directly link to my steam account, but this one seemed (and is) worth it. I did the tutorials, which I see no problem with. As with any in-depth strategy game, the tutorials are only there so you aren't saying "what does this button do?" later. Once youre done with those, do yourself a favor and set up a small map with an easy AI. Thats the real tutorial. I have played Civ 5 almost religously (I bring it up because it seems to be the most common comparison) and yes, its tutorial teaches you more in a shorter time frame. HOWEVER Civ 5 was also dumbed down quite a bit from its predecessor, if you know your civ. While I admit to not having played enough to get a feel for the power balance among the 6 different factions you can play as, they seem to creatively offer different playstyles, most related to war. An in-game simplistic map creator and adjustable settings of almost anything in the game (victory speeds, quick starts, team locks, ect.) score big points. Mods are endless, Star Wars comes to mind almost immediately. The ONLY MAJOR CON I HAVE ENCOUNTERED is the multiplayer system. Accross PC and console gaming I have never seen a lobby/host/chat system as confusing as SINS. There is a seperate tab for a hosting test, which has a single check box for alloy. I have no idea what alloy is, and still dont after reading multiple stardock FAQs. It says it is used to identify the IP address of your computer to allow hosting. I honestly have no idea what that means, and I personally feel as though it scares away players with little to no knowledge in that area. If it doesnt, the technical guides will. I tried reading the help sections, and posted were comments rich in IT language and computer terms I wasn't familiar with, and most certainly wasn't comfortable with changing on my computer, especially when one of the few words I understand in those comments is "firewall". From the number of commenters and views, a great many other people are having the same problems. I would like to be able to host a multiplayer game, just as easily as I can in any other game, such as Civ 5. I do NOT want to have to become an IT guy to play a 1v1 with a friend. I reccomend the game, and should multiplayer become clearer to me I will edit or respond to this review. However, potential buyers YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED. Multiplayer is confusing and complicated and appears to me as though it cannot do what other games can. I would like to see improvements from the DEV team in the future, if only in its coherency. Love the look. But when setting up a game with other people is harder than learning a real-time, in-depth stategy game, it kills most of the fun. 7/10 from me. For now

content:
Posted: November 26, 2012
												It's...an expansion for Sins. Core gameplay is the same, changes include corvettes, which are smaller than frigates but just as fast (and just as ♥♥♥♥ING annoying) as strike craft), and titans, which are apparently ♥♥♥♥huge ships but in all honesty I haven't built one personally yet because they are really really expensive. The 3 races from the original Sins have been "split" into 6, I say "split" because between the loyalist and rebel factions of each of the original races share much of the same units and research upgrades, however there are some small differences. Speaking of research upgrades, the trees got cleaned up a bit too. All in all, if you like Sins pick up Rebellion, it's the same but with more.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 2, 2013
												A complex game of resource management, strategy, and out-thinking your opponent. Although I have little multiplayer experience, I've experienced enough to realize it's extremely competitive, with a small but dedicated playerbase.  The vast majority of this game's players seem to play skirmish battles alone or with a few friends.The game has extreme longevity/replayability due to it's highly moddable nature. I know of at least 3 star wars mods, a halo mod, a mass effect mod, 2 star trek mods, and a host of others that make less drastic changes. The AI is a decently challenging opponent, although it has it's weaknesses as all AI does. Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion is fairly well optimized, with some slowdown late-game due to it's 32-bit nature.Overall I'd highly recommend, as this is both a fine game for competitive multiplayer, or more casual games played against the AI.

This was one of the earliest games I played (probably second actually) and I had the game of the year edition on disk (so don't let the time counter fool you, I've actually spent a lot more time on sins outside of steam). Honestly from a space RTS I really couldn't ask for much more. It's a slightly old game so the graphics aren't "next gen" however the interface is very convenient and allows for quick switching between zoomed out tactical views to help manage your fleet battles, and a more up close cinematic view to really engage the player into what's going on. The civilization management aspect is also very indepth and has many different factors which need to be accounted for when making certain decisions. Coupling that with a very indepth research tree (many aspects of which are race specific) and the other deep differences in the entire play style of the three races, there's a lot of varience for enjoyable replayability.Honestly thought... I'd say the best part is just the scale the battles can get too, and mine haven't even been that grand compared to other's I've seen. It's quite enjoyable to watch a fleet of 100 frigates, and 50 or so cruisers charge into a pirate base, only for their pirate adversaries to just be engulphed and devoured in your swarms of hundreds of fighters and bombers at the ready. Also... the main difference the rebellion version has over the rest is that it adds two subfactions to eatch race, loyalists and rebels, and each of these subfactions has their own individual titan, which is just awesome. The titans add a new aspect to the combat as they can be the definite deciding factor in many of your future battles, and when you watch one plow through the enemy frigates like a steam roller... well let's just say it's satisfying.So honestly all in all I think it's worth it and you can get a lot of hours out of it. Of course it's still smart to wait for sales, so if it's on sale for cheap I'd say snatch it up. However that's just me and my experiences, I hope this helped, bye!

content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion, is possibly one of the best "expansions" to a game I have ever played. Why do I say "expansion" you might ask, well, the basic point is, SOASE:Rebellion is a full game "expansion". Not an add on pack, you don't need to own the original game, you just need to put $15 on the table and pick up a wonderfully crafted, beautifully balanced product.The basic premise of SOASE is to build a giant army of death bringing spaceships, and ram them as close as you can to other giant armies of death. Repeat steps 1-2 four hundred times and eventually you might get somewhere.PRO TIP: Have a bigger, more expensive, giant death army than the other players. More likely to win that way.It may sound repetitive, and it is, but you won't notice as giant lazer beams of death come out of your giant space ship and kills 4 spaceships at once. This game is brilliant on high powered PC's and even runs on Mac (PC is reccomended though because it looks great at 1080p on ultra)This game is a definite buy for you, and all of your friends.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 2, 2013
												A complex game of resource management, strategy, and out-thinking your opponent. Although I have little multiplayer experience, I've experienced enough to realize it's extremely competitive, with a small but dedicated playerbase.  The vast majority of this game's players seem to play skirmish battles alone or with a few friends.The game has extreme longevity/replayability due to it's highly moddable nature. I know of at least 3 star wars mods, a halo mod, a mass effect mod, 2 star trek mods, and a host of others that make less drastic changes. The AI is a decently challenging opponent, although it has it's weaknesses as all AI does. Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion is fairly well optimized, with some slowdown late-game due to it's 32-bit nature.Overall I'd highly recommend, as this is both a fine game for competitive multiplayer, or more casual games played against the AI.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
												An ambitious RTS that tried to do a lot of things and actually pulled it off rather well.  Essentially it takes some 4X game elements, simplifies them a bit, and puts them into a sci-fi RTS environment.+Lots of exploration, technologies to research, and planets to be built up while you amass a fleet and defences+AI puts up a decent fight on hardest non-cheating setting+Decent variety of units and defences to keep games interesting, with each race broken into 2 sub-factions for more variety+Starbases and titans are really neat+Save function in multiplayer so you and a friend(s) can takes as long as you like to finish a large map.+Smaller maps for those who want a quicker, more aggressive game+TCP/IP and LAN multiplayer options; possibly one of the last games to have such options.-Competitive multiplayer, which was never really alive even at the game's peak, is dead at this point-Even with saves, not really an RTS that's suitable for short sessions beyond small 1v1 matches.-Pretty barebones diplomacy system-Pirates were a cool idea, but the 'ebay bidding system' for them is horribly done and you'll probably end up turning them off.-There is no campaign or story mode whatsoever.  Who are the Visari, who are they running from, and why do Advent hate the TEC?  Damned if anyone knows.Overall, if you want a good single player FFA or co-op vs AI multiplayer RTS with a bit more depth to it than your usual RTS fare this is a great game.  The lack of story for what seems to be an interesting sci-fi setting is sorely lacking for a game like this though.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												Serious Review time? Ok FineSins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion is a unique space RTS games that centers around moving from planet to planet conquering and establishing your empire. The closest thing you can compare this game to is like playing CiV 5 in space, but its in real time.Other than the homeworld franchise and a little nastalgic empire at war, this is one of the only space RTS games in existence that not only does not suck more than a tai hooker, but it actually pretty well done. Featuring massive and i mean massive battles between fleets of ships by the end game your ships will probably ram into eachother from a siezure because of all the laser beams flying everywhere.As previously stated you start on 1 planet that revolves around 1 star, you then migrate to neighboring planets exterminating anything you come across around the planet, then you invade and conquer the ♥♥♥♥ out of it like a space age christopher columbus. Maps however can be extremely large, featuring multiple stars, each with their own set of planets revolving around them to conquer and add to the might of your empire.Oh did i mention when you attack a planet already controlled by another main faction of the game you literally nuke it from orbit (because its the only way to be sure) until everyone dies and you can recolonize it, if that isnt enough for you then i dont know what is.The reason i also say this game is a real time space version of civ 5 is because the game moves at a slow enough pace that you are playing an RTS, but at the same time you can manage your empire and economy etc with ease. The game also has one of the most well done camera systems ive seen in an RTS game, allowing you can look and go anywhere despite the map being gigantic, all with the simplicity of a scroll wheel.But seriously, one of the best space rts games in existence, So if you are into either i would absolutely recommend buying it. Ever since i bought the original game its given me YEARS of entertainment.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 4, 2015
												One of the best RTS 4X strategy games out there.This game is about pure survival, you will try to use whatever tool necessary to make sure your empire sees another day.It offers the four mighty Xs, Exploring the darkest corners of the solar systems or entire sectors. Expanding your empire by colonizing all kinds of different planets, asteroids and stations. Gathering basic resources which you need for your empire's growth and most importantly eliminating rival opponents in both single or multiplayer matches.One of the greatest features of this game is actually the option to zoom in onto even the smallest objects in the space. Therefore you can enjoy some really beautiful sights of awesome ship and building models and space battles.You can take control over large amount of ships which you can even asign into custom fleets to ease issuing commands.The game's soundtracks are one of the best I've listened to while playing any kind of strategy games, simply marvelous.Both single player and multiplayer gameplay is really smooth and solid. All the base game races are surprisingly well balanced. Every race has its pros and cons, but they share a kind of a basic setup from where the different specializations start off. What really surprised me about this game is that you can actually host a multiplayer match on a public IP with an access to your router's port-forwarding rather than crating LAN or Official lobbies.There are few things that actually dissapoint me about this game.One of them is the lack of any sort of story based missions or a campaign, which is really a shame, because the littly backstory of this game is really interesting and is surely worth pointing out.The other, but not the last thing is about the not very efficient AI difficulty levels.Using increased income bonuses and faster research as a buff for higher difficulty AI is in my opinion wrong move and it is nearly impossible to defeat highest difficulty AI in a regular match just on your own, without anyone else to balance the enormous pressure on, because the enemy's economy overcomes you in just few minutes into the game.Other great thing worth pointing out is the support for mods. There are plenty of awesome mods out there, which can really spice up the gameplay of the base game or add an entire new experience with something new, using conversions.As of the DLCs, If you find yourself enjoying this game at first, and you kinda get into it I certainly recommend adding both of them into your game as each of them adds some minor things and tweaks that can really improve the overall gameplay experience of every match you play.I've played this game for more than a thousand hours in total off-steam and I enjoy every battle I manage to win or lose decisively or just by a pure luck. SoaSER is love, SoaSER is life.Without anything more to say, I would rate this game by 9/10 for how awesome it is.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												The game itself is fantastic. I run it at the highest graphics settings because I can, so maybe I'm jaded in that respect. However, upon entering the game, I was asked to make a stardock account. Im not a fan of games that dont directly link to my steam account, but this one seemed (and is) worth it. I did the tutorials, which I see no problem with. As with any in-depth strategy game, the tutorials are only there so you aren't saying "what does this button do?" later. Once youre done with those, do yourself a favor and set up a small map with an easy AI. Thats the real tutorial. I have played Civ 5 almost religously (I bring it up because it seems to be the most common comparison) and yes, its tutorial teaches you more in a shorter time frame. HOWEVER Civ 5 was also dumbed down quite a bit from its predecessor, if you know your civ. While I admit to not having played enough to get a feel for the power balance among the 6 different factions you can play as, they seem to creatively offer different playstyles, most related to war. An in-game simplistic map creator and adjustable settings of almost anything in the game (victory speeds, quick starts, team locks, ect.) score big points. Mods are endless, Star Wars comes to mind almost immediately. The ONLY MAJOR CON I HAVE ENCOUNTERED is the multiplayer system. Accross PC and console gaming I have never seen a lobby/host/chat system as confusing as SINS. There is a seperate tab for a hosting test, which has a single check box for alloy. I have no idea what alloy is, and still dont after reading multiple stardock FAQs. It says it is used to identify the IP address of your computer to allow hosting. I honestly have no idea what that means, and I personally feel as though it scares away players with little to no knowledge in that area. If it doesnt, the technical guides will. I tried reading the help sections, and posted were comments rich in IT language and computer terms I wasn't familiar with, and most certainly wasn't comfortable with changing on my computer, especially when one of the few words I understand in those comments is "firewall". From the number of commenters and views, a great many other people are having the same problems. I would like to be able to host a multiplayer game, just as easily as I can in any other game, such as Civ 5. I do NOT want to have to become an IT guy to play a 1v1 with a friend. I reccomend the game, and should multiplayer become clearer to me I will edit or respond to this review. However, potential buyers YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED. Multiplayer is confusing and complicated and appears to me as though it cannot do what other games can. I would like to see improvements from the DEV team in the future, if only in its coherency. Love the look. But when setting up a game with other people is harder than learning a real-time, in-depth stategy game, it kills most of the fun. 7/10 from me. For now

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
												An ambitious RTS that tried to do a lot of things and actually pulled it off rather well.  Essentially it takes some 4X game elements, simplifies them a bit, and puts them into a sci-fi RTS environment.+Lots of exploration, technologies to research, and planets to be built up while you amass a fleet and defences+AI puts up a decent fight on hardest non-cheating setting+Decent variety of units and defences to keep games interesting, with each race broken into 2 sub-factions for more variety+Starbases and titans are really neat+Save function in multiplayer so you and a friend(s) can takes as long as you like to finish a large map.+Smaller maps for those who want a quicker, more aggressive game+TCP/IP and LAN multiplayer options; possibly one of the last games to have such options.-Competitive multiplayer, which was never really alive even at the game's peak, is dead at this point-Even with saves, not really an RTS that's suitable for short sessions beyond small 1v1 matches.-Pretty barebones diplomacy system-Pirates were a cool idea, but the 'ebay bidding system' for them is horribly done and you'll probably end up turning them off.-There is no campaign or story mode whatsoever.  Who are the Visari, who are they running from, and why do Advent hate the TEC?  Damned if anyone knows.Overall, if you want a good single player FFA or co-op vs AI multiplayer RTS with a bit more depth to it than your usual RTS fare this is a great game.  The lack of story for what seems to be an interesting sci-fi setting is sorely lacking for a game like this though.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2014
												As a fan of the Sci-Fi genre I love everything that involves massive starship battles, and Sins of a Solar Empire have always delivered on that front, Rebellion brings diffrant factions to the table, it splits the three main factions into six factions, one loyal and one radical faction. The gameplay is much like in the old games, a real time strategy where the goal is to fight it out among the diffrant maps and planets. the maps are usally split up into a number of solar systems, on some maps they are connected by wormholes or you can reach each of the solar systems by traveling by your local Star. each solar system consist of a number off planets that you can colonise, some reqiure a bit of research to anable them to be colonised, while astroid belts can't be colonised at all. Each planet ( depending on the kind of planet, and the ammount of research made) will allow you to produce a number of buildings, such as two kinds of tech labs, one to research defensive and offensive tech for your empire, while the other lab focuses on the economic and diplomatic side of your empire, this will allow for diffrant strategies and a bit on empire planning. then you have the standard Ship factories, one will produce small to medium ships while the other one will construct your capital ships, the core of any armada. These Ships will need research to unlock while the capital ships will require you to research fleet logistics, a sort of supply system were every level of research will unlock more ship supplies and more captains for your capital ships. After these two we have the largest ship your faction can construct, these are faction and race specified, meaning that every faction have their own "Titan" as they are called, while the capitalships and lesser ships are race based. These titans require lots of research and will take quite some time to construct, that said, these ships will more then often decide the outcome of any battle. There is also the possiblity to construct "Trade ports", "media huts" and "refineries" to generate credits or influense the planets around your solar system and generate extra amounts of crystal and metal. Of course the game also allow you to bunker up your planets with large amounts of diffrant defences, all from large Starports, Mines, turrets, Warp disrupters and a special race super weapon.Now moving on to resurses, there are three resurses that are used in the game, Credits that are generated from your planets and ammount of people you have living on the actuall planets, then you have crystals and metal, these two will require you to construct asteroid mines where ever you might find them, some planets might only contain crystal while others only contain Metal so deciding what planet to colonise is again quite important. The game also futures a bit of rouge covert bits, were you can send pirates ( that said, this is a game optiuon that can be turned off before the start of the game) to harrass the planets of your enemy, these will grow in strenght over time and can be quite hard to take out early in the game because of the ammount of defences around their base. There is also a black market where you can trade crystal and metal for credits and vice verse, this works with supply and demand and some times the market for metal can crash because of the ammount of people trying to sell their large amount of metal for a bit of credits. The factions in the game are just as in the old games TEC, Advent and the Vasari Empire. These are then spilt up into two diffrant factions within the Race, each of them have their special Titan and each also have special powers that the other faction and race can't research. For example the Vasari loyalists can research a special upgrade so that their warp gates ( that allow them to move around to other warp gates constructed around the solar system) can summon the Vasari dark fleet that will assist the defence of their planet. The game is to me a balanced strategy game that in my opinion futures a large amount of content, that said, this game is made for multiplayer as the campaign is non existing. That said this game is at its best when you can gather a group of friends and just battle it out across a large space battlefield. I give it a 10/10 for a very polished and fun strategy game and one of the best space real time strategy games on the market.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 22, 2014
												Can't believe I never wrote a review for this till now. Split into played original/new sections.If you played the original Sins of a Solar Empire, this feels like another addon. Buffed graphics, addition of Corvettes (rapid raiders who will tear up frigates and long range frigates) and Titans (yes, basically what that suggests - will take on several capital ships no problem). Couple of new techs based off your Loyal/Rebel alignment, making for somewhat different play styles, especially involving diplomacy. Ever wanted 2 TEC starbases in the same gravity well without mods? Play TEC Loyalists. Wanna stripmine planets into dead asteroids like a proper Vasari? Loyalists. Care to set fire to entire worlds with righteous Advent hate? Loyalists again. Good for immersion. Would not recommend DLCs unless you're feeling rich. 5 bucks is a bit much to pay for a couple of new planet types and the ability to specialize a planet in commerce or industry. Same applies to the Stellar Phenomena DLC. It adds to the immersion and would recommend if they were like $1 each, but 5's a bit much for so little content. Definetly not on the scale of Entrechment/Diplomacy.New to the series? It's a RTS. Not a micro management game though, in fact the game promotes macro managing - the lower the shields on a ship, the higher the damage mitigation. No mass firepower orders here! Well, capital ships excepted, I prefer to blow those up before letting the AI handle the rest. Typical 4x Space RTS - start with a homeworld, colonize more, build ships, blow up enemies, make friends - and backstab them if you feel like it. Each side is balanced properly with no glaring advantage beyond numbers. That's not to say you can just spam nothing but heavy cruisers; proper fleet composition is key in this game series. Planetary infrastructure is basically just upgrading its capabilities - no GalCiv construction here.Would I recommend it? Sure, it was a good waste of just under 100 hours while I grabbed all the achivements. Be warned that it's basically nothing but skirmish gameplay - no campaign.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2012
												It's...an expansion for Sins. Core gameplay is the same, changes include corvettes, which are smaller than frigates but just as fast (and just as ♥♥♥♥ING annoying) as strike craft), and titans, which are apparently ♥♥♥♥huge ships but in all honesty I haven't built one personally yet because they are really really expensive. The 3 races from the original Sins have been "split" into 6, I say "split" because between the loyalist and rebel factions of each of the original races share much of the same units and research upgrades, however there are some small differences. Speaking of research upgrades, the trees got cleaned up a bit too. All in all, if you like Sins pick up Rebellion, it's the same but with more.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion, is possibly one of the best "expansions" to a game I have ever played. Why do I say "expansion" you might ask, well, the basic point is, SOASE:Rebellion is a full game "expansion". Not an add on pack, you don't need to own the original game, you just need to put $15 on the table and pick up a wonderfully crafted, beautifully balanced product.The basic premise of SOASE is to build a giant army of death bringing spaceships, and ram them as close as you can to other giant armies of death. Repeat steps 1-2 four hundred times and eventually you might get somewhere.PRO TIP: Have a bigger, more expensive, giant death army than the other players. More likely to win that way.It may sound repetitive, and it is, but you won't notice as giant lazer beams of death come out of your giant space ship and kills 4 spaceships at once. This game is brilliant on high powered PC's and even runs on Mac (PC is reccomended though because it looks great at 1080p on ultra)This game is a definite buy for you, and all of your friends.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 13, 2014
												Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion is a fantastic game. One, it's a space game, which earns it several points before even considering other features. Unlike many other games, however, Sins allows you to win in several different ways. You could go with the simple path of exterminating your enemy (Hey, I don't judge), you could sweep them from the star with culture, set the pirates on them, or even become their friend (And maybe, depending on how horrible of a person you are, back stab them-again, I don't judge). Games can last anywhere from half an hour to around ten hours depending on the skill level of the payers and map size of the game. If you don't like a victory option on you can always eliminate it somehow--by locking the teams, turning pirates off, for example.A word of warning, however, I strongly recommend that new players start with TEC. While they don't have any particular advantage over the other species, their ships are most intuitively named. The flak frigate, for example is for eliminating fighters. The Sentinel, however, doesn't give its purpose in the name, making it more difficult for new players to find out what they're doing. On top of that, with advent you have to focus too much on more complex (Not much so, but noticeably) things such as culture. Vasari, in my own opinion, are the hardest to play because they require more tactics. Their fleets tend to be smaller, even if their reaction time with phase stabilizers is increased.Once you play a few games, don't hesitate to play as the other races. They're all fun in their own way.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 22, 2014
												Can't believe I never wrote a review for this till now. Split into played original/new sections.If you played the original Sins of a Solar Empire, this feels like another addon. Buffed graphics, addition of Corvettes (rapid raiders who will tear up frigates and long range frigates) and Titans (yes, basically what that suggests - will take on several capital ships no problem). Couple of new techs based off your Loyal/Rebel alignment, making for somewhat different play styles, especially involving diplomacy. Ever wanted 2 TEC starbases in the same gravity well without mods? Play TEC Loyalists. Wanna stripmine planets into dead asteroids like a proper Vasari? Loyalists. Care to set fire to entire worlds with righteous Advent hate? Loyalists again. Good for immersion. Would not recommend DLCs unless you're feeling rich. 5 bucks is a bit much to pay for a couple of new planet types and the ability to specialize a planet in commerce or industry. Same applies to the Stellar Phenomena DLC. It adds to the immersion and would recommend if they were like $1 each, but 5's a bit much for so little content. Definetly not on the scale of Entrechment/Diplomacy.New to the series? It's a RTS. Not a micro management game though, in fact the game promotes macro managing - the lower the shields on a ship, the higher the damage mitigation. No mass firepower orders here! Well, capital ships excepted, I prefer to blow those up before letting the AI handle the rest. Typical 4x Space RTS - start with a homeworld, colonize more, build ships, blow up enemies, make friends - and backstab them if you feel like it. Each side is balanced properly with no glaring advantage beyond numbers. That's not to say you can just spam nothing but heavy cruisers; proper fleet composition is key in this game series. Planetary infrastructure is basically just upgrading its capabilities - no GalCiv construction here.Would I recommend it? Sure, it was a good waste of just under 100 hours while I grabbed all the achivements. Be warned that it's basically nothing but skirmish gameplay - no campaign.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 4, 2015
												One of the best RTS 4X strategy games out there.This game is about pure survival, you will try to use whatever tool necessary to make sure your empire sees another day.It offers the four mighty Xs, Exploring the darkest corners of the solar systems or entire sectors. Expanding your empire by colonizing all kinds of different planets, asteroids and stations. Gathering basic resources which you need for your empire's growth and most importantly eliminating rival opponents in both single or multiplayer matches.One of the greatest features of this game is actually the option to zoom in onto even the smallest objects in the space. Therefore you can enjoy some really beautiful sights of awesome ship and building models and space battles.You can take control over large amount of ships which you can even asign into custom fleets to ease issuing commands.The game's soundtracks are one of the best I've listened to while playing any kind of strategy games, simply marvelous.Both single player and multiplayer gameplay is really smooth and solid. All the base game races are surprisingly well balanced. Every race has its pros and cons, but they share a kind of a basic setup from where the different specializations start off. What really surprised me about this game is that you can actually host a multiplayer match on a public IP with an access to your router's port-forwarding rather than crating LAN or Official lobbies.There are few things that actually dissapoint me about this game.One of them is the lack of any sort of story based missions or a campaign, which is really a shame, because the littly backstory of this game is really interesting and is surely worth pointing out.The other, but not the last thing is about the not very efficient AI difficulty levels.Using increased income bonuses and faster research as a buff for higher difficulty AI is in my opinion wrong move and it is nearly impossible to defeat highest difficulty AI in a regular match just on your own, without anyone else to balance the enormous pressure on, because the enemy's economy overcomes you in just few minutes into the game.Other great thing worth pointing out is the support for mods. There are plenty of awesome mods out there, which can really spice up the gameplay of the base game or add an entire new experience with something new, using conversions.As of the DLCs, If you find yourself enjoying this game at first, and you kinda get into it I certainly recommend adding both of them into your game as each of them adds some minor things and tweaks that can really improve the overall gameplay experience of every match you play.I've played this game for more than a thousand hours in total off-steam and I enjoy every battle I manage to win or lose decisively or just by a pure luck. SoaSER is love, SoaSER is life.Without anything more to say, I would rate this game by 9/10 for how awesome it is.

												One of most fun, well-balanced and gorgeous looking space strategy games out there. You have absolute control over your empire and your fleet. You can zoom out to view an overlay of the entire solar system, focus on a particular planet or zone, or just zoom right in and watch the epic battles unfold before your eyes. The vast distances between some of your strategic points can really stretch your fleets thin. You need have a keen eye for strategy to win against tougher opponents. The expansions to the game build on the story, battles, diplomacy and strategy even more. I can't recommend it enough for people who love strategy games, space games or just really beautiful games overall.

content:
Posted: July 30, 2014
												Great RTS space game! Variety is better than I expected as each race plays very differently from the others. My favorite thing about this game is the fact that it takes longer than other RTS's to win. Games can take 2-8 hours depending on settings. If you are on a very big map with multiple players or AI then games can even take 20+ hours to finish. PvP multiplayer games however can be as short as 20 minutes or as long as 6 hours. AI games typically take longer to complete depending on your play styleThe AI comes in several difficulties. The higher difficulties give a great challenge that no other RTS AI I have played can match.The game comes with a map builder so you can make any type and size map that you want to suit your needs8/10 Highly recommend! Great AI, great gameplay, great balance, amazing graphics, and challenging multiplayer. For new players It may take a while to learn the controls and what everything does; the tutorials aren't as detailed as they could be so this knocks my score down a notch

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 13, 2014
												Great mix of 4x and RTS. Really love the super smooth zoom in/out function. Large battles feel epic. Good portion of economy gameplay. I mostly play with AI and a friend. AI is good and quite cooperative. You can ask them to attack or defend a planet.There are 3 faction with 2 sub faction inside them, loyalist and rebel. They each play differently, have unique research tree, and ohh I wish there were more factions! Playing this game is really an eye opener for me. Culture system, Pirate, Diplomacy, Jump/Warp Technology, Trade Routes, Capital Ship and Titan that levels up and have QWER skills like MOBA, oh not forgetting Superweapon too!Sad thing is, no matter how good your machine is, game is going to lag eventually when things get crowded. Some says it's due to 32 bit architecture, etc. I'm so looking to play the sequel(I hope they won't make me wait too long)One match with 4-6 players can last 6 hours or more. Thing is, I usually spent those hours with excitement and intensity. Always have something to do, check, optimize, micro, rarely dull moment.Audio:3/5 Some clipping, some low quality sounds, unique but mediocre music.Gameplay:4/5Overwhelming at first, due to depth. No LAN, high latency online match.Graphic:4/5Cool ships, planets, weapon particles.GUI:3/5Not so artistic, but very effective and intuitive.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												This is hands down my favorite RTS.  It features beautiful space battles, excellent music, and scant but intriguing lore.Play as the mighty but desperate Vasari, the vengeance-obsessed Advent, or the commercial and industrial powerhouse of the TEC.  Each faction has distinct strengths and weaknesses.Much of the appeal of the game lies in its emphasis of macromanagement (research choice and fleet deployments) over micromanagements (managing individual units).  Instead of babysitting worker units, your attention is focused on hunting down enemy fleets, capturing new territory, or destroying the recently-constructed enemy superweapon before it rains doom on your planets.This game also has an excellent modding community with many great mods that add tons of new content and keep you busy.The game's main weakness is its utter lack of any sort of campaign; you can only play skirmish mode.  Fortunately, every match feels different because of the varied maps, random events, and differing outcomes.  Also, the enemy AI has an annoying tendency to sometimes give up when defeat is assured, bowing out of the game early instead of putting up a valiant last stand, which can make for an unsatisfying conclusion to hours of conflict.All in all, this is an excellent space RTS well worth its asking price.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 5
												Honestly, one of the better 4x strategy games I've played in years. I've been a fan of this game from the very beginning, bought trinity, and then the newest version when it was released on steam. Each of the 3 factions, now technically 6 with the loyalist and rebel variant of each, play very differently from each other. Luckily, while they're each so unique, the game is still balanced about as well as it could be while pushing players to consider different strategies and playstyles for each faction/map and how to best counter your opponents strengths. Graphics are reasonably good, and the interface is very intuiative when being able to easily zoom out and move in to different gravity wells on the fly. It may be silly, but I love how after a large battle you'll see a ton of debris just littered and floating in space. Commanding and controlling units is pretty simplistic, and much of the micromanaging in activating unit abilities can be automated if you like. Compared to stellaris, another space 4x game, the combat is significantly more interactive. You can combine units into fleets, select targets for individual units, tell units to engage if enemies get within a certain distance or are present in a gravity well (can be useful if you want to keep your fleets behind defensive minefields and turrets), and activate abilities as needed.  With the addition of starbases, and titans (Massive ships that can decimate enemy fleets, sometimes solo when you're leveled up), there are plenty of reasons to take on the challenge that SoaSE presents. I would highly recommend this game, even at full price. New players, start with the TEC. They tend to have the best early game perks, cheaper ships, and the best perks for boosting your economy and income. Try and advent and vasari afterwards. Also, note that in this game, the decision to expand your fleet capacity is IRREVERSIBLE in each game. This adds to the total number of ships you can employ, but permenantly increases your upkeep costs (even if you have zero ships deployed, the % taken off your income still persists). So early on, put off expanding your capacity UNLESS you're playing in a very small map where you're immediately encountering other hostile players.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												Sins has been my first look into a 4X game, it's definitely not going to be my last.The game is a standalone expansion to the original "Sins of a Solar Empire" which previous to Rebellion came in a Trinity pack. The game is highly addictive and takes a lot of time to get into the swing of things but you won't notice, you will be too busy exploring Feros, while defending Gateway and sending an envoy to Lexmada at the same time! The game plays much like a space orientated RTS with a top-down camera as default, you can change the visuals in a fullly flexible camera and the zoom can be looking at a shole solar system or a single planet.The game itself features 3x factions, split into 2x subfactions each. There are a variety of ships & buildings available, several research trees per faction and hours of gameplay just there alone. You can chose to conquer your system with diplomacy as you explore and develop your planets or simply wage war on everyone, choice is yours. The gameplay is quite slow but can be adjusted in realtime.Some of the achievements are time consuming but keep some replayability in the game, the online multiplayer requires an Ironclad Online account but you can organsie a match in the chat room and the players there will usually stick throughout the whole session. There are ~400 active players at any given time.Some drawbacks are the games engine, it isn't optimised well for modern hardware so no matter what you're playing on, if you're waging war in a system with 100+ planets, after some time the game will beging to stutter - if you have low / modest hardware you will see this much sooner. It doesn't have an overall negative impact on the game but should be taken into account. Personally, I wouldn't let it spoil the overall experience that is Sins, this is a game that holds hours of play and while it looks very complicated the tutorials will hold your hand through the basics and from there the game takes no time to get involved with.A secondary gripe is the lack of a single player story, the intro video looks like it is geared for one but it is not present in this game. I'd still recommend it any day.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 5
												Honestly, one of the better 4x strategy games I've played in years. I've been a fan of this game from the very beginning, bought trinity, and then the newest version when it was released on steam. Each of the 3 factions, now technically 6 with the loyalist and rebel variant of each, play very differently from each other. Luckily, while they're each so unique, the game is still balanced about as well as it could be while pushing players to consider different strategies and playstyles for each faction/map and how to best counter your opponents strengths. Graphics are reasonably good, and the interface is very intuiative when being able to easily zoom out and move in to different gravity wells on the fly. It may be silly, but I love how after a large battle you'll see a ton of debris just littered and floating in space. Commanding and controlling units is pretty simplistic, and much of the micromanaging in activating unit abilities can be automated if you like. Compared to stellaris, another space 4x game, the combat is significantly more interactive. You can combine units into fleets, select targets for individual units, tell units to engage if enemies get within a certain distance or are present in a gravity well (can be useful if you want to keep your fleets behind defensive minefields and turrets), and activate abilities as needed.  With the addition of starbases, and titans (Massive ships that can decimate enemy fleets, sometimes solo when you're leveled up), there are plenty of reasons to take on the challenge that SoaSE presents. I would highly recommend this game, even at full price. New players, start with the TEC. They tend to have the best early game perks, cheaper ships, and the best perks for boosting your economy and income. Try and advent and vasari afterwards. Also, note that in this game, the decision to expand your fleet capacity is IRREVERSIBLE in each game. This adds to the total number of ships you can employ, but permenantly increases your upkeep costs (even if you have zero ships deployed, the % taken off your income still persists). So early on, put off expanding your capacity UNLESS you're playing in a very small map where you're immediately encountering other hostile players.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												This is hands down my favorite RTS.  It features beautiful space battles, excellent music, and scant but intriguing lore.Play as the mighty but desperate Vasari, the vengeance-obsessed Advent, or the commercial and industrial powerhouse of the TEC.  Each faction has distinct strengths and weaknesses.Much of the appeal of the game lies in its emphasis of macromanagement (research choice and fleet deployments) over micromanagements (managing individual units).  Instead of babysitting worker units, your attention is focused on hunting down enemy fleets, capturing new territory, or destroying the recently-constructed enemy superweapon before it rains doom on your planets.This game also has an excellent modding community with many great mods that add tons of new content and keep you busy.The game's main weakness is its utter lack of any sort of campaign; you can only play skirmish mode.  Fortunately, every match feels different because of the varied maps, random events, and differing outcomes.  Also, the enemy AI has an annoying tendency to sometimes give up when defeat is assured, bowing out of the game early instead of putting up a valiant last stand, which can make for an unsatisfying conclusion to hours of conflict.All in all, this is an excellent space RTS well worth its asking price.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2016
												Background: Played the original Sins and all the Expansions, back before it was on Steam, Direct from Ironclad Website.Combat Mechanics: 4x Spacesim Lite. Active Time Battle, Fleet Building, Starline locked Galaxy Domination Simulator.  SINS has had a number of improvements and Xpacs added to it over the last 8 years. 6 Major factions now exist.  The TEC are Armor Focused. The Advent are Shield Focused. And the Vasari are middle of the road awkward. Combat takes place in real time using the entire galaxy as the battle field. Ships have roles that they fulfill and Capital ships are customizable.  The Game progresses as Technology is researched. Combat can be very slow and laborious at times when fleet sizes get huge, but often the right counter can end even massive battles quickly.  Socially after all this time: The community is small but we're still alive people.Final thoughts: "We'll make them Understand." - Advent. I've been told by my Advent Brethren that you must buy this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2015
												Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion is perhaps my favourite game out of those that I currently own, there are just so many features  and games will last you several hours. Few games have such a high level of replayability and sheer fun factor but Sins manages it with ease. Each faction is well balanced and unique, the split between Loyalists and Rebels is a nice touch, perhaps there could have been slightly more to seperate the two but it's not a pressing issue and they are unique enough.graphically the game looks impressive, models and textures are of high quality so people who enjoy their shiny games won't be dissapointed. The only particular issue with the game is the engine Ironclad used, it's very old and only uses a single core. Sadly this means no matter how beastly your rig is, during large battles with big fleets the game WILL stutter.If that doesn't put you off then Sins is well worth a buy, plus the game has modding support with a very active modding community that have made some fantastic mods. While you may not personally wants Sins itself (but it is good so do try it out) there are well developed mods including Halo, Mass Effect and Stargate and a Homeworld mod.Just for refference I have an i7-3930k clocked at 3.8ghz and the game still loses massive frames and stutters duing big battles. So do keep in mind the engine limitations...I wouldn't mind a Rebellion Remastered on a better engine Ironclad. Wink, wink, nudge, nudge.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												This game is too good to pass up while it's on sale.I'm going to start with Pros and Cons first:+ The game itself is beautiful. The pictures above show what actual gameplay looks like for the most part, and I found myself ooing and ahhing quite often.+ 3 entire races to choose from, each fundamentally different. Each empire is easy to pick up once you get the hang of the game, but you'll find you prefer one race over the others, depending on your playstyle. In addition, you can pick between "Rebel" and "Loyalist" classes in each race, which have their own perks as well!+ There are many ways to win the game. Choose to conquer your enemies by destroying and taking over their planets, research technology, form peace treaties, etc... + Diplomacy is a fun aspect of the game, and can be quite challenging to manage at times.+ Once you get the hang of the game, it's very fun and engaging.+ You get to build MASSIVE fleets and manage planets at a universal level. It's freakin' awesome.+ You can create and customize your own universe to play on! It's a lot of fun to make your own maps and see how well you do on them. Most of the time you'll play on fair, randomized maps.+ The game has a speed-up function for offline play (up to 8x speed) so you can shorten a 20 hour experience vs 8 tough AI to maybe 5 (just an example).- If you don't have a powerful computer, you may not be able to experience the game to its fullest when manning a massive fleet.- Pretty steep learning curve; you really want to play the tutorials so you have a remote clue as to what to do.- All undiscovered planets have neutral units that try to kill you so it's tough to colonize. You get used to it.- Matches can be really, really long. Also, units take a long time to travel. It's as "realistic" as space games can get, however.The "Gray Area":This may be different preference for some people, but some matches can potentially last for hours on end. Computer matches can be paused and saved, but human vs. human really can't be. Playing vs AI is still very engaging, and with the many levels of difficulty, you won't be missing out much if you choose not to play vs human players. Either way, it's a satisfying game for the casual weekend gamer all the way to the basement dweller.Also, pirates. Pirates can be a b*tch. You can pay them to attack other empires, but you are also at risk of being out-bidden and being attacked as well. They add a really cool element to the game, and you have the option to turn them off. I personally turned them off until I learned the game well, then turned them back on for the fun of it.Final Thoughts/Review:When I first bought the game, I really wasn't sure what I was getting myself into; the pictures on the store page are a very simplified and zoomed in view of the game. In actuality, you are looking at a planet-by-planet point of view 90% of the time. The user interface isn't shown in the pictures, and when the game first starts, you are pretty much thrown into the game without much mercy. Once you play through all the tutorials and get beaten around by an easy AI the first time, you start to pick up the tricks of the game. Then you develop strategies. Then you start winning. Then it gets really fun. Then you starting adding more players. Then you increase the difficulty. Then you do it again.With randomized universes, huge options between each type of empire/victory method, scope of the game, level of challenge, I can't say bad things about this game. Once you invest a bit of time, Sins of a Solar Empire is worth every penny you spend on it.9.5/10. The only reason I don't rate higher is because I don't have time to play it all the time.*re-rated higher after some consideration.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
												This is a game of patience, but oh man, will your patience be rewarded. Matches can concievably be played over the course of a few days, with fleets of apocalyptic proportions being the end result, blasting eachother into oblivion. Battles start small and get very, very big in scale as they go on, and the game even has a sweet cinemetic option that makes it easier to watch the space combat. Just don't do that in a serious fight or you'll find your ships exploding without you around to control them.The factions are slightly reminiscant of Starcraft's, with the defensive humans, offensive genetics-minded evil aliens and fanatical religious psychics. Space battles are fun but the game truly becomes great when you get diplomacy involved and start paying serious attention to economics, the game gives you alot of time to think and it's at it's most fun when that time is spent controlling as many of the intricate pieces in the game as possible. Definitely worth everything, highly reccomended to anyone who likes to take things slow and play mastermind.

content:
Posted: March 31
												My first space-based strategy game. Stardock creates quality games, and SOASE is no exception. I'll admit that this game isn't at the complexity of more recent space civs (like Stellaris, which I reviewd only a few minutes ago, or Galactic Civilizations 3 which is also by Stardock but is a 4k turn-based strategy game,) this game is still thouroughly entertaining, keeping a special place on my computer if not on my mind.Gameplay is streamlined but simple, and definitely can become repetative even when playing nothing but randomized maps. Diplomacy can be a pain and isn't usually worth the bother, and the economy is somewhat difficult to control (you really have no direct controls except those found in the black market.) Combat is quick but exeptionally thrilling, as ship movements are completely under your control throughout a battle and usually requires some level of strategy beyond just "have more ships". The three factions are all uniquely balanced and interesting to play as; personally I focus on the TEC but the Vasari are also a fun faction to play as (admittedly the Advent are somewhat boring.) *Please note that I only possess the New Worlds DLC, so I cannot be certain if the newest "Sectors" dlc changes gameplay in any dramatic way.This editionof the game (specifically Rebellion) is easily the greatest of the SOASE collection, possessing all the qualities and updates of the previous editions with the added bonus of the Titan ship class (my favorite being the TEC Ragnarov, Sniper shot beats EVERYTHING at higher levels.) I have to admit, this game gets me somewhat nostalgic due to my extended experience with it, but I don't believe it clouds my judgement too much. 8/10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 20, 2015
												One of the most epic, large-scale, intense, strategic, balanced RTS games I know of.   You have three factions to choose from, each with two sub-factions a piece.  You have a wide variety of ships to build your fleets from, you have many planets connected by tenuous hyperspace lanes.   You have war.  Lots of it.Diplomacy is a viable option in this RTS, unlike many.  One can win the entire game by turtling and sending out envoys to convert people to their way of thinking, meanwhile opening up extremely valuable technologies that can only be applied to staunch allies.One can also win by culture.  Literally propagandizing the entire galaxy into submission.This game is golden.  My favorite RTS of all-time.  It has flaws, but they're easily overcome by it's great strengths.10/10 Buy this.

Product received for free
												My brother bought this as a gift for me and a group of friends. i find the multi-tiered strategy excellent and the replayability high as well. 2 different factions of each race let you play the same race with a totally different experience. good single player pve, good multiplayer team pve, have not tried all player pvp yet. keeping track of the large maps can be difficult at time [especially when there are 3 different solar systems and 96 planets!] but finding map sizes you like is easy and there are a TON to choose from.i also really like how each type of ship [different skins for each race mind you] is in the same place...colonizing cap ship is ALWAYS the 3rd one...makes it easy to find and build the ships you want. you can go tech, military, diplomacy, or any combo...LOVE IT!...i'm buying xpacs for all my friends to return the favor!for someone that wants REAL minutiae and micromanaging this might not be QUITE detailed enough for you...but it gets close. for those who want 'fire and forget' it supports that too. VERY versatile game.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2013
												This game is an RTS - 4X hybrid (which focuses a lot more onthe RTS aspect), featuring three different races with two factions each (Rebels and Loyalists). Each faction is a bit different from the other, while they share base similarities. This last expansion, which is now also standalone, has all the features (and more) than the previous ones had: Diplomacy and Entrenchment. I do quite like it, I've spent many hours on it and I do suggest you buy it if you like RTS games that are set in space. It's pretty unique on itself because of the rather uncommon lore the game has; there's no story nor any form of campaign, you are given the races and a bunch of maps (quite big bunch in fact) and you just play. I hope that the backstories of each race are expanded upon with any further release/DLC and I hope that some day we see official campaigns, meanwhile we still have the map creator tools.It also is mod compatible, even online. Has pretty grafix and doesn't play too bad, although the framerate will progressively decrease on big maps with lots of AI players and units (sometimes to the point of having a 20fps slideshow, but the slideshow is still pretty!)New units and all that yadda.Overall 8.7/10 Would recommend again.

												Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion is essentially Jesus in RTS game form.You get to choose from six factions, all with differing research trees and a wide variety of ships and a different titan for each.It utilizes a grand scale real time system, you can make huge A$$ fleets and do whatever you want, split them up and send them to different areas, move as a giant mass, go crazy, it allows for a lot of strategic, tactical flexibility.The map system is also pretty incredible, multiple planets and locations of interest all around a sun which can differ each time, and not only that but you can make the map just as huge as well, more than one solar system.It's fun with friends, fun alone, and fun in multiplayer, I'm being serious when I say I can't find any downsides to this game.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												One the best sci-fi RTS games ever made really. This is an unsung classic of the genre IMO. The closest way to describe this is that its Rise of Nations in space. You have a civilization management side to the game via customizable planets and using starbases to shape the political and economic terrain. You also have crazy awesome massive fleets battling it out against each other and against epic planetary defenses.The tactical combat rewards a certain amount of micro-management via the special powers provided by capital ships. The automation and fleet logistics are good enough to where you don't have to be a twitch-master to be effective though. Few games get this balance right.The original SINS game was not the best, I'll be straight. The complete Rebellion pack with all the expansions and DLC is however a very good and fairly different game. So if core SINS has a bad rap, you need to really look at the total package not just vanilla.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												Absolutely love this game! The graphics excellent, the AI can be very tough to fight on Hard difficulty alone (let alone the "Very hard" and "Unfair" diffulties!) and the variety in ships between the factions and their research and powers provides a continuous feel.My main positive with this game though, is how mod-able it is! "Sins of a galactic Empire" (Star Wars full conversion), "Sins of the Prophets" (Halo full conversion), "Star Trek Armada" (Star Trek full conversion), "Dawn of the Reapers" (Mass Effect full conversion), are just a few of the mods you can find that are just mind blowing and yet keep the same Sins feel to them!PROS:+ Excellent gameplay+ Excellent scenery + Great effects during conflicts+ Huge numbers of ships can be recruited, giving potential to massive conflicts at a time+ Love the music and sounds+ Very mod-able, opening up a variety of other gameplays+ Multiplayer+ Large numbers of maps available to play with various sizes and star systemsCONS:- Can be difficult to get used to some of the features and the pace of the game if your new to it. Give it some time and perhaps start on a small map to work out the controls and your style of play before taking on the larger maps and harder AI's (trust me, you'll get obliterated otherwise haha)- [This is more of a personal con] - Wish there could be a bit more detail in wreckage. One thing I seem to keep missing when playing sci-fi RTS games like this is that when a ship is destroyed it explodes and then nothing is left behind. In this game there is only a small amount of wreckage left. If you have a big enough battle it's not such an issue, but more wreckage would add another level of greatness to conflict. However there are some mods and full conversions (such as Star Trek Armada) that address this.OVERALL: Fantastic game that is a perfect addition to the RTS genre. If you're looking to expand your RTS collection or just add more games to your library list, this game is certainly worth the buy!

content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												So first and foremost, I love this game, i've enjoyed it alone and even more so with friends. For those who can't be bothered reading anything lengthy, if you are looking for a fast paced strategy game you're very much in the wrong place, go play starcraft, or, well I guess thats it (Dear god we need better RTS titles)  Rebellion takes the slow, methodical strategy of its predecessor and adds on largely to the end game but there are some new toys almost every aspect of the game. If you liked sins of a solar empire I cannot fathom any reason you wouldn't like rebellion. Havnt played either? Sins is a space based 4x Real Time Strategy game focusing quite largely on fleet composition and production with empire management taking a bit of a back seat. Don't expect civilisation depth but thats not to say its a simple game. Rebellion in my opinion is a good game to go for as a first step into the sins series or for experienced players. The scale of the combat alone can be awesome in the literal sense of the word and the new titan class ships can make for some very interesting boss battle style engagements. The new factions (well, old factions split in to two groups) can really give players a good sense of direction and palystyle which really does run on to the rediculous once you hit the end game research.   The corvettes while were a nice addition are not overly game changing like much of the other additions much to my own dissapointment and this version still suffers from one drawback it shares with the original trilogy. The combat can look a little stupid at times. While its really cool to see the larger ships turn to fire broadsides at eachother, the smaller ships tend to just sit there like stationary platforms. The smallest ships are a little silly looking as they have a tendancy to literaly fly into their target and fire in a random direction, poorly representing any sense of speed and manuverability or even looking remotely sensible.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2014
												This game.... This game is probably the best Space based game I've ever played. Sin's of a Solar Empire started off as a revolutionary Space combat system, with hundreds of planets, dozens of ships and unlimited possibilities. Rebellion is the next step, and Stardock did not dissapoint me at all. This game is as close to perfection as you can get. Amazing graphics, gripping storyline, and explosive combat. In this game, you take command of one of six Factions, and command an entire empire throughout war and peace. You can choose from one of six factions, of three Races.The Trader Emergency Coalition is the human empire. They were formed after an alien assault, and have been fighting a losing battle ever since. The Loyalists want to find a diplomatic way to end the war, preferably saving as many lives as possible along the way. The Rebels on the other hand, are only interested in Human domination, and will do anything to destroy the enemies of humanity. The Advent are a long lost sect of Humanity. They strive to seek peace and enlightenment, and the only way they see they can succeed is by either indoctrinating everyone else, or destroying those who appose the Unity. The loyalists are trying to remain peacefull, spreading their religion as far as they can, taking over worlds through persuasion, and not violence. The Rebels are violently assaulting other worlds, using massive weapons of mass destruction and mind control to overthrow planetary governments. The Vasari are an ancient race, born in the beginnings of the galaxy. They are all that remain of a galaxy spanning empire, and are fleeing from a dangerous species, known only as the unknown. They are incredibly powerful, and will do anything they can to keep their species alive, through intimidation, or slavery. Loyalists of the Vasari commune want to enslave or destroy the other races they have encountered, while the Rebels want to work together to survive, and the gods know that to survive something that can destroy an entire empire, who knows what will have to be done.....20/20 Score10/10 for Graphics and Visuals10/10 for Storyline and Gameplay

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 6, 2014
												Although Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion lacks a campaign that so many gamers love and look for, it more than makes up for this by atmosphere, scale, and depth. Sins of a Solar Empire is one of those games balanced in such a way that there's no clear balance. That doesn't mean it's bad, it just means that each race (the Vasari, the TEC, and the Advent) have different playing styles. In contrast to games such as StarCraft, where everone knows the three races have their own triangle of defeat (Zerg beats Protoss, Protoss beats Terran, and Terran beats Zerg), Sins of a Solar Empire is all about your strategy. Will you expand your space outwards, take planets and conquer the enemy, or will you lie in wait until the time is right? The scale of the game is truely marvelous, but often goes overlooked. The zoom function is really helpful, as it shows that even the tiniest of battles are absurdly dramatic: If you're zoomed out enough, you see two little ship icons, and perhaps some fire in between them, Zoom in more and you see stunning 3D models, complete with thrusters, blinking lights, etc, and you can see exactly what they're firing. Zoom in until one fills your screen and suddenly you notice that it's on fire, sparks are flying, and the enemy's fire is devastating the hull with massive explosions.If you love strategy games, space games, or just want to watch ships burn, you'll probably like this game.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												THE best 4XRTS game I have ever owned. It does take some getting used to at first, but once you get the hang of it, it becomes very addicting.                 Graphics and gameplay greatly balanced. No extra effects that do not add to the gameplay. If you have a beefy rig, or a standard laptop, the settings are highly configurable to suite your needs. You can zoom right in and see your ships shoot lasers and rockets at the enemy, watch your fleet jump into an intense 3D fire-fight, and zoom in on a building that you just destroyed to watch it explode.                You will always be researching armor, weapon, mining, colonization, and diplomatic sciences to improve your empire. Build a variety of ships, defensive structures, and planetary upgrades to improve you empire's spread rate and combat effectiveness.                Overall I would rate this game 9/10. Love the game, but matches can take hours, and not everyone has that time. But what do you expect? It's a strategy game, they all take a long time.

												Although Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion lacks a campaign that so many gamers love and look for, it more than makes up for this by atmosphere, scale, and depth. Sins of a Solar Empire is one of those games balanced in such a way that there's no clear balance. That doesn't mean it's bad, it just means that each race (the Vasari, the TEC, and the Advent) have different playing styles. In contrast to games such as StarCraft, where everone knows the three races have their own triangle of defeat (Zerg beats Protoss, Protoss beats Terran, and Terran beats Zerg), Sins of a Solar Empire is all about your strategy. Will you expand your space outwards, take planets and conquer the enemy, or will you lie in wait until the time is right? The scale of the game is truely marvelous, but often goes overlooked. The zoom function is really helpful, as it shows that even the tiniest of battles are absurdly dramatic: If you're zoomed out enough, you see two little ship icons, and perhaps some fire in between them, Zoom in more and you see stunning 3D models, complete with thrusters, blinking lights, etc, and you can see exactly what they're firing. Zoom in until one fills your screen and suddenly you notice that it's on fire, sparks are flying, and the enemy's fire is devastating the hull with massive explosions.If you love strategy games, space games, or just want to watch ships burn, you'll probably like this game.
