number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9, 2014
												Hey all, Deadpool here with a review. Now that the obvious is out of the way, let's get to it shall we? Here be the review for Sins of a Solar Empire; Rebellion, a 4X RTS game set in space. Oooooooooo.PlotThere isn't one. At least not that I can infer. I think. Let me start from the beginning. Rebellion is the first Sins game I have played. As with sequels, you'd usually get a recap, yes? Crysis 3 has a rather long one, the Assassin's Creed games(save for the first) have recaps, and the list goes on. Sins of a Solar Empire; Rebellion does not have one. So me being new to the series, I have absolutely no clue what is going on. The intro video, while stunning and well done, offered little to no info. All I know(and still know because I am too lazy to Google) is that there are humans, some very spiritual alien peeps, and some nano-tech alien things that are running from something. Each race has been split into Loyalists and Rebels. So you have, vaguely, six to choose from.The Good StuffThe game is pretty well balanced. The developers seem to have a keen eye for balance between the various ship classes and races that produce the ships. I tried spamming with smaller frigates, but was easily defeated. A balanced fleet is a good one, and the Devs seem to have hit the nail on the head when it came to making sure of it. The Same can be said for the balance between the factions themselves.Graphics. Wow. The explosions seem legit, and make the camera shake if you zoom in. Which, I love. The level of detail in the game is astounding. Then again, it being a space based game, you'd really hope so. Truly well thought out and beautiful artwork. Same can be said for the sound. Very, very well done and aesthetically pleasing.Complex, but simple. It is complex enough to thoroughly enjoy and really make you think about your next move, yet simple enough to where there is a minimal learning curve; especially for someone like me who has never played a Sins game before. Little to no micromanaging of your planets and/or colonies, which allows you to truly focus on your fleet, defense, economy, and of course diplomacy.Now, for diplomacy. The devs offered up something I haven't seen in diplomacy before I played this game. It is complex with your actions affecting not only the intended faction, but rippling through to the other factions in the game. And likewise with their actions. Not only that, but to create alliances and forge pacts, not only do they have to like you, but your people have to like them. I, for one, absolutely love this. It prevents you from going all out and forging alliances just to win an allied victory and truly brings into perspective just how closely and how far the devs went to instill a balance into the game.Voice acting. It is phenomenal. 'Nuff said. Some of the best I have seen. Or heard, rather.Diversity. The diversity between the three races, and even their Loyalist and Rebel sub-factions, is outstanding. The research options differ greatly between the three races. The technologies are different, the voices are different, everything is different! Mostly. Each time you play as a different race, it feels and plays completely different from the last.The Bad StuffCampaign. There isn't one. The only mode, aside from multiplayer online, is relative to skirmish mode on Command and Conquer games. That's it. No campaign to play through, nothing. Nothing but a repetitive procession of skirmish after skirmish. Set up, conquer, win. Set up, conquer, win. As amazing as the game looks, it gets old. Unless you're like me and use Galaxy Forge(Comes with the game, program you can use to create your own maps) to play very sadistic games with the AI.Speaking of AI, it is very finicky. If you have great defenses, they don't attack. Even when you set them on the hardest difficulty, they wont attack. The only good thing about the AI is the diplomacy, and watching them fight between themselves. I once sat for two hours watching five AI's battle it out over 2 different star systems. There was a tug of war, take and lose. The AI's fight each other real well, but if you're too powerful they leave you alone like you have the plague. If you maintain a decent level of awesomeness, they will attack you. They will take what you have and own you. So it is somewhat of a balancing act. Depends on how you want to play it.Micro Management. I put this in the Bad Stuff section as well because if you're like me and love micro managing, then this game will disappoint. Yeah sure you build things in orbit to advance your culture and spread it, but so what? I want to be able to see who the leaders are, select the political whatevermajiggs, change the funding from research to defense if I wanted, and truly see what my people(ingame people, you know, in my empire) are made of. But no. You get a planet, some aircraft whizzing around it, and city lights if you're on the nighttime side of it. That's it. To me, once you learn the game and how to play it, there is sooooo much room for micromanagement. But, I can see why the Devs didn't do it. It is an RTS game, and sometimes not enough time for micromanagement.ConclusionNow that I touched on just a few of the high and low points of the game, here is my condensed review of my review of the game. To be frank, the game is amazing. Excellent mechanics, balance, diplomacy, voice acting, visuals, diversity, and a true pleasure to play. Tutorials are available if you have questions, but in the end you will still be discovering little things here and there that you can do months after the fact. Lack of a campaign makes the endless C&C and Starcraft-like map skirmishes repetitive and give it a lack of long-term playability(Invented that word just for this review). In this game, I feel, the Pros outweigh the Cons and thus I give it a 7 out of 10.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												Absolutely love this game! The graphics excellent, the AI can be very tough to fight on Hard difficulty alone (let alone the "Very hard" and "Unfair" diffulties!) and the variety in ships between the factions and their research and powers provides a continuous feel.My main positive with this game though, is how mod-able it is! "Sins of a galactic Empire" (Star Wars full conversion), "Sins of the Prophets" (Halo full conversion), "Star Trek Armada" (Star Trek full conversion), "Dawn of the Reapers" (Mass Effect full conversion), are just a few of the mods you can find that are just mind blowing and yet keep the same Sins feel to them!PROS:+ Excellent gameplay+ Excellent scenery + Great effects during conflicts+ Huge numbers of ships can be recruited, giving potential to massive conflicts at a time+ Love the music and sounds+ Very mod-able, opening up a variety of other gameplays+ Multiplayer+ Large numbers of maps available to play with various sizes and star systemsCONS:- Can be difficult to get used to some of the features and the pace of the game if your new to it. Give it some time and perhaps start on a small map to work out the controls and your style of play before taking on the larger maps and harder AI's (trust me, you'll get obliterated otherwise haha)- [This is more of a personal con] - Wish there could be a bit more detail in wreckage. One thing I seem to keep missing when playing sci-fi RTS games like this is that when a ship is destroyed it explodes and then nothing is left behind. In this game there is only a small amount of wreckage left. If you have a big enough battle it's not such an issue, but more wreckage would add another level of greatness to conflict. However there are some mods and full conversions (such as Star Trek Armada) that address this.OVERALL: Fantastic game that is a perfect addition to the RTS genre. If you're looking to expand your RTS collection or just add more games to your library list, this game is certainly worth the buy!

Posted: May 20, 2014
												This game is one of the best by far RTS Space-Set games, The fact that it is pure RTS is wonderful, The combat system is iffy and could look more space-battle like instead of two ships looking at each other but that is pretty much the only flaw, the research shows you ahead of time what you can get and explains the advantages of getting that upgrade, the game itself was confusing at first for me but i literially played the very first version where you got ships, a planet, and that was it, no mines, no space stations, no titans, no corvettes etc. etc. This game does feature tutorials so do not be down, and a tip: The very first game you play on here should not be a multiplayer game! There are literal people who this game is their bread and butter for favorite games and are skilled at it and can bulldoze you and your fleet like a literal bulldozer going over a stick, try AI easy at first then work your way up to about hard then try multiplayer. Good luck and this is one of the best games of its kind on the market.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												A slow-paced RTS on a level on it's own, Sins of a Solar Empire give the player the opportunity to control their own space fleet to control the galaxy. Unlike most other RTS games, Sins allows strategic, tactical, micro and macro management by being able to see the full view of the star systems, and to zooming all the way down on individual ships to optimize the use of each ship to it's strengths.Small maps can be done relatively quickly, often within half an hour, but don't allow progression down the tech trees, while a large map could have hundreds of planets, allowing every tech tree to be explored fully, resulting in games that can go over 10 hours.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												Sins of the Solar Empire Rebellion is a combination of the classic RTS genre with the 4x games. The main focus of the game is absolutly the real time battle between the six factions. The colonisation and construction part of the game is very limited (got slightly expanded with the DLC) but fits perfect in the gameplay. The battles could reach epic sizes (on large galaxies) where hundrets of  ships fight for one planet. Titans and Corvettes, which was both introduced with Rebellion, changed the way to play extremly if you compare it with the predecessor.All three main factions plays different and focus on other ways to overcome there enemies. The grafic is absolutly impressive for a 4x game. Music and Sound are also up to date and give you the right "space feeling" while playing. The AI is a very hard opponent in higher difficulties, so the game keeps challenging.The Multiplayer is active and you can always find someone to play against the AI or each other. A single game could take 1 - 6 hours, depending on the size of your galaxy. There are also a lot of mods that change or improve the gameplay, so anyone will find something for his taste.A last hint, if I only could take one game with me to a lonely island, it would be Sins - Rebellion

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2014
												This game has been adding new game objectives, research, ships, orbital structures and planet types for a number of years now and it has turned it into a really great game. Each of the races and now factions within the races (Loyalist/Rebellion) offer higher defensive, offensive, economic or boosts to your culture (culture will overthrow enemy planets non violently) which gives a varying amount of replayability and playstyles. The learning curve for playing this game is low to mid, it doesn't take long to learn how to play.In this game you'll be able to build up a massive fleet armada or split your fleet in two or three and raid the enemy's core planets after destroying their fleet. You'll be able to build starbases that can halt the advance of armadas until they are dealt with that also protect your trade empire from pirate raiders, jumping away from a starbase before it is destroyed seriously damages ships automatically.This recent expansion breaks each of the three races into a loyalist and rebel faction. Each group has unique researchable abilities that offer different playstyles (defensive, offensive, culture) and each loyalist and rebel race receives a different Titan ship, a juggernaught of a ship that is 10 times larger than any capitol ship. These Titans can easily throw a pitched battle by special abilities that will either do area effect or very high single target damage, while others are disablement oriented, reducing the damage your fleet takes and reducing the firing rate of the enemy.General overview of races:TEC (Trade Emergency Coalition) - An economic powerhouse compared to the other races with quicker access to trade ports and higher research done that gives you extra credits anytime another faction buys something. The ships they field are considerably weaker though at end game research, as they have less fleet support abilities unless you have they loyalist capitol ship in the fleet to help reduce incoming damage. Their ships have high armor and their ultimate weapon is the Novalith Cannon, a weapon that sits in a planet's gravity well and regularly fires shots at enemy planets destroying all life on them and making them temporarily uncolonizable.Advent - This race, in my opinion, fields the best armadas in the game. Their capitol ships and cruisers offer a lot of support abilities to spread damage to each ship, redirect damage from their own ships back to the enemy, area effect shield recharge all the while fielding a massive amount of fighters and bombers making the need for direct engagement with an enemy fleet purely optional. The flip side to this is they have a really weak economy and the worst ultimate weapon compared to the TEC or Vasari. Their ships have very high shields and their ultimate weapon shoots at enemy planets your planet's culture which is easily countered.Vasari - A brutal alien race that terrorizes the galaxy thru subjegating and enslaving other races. They get a later start with building up their economy but their economy is pretty great at end game. Their units have a variety of disablement oriented abilities and a area effect hull repair and they tend to have higher hull values than the other races. Further research into missile technology allows you to bypass shields making them excellent against advent in a stand up fight. Their ultimate weapon is the Kostura cannon that will shoot at enemy planets damaging and disabling enemy structures in that planet's gravity well. If an enemy fleet is there, the fleet will be temporarily disabled and be unable to move or attack making it an invaluable tool to use while attacking with your fleet.If you are a RTS fan or just enjoy viewing space warfare, I'd definetely recommend this game.

												This game has been adding new game objectives, research, ships, orbital structures and planet types for a number of years now and it has turned it into a really great game. Each of the races and now factions within the races (Loyalist/Rebellion) offer higher defensive, offensive, economic or boosts to your culture (culture will overthrow enemy planets non violently) which gives a varying amount of replayability and playstyles. The learning curve for playing this game is low to mid, it doesn't take long to learn how to play.In this game you'll be able to build up a massive fleet armada or split your fleet in two or three and raid the enemy's core planets after destroying their fleet. You'll be able to build starbases that can halt the advance of armadas until they are dealt with that also protect your trade empire from pirate raiders, jumping away from a starbase before it is destroyed seriously damages ships automatically.This recent expansion breaks each of the three races into a loyalist and rebel faction. Each group has unique researchable abilities that offer different playstyles (defensive, offensive, culture) and each loyalist and rebel race receives a different Titan ship, a juggernaught of a ship that is 10 times larger than any capitol ship. These Titans can easily throw a pitched battle by special abilities that will either do area effect or very high single target damage, while others are disablement oriented, reducing the damage your fleet takes and reducing the firing rate of the enemy.General overview of races:TEC (Trade Emergency Coalition) - An economic powerhouse compared to the other races with quicker access to trade ports and higher research done that gives you extra credits anytime another faction buys something. The ships they field are considerably weaker though at end game research, as they have less fleet support abilities unless you have they loyalist capitol ship in the fleet to help reduce incoming damage. Their ships have high armor and their ultimate weapon is the Novalith Cannon, a weapon that sits in a planet's gravity well and regularly fires shots at enemy planets destroying all life on them and making them temporarily uncolonizable.Advent - This race, in my opinion, fields the best armadas in the game. Their capitol ships and cruisers offer a lot of support abilities to spread damage to each ship, redirect damage from their own ships back to the enemy, area effect shield recharge all the while fielding a massive amount of fighters and bombers making the need for direct engagement with an enemy fleet purely optional. The flip side to this is they have a really weak economy and the worst ultimate weapon compared to the TEC or Vasari. Their ships have very high shields and their ultimate weapon shoots at enemy planets your planet's culture which is easily countered.Vasari - A brutal alien race that terrorizes the galaxy thru subjegating and enslaving other races. They get a later start with building up their economy but their economy is pretty great at end game. Their units have a variety of disablement oriented abilities and a area effect hull repair and they tend to have higher hull values than the other races. Further research into missile technology allows you to bypass shields making them excellent against advent in a stand up fight. Their ultimate weapon is the Kostura cannon that will shoot at enemy planets damaging and disabling enemy structures in that planet's gravity well. If an enemy fleet is there, the fleet will be temporarily disabled and be unable to move or attack making it an invaluable tool to use while attacking with your fleet.If you are a RTS fan or just enjoy viewing space warfare, I'd definetely recommend this game.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												Alrighty, as a hardcore enthusiast of RTS and similar strategy games, this worked it's way into my top 3. The online scene is a little dead, but that doesnt take away from the fact that this is a fantastic game.There are 3 things that set this apart from most other RTS's I have played:1) The diplomacy is challenging as you have to build a relationship with a faction. Unlike other games with diplomacy mechanics, you really have to work at it.2) The resources are scarce. It's not like Starcraft where you can just start mass-producing probes/drones/scvs to boost your economy intake. You need to manage resources and take advantage of the refining boosts you get through research.3) The research tree. This is probably one of the most standard mechanic of any good RTS, and because of that I have seen some terrible tech trees. This game however has a balanced tech tree that allows for a little variability in expanding and is grouped into nice little sections for easier maintenance. I like this a LOT.Aside from these three things, the game is also visually appealing, with an interesting (if a bit cliche) backstory and lots of available strategies for play. The only true downsides are the somewhat annoying and repetitive unit voices, the rather repetitive soundtrack, and the steep, steep learning curve.In any case, I give this a 9/10. Excellent game to pick up if you dont mind spending an hour or 2 per match.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2014
												Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion is the latest iteration of Sins of a Solar Empire, a space themed real time strategy game with a truly fantastic scale. I’ve seen battles with hundreds of ship engaging each other as more reinforcements filter in from distant star systems. Even friendly comp stomp games can last for hours as your forces slowly conquer the cosmos. Whether this is epic or tedious is a matter of taste, but I fall into the epic camp.Sins plays a little like a 4X game. You’ll explore the universe, colonize and develop planets, research all manner of military and civilian technologies, meet other peoples, and kill them.  Throughout you’ll be struggling with issues like whether asteroid colony Y would benefit more from a refinery, trade port, or capital ship factory. You are Space Stalin, staying up late in your space Kremlin while devising plans to ensure your people are mining enough crystals to build the ships you’ve just researched. This isn’t a game where you’ll dance a little hero unit around the map. Yes, you can do a little micromanagement. However, you’ve got a lot on your plate already. It’s best to just let the Battleship Captain decide when he wants to fire his special Gauss Rail Gun.If you want to play an RTS during a lunch break then this is definitely not for you. It’s possible that you could order units to help save an ally’s distant home world, step away from the computer, go out and grab some lunch, eat said lunch, and return before the battle finished. That kind of scale and speed will be a turn off for many people. However, I highly recommend Sins of a Solar Empire Rebellion to patient people with an inner Ming the Merciless.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2015
												One of the best 4X space strategy games I've ever played, proven by my 250+ hrs of gameplay.  The game offers excellent balance, interesting factions that, while similar in organization, offer enough degrees of difference to allow for a variety of strategies in gameplay.  The software itself is solid, but one of the features that makes SoaSE so sustanable is the developer and distributor supporting, wholeheartedly, the modding community.  Just when you thought you were growing weary of the Vasari's dark fleets, or the TEC's economic supremacy, you can download any of several well-developed mods to suit your favorite sci-fi franchise.  The utter collapse of Kerberos' Sword of the Stars II left a void in the 4x genre that Sins has continued to fill with ease.  What the game lacks in the finer points of empire building, it more than makes up for with good macro-economic management tools.  But the brilliant tactical and strategic engine is what makes Sins the standard in current space-based strategy games.  If you were a fan of the Galactic Civ franchise, Masters of Orion, or Sword of the Stars (the original), this game is a need-to-have part of your collection.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 15, 2013
												If you are looking for an epic space combat simulator then look no further, Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion delivers a fantastic experience with a few hicups but, they can easily be ignored. For the most part this game looks great, especially when there are hundreds of ships duking it out for a vital planet. On the other hand, some ship models look to have some basic textures and some planets do look a bit dated. These problems however, arn't big enough to pull you out of the massive battle experience; when there is a massive hundred ship battle it brings a manly tear to your eye. Enough about the graphics lets move onto what the game has to offer, for £30 the amount of content here is excellent if you haven't played the previous games (which I haven't) however; after watching many gameplay videos of the previous games I would wait until a sale to pick this one up as I have seen some repititve gameplay. The amount of hours that I have sunk into this game is ridiculous, the gameplay is complex and indepth, this is a very good strength for me because alot of game developers nowadays try to dumb down their games to make it more casual, this is a refreshing change of much needed complexity in games. Complexity is also a problem with this game, it can take a while to learn with a steep learning curve; I would highly recommend new players to start with offline matches and tutorials before diving into the multiplayer which is fantastic by the way, apart from the fact that games can take a long time to finish I am talking litural hours, make sure you arn't going to school or work that day or you may have to cut the game short. One final note is the fact that the depth and scale of this game is amazing (coming from a Total War player). Another problem with this game is the fact that there is no single player campaign there is however, a nice backstory intro scene at the start of the game which I catch myself strangely watching over and over again. If you're looking for a complex, well executed game with good multiplayer buy this one it is worth it. If you're a more casual player looking for quick online games then you might want to miss this one.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												A good grand RTS game of scale comparable to Supreme Commander but in space.You can fight on 'maps' that are anywhere from a single star surrounded by only a few planets to a few stars with upwards of a hundred varied planets, from dwarf planets and giant asteroids to molten and ice covered planets. There are three factions, both with a loyalist and a rebel side to choose from that mostly comes to a choice of offense vs. defense. And it even has mod support with no shortage of mods to choose from be it Star Trek, Star Wars, or even the Stargate SG1 series among other mods that add whole new factions not pulled from other scifi.Taking planets could be more interesting, given that you can only bombard them into oblivion or overwhelm a planet with your culture to break it's loyalty down. Combat itself isn't too involved either, most any abilities are auto-cast and there's nothing dynamic about the damage system. It can become a bit boring after a while because of that but this is a grand strategy so what's to expect.There is zero reason to pick up the previous games because every single release, including this game, since the original's release has been a DLC pack.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2014
												Sins was a game that honestly had me relatively surprised in a number of aspects. Here's my thoughts:Graphics: 7/10; For a game made more than a couple years ago, it manages to push a rather impressive resolution, detail and ambience. Everything from massive capitol ships and Titans, to small units such as fighter squadrons are well textured, clearly defined and able to give a good visual experience that's both impressive, and incredibly well optimised. So well in fact even older PC's can handle the game on higher graphics levels. Sadly in large scale games with multiple players the game does tend to putz around a bit with the number of items and commands being issued but thats simply a common feature among RTS games.Gameplay: 8/10; RTS at its finest, with a bit of micro-RPG elements attatched to each ship, the game is fun to play, flows well, and encourages good strategy as well as economy management. The controls are a bit much to take in all at once, and it like many other games involving a 4 tier RTS, requires a bit of a learning curve. However, once understood the game is able to flow well, it rewards tactics and an understanding of your opponent, and a satisfying feeling of accomplishment.Sound: 5/10; Its an older game, but the sound effects hold up, and are fairly solid. Listening in on battles is an enjoyable experience and the sound levels are accurate. However some of the more notable abilities used by the Titan units seem unnessecarrily loud, and if listening with headphones can be somewhat deafening if zoomed in close to observe the battle.Addictiveness and Depth: 4/10; The game suffers from one major flaw. Its absolute lack of a single player campaign. The game has all the makings of what could be a very entertaining single player space domination game, however it is restricted to arena style RTS combat over a set number of worlds against 1 - 7 opponents. The game does have an interactive level up system for Capitol ships, which are allowed to level in a manner you can guide them in by increasing their abilities, and the games heavy amount of depth via a diplomacy system, a working active and live economy, as well as player issued missions, falls by the wayside when faced with the knowledge that the entire games structure is simply a Starship based battle arena.Overall: 6/10; The games very fun if you can settle into its niche setting. Enjoying well detailed space battles happening in real time is difficult to manage especially with the graphical quality this game manages to provide. However the lack of a single player campaign hits this game hard, and pushes it onto a back burner if you're looking to pick it up. Best to get if you know a friend that plays it as well, or if you enjoy the competition of facing down another player in a 3 Tier RTS game. Only reason this game isnt being reccomended is its heavy reliance on other players for any sort of content.

												over all a solid game from a mechanical point of view. the only mechanical draw back "if you want to call it a drawback" is while each faction does have a personality the basic mechanics beyond a few key points are identical to the other factions, the basic ship, the siege ship, the carrier ship etc etc all work the same way. compare to say other rts games like starcraft each faction and their units are unique in how they approach a function or role in combat. in Sins you have the same core mechanics and approach to roles uniform across the board. This makes the game easier to transition from faction to faction with only a general style change with a few key talents to take into account however it does reduce replay appeal.the game does have a cool lore but lacks a single player story driven campaign which to some will be a drawback.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												One of the greatest 4X RTS games of all time. If you like space, spaceships, epic space battles, and empire management, then this game is for you. I played the original before it was on Steam (have the retail box here) and Rebellion basically combines the basic game with all released expansions; the end result is an amazing game extended with more awesomeness.+ The graphics are beautiful, you can freely zoom from a scale showing the entire solar system down to a single ship, the detail is amazing and space and especially the battles look incredible+ The expansion packs have added a lot, giving more defensive options, more offensive options, and more diplomatic options+ You can make custom maps and many maps have random elements for which planets or anomalies appear where, making for great replay value+ Full mod support+ The scale of this game is amazing+ The interface holds up really well and makes managing large empires easy- The game can be very performance demanding, especially as games drag on and everyone fields fleets of hundreds of ships, paired with hundreds of trade ships- you get the idea- Even though diplomatic options have been expanded, it's still more action focused in general- The three (six) factions all play fairly similar, they are about as different as Nod and GDI in C&C- No campaign, this game is focused on skirmish matches both in Single- and Multiplayer

content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												Your basic so-so space related tactical sim game. I bought a half dozen of similar games from Steam on sale, and while each has their good and bad points, all play basically the same with little variance and limited tactical ability. Get it on sale, not even close to being worth the full price. Good points. Space battles aren't the quick turn based fights that many such simulators have. The battles in Rebellion actually take a while, you don't need to micromanage them.. just send your ships to enemy area, and your off, they can fight their own fights. Lets you work on your planets, research, etc while your fleet is off doing stuff. Also pirates. Most maps have a pirate homeworld that constantly spawns harder than normal pirate fleets to harass you and the npcs/other players playing the map. Sadly this is easily handled by just giving money in bounty thus letting the pirates attack someone else. Bad points. Game is pretty easy once you figure out a few basic things. Fleet battles will determine map winner, you won't win on diplomacy, or other tactics. Biggest best fleet wins. Pirates are a pain until you quickly figure out how to post bounty switching them to other players.. easy enough. System defenses? kinda useless since fleets can just fly past your defenses unless they are specificially attacking that planet. They can just fly past your fleet until they get to the system they are targetting, so managing your fleet well = win.  Other than that, you simply do what all other space sim type games do. upgrade your planets, do research, build ships to fight other systems. But it isn't super hard, kind of boring after a while once you learn the few basic things to do (expand fast, build up fleet fast, focus more on trade/research than system defenses).Plus there isn't any campaign. Just pick a map and play. Again, boring after you figure out how easy it is to beat opponents with a big fleet. Of all the space games, i'd say the best thing about this one is the real time fleet fighting, much better system than many of the few turn-based fighting that occurs with other games.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2016
												Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion is a comprehensive science fiction fleet simulation. You take the role of the miltary commander (or everything commander honestly) and you make ships that you can send to blow up other ships (or you could send ships to be diplomatic but that's boring). It's your duty to mke sure that your faction beats all the other factions in bloody space RTS warfare (pew pew).Pros:- lots of ship variety- highly customizable scenarios- factions don't lock you into a specific playstyle- lore is cool I guess- pew pew laser fights that look really cool- lots of graphics options- UI is pretty good- some cool mods out there (not on Steam)- each faction has a superweapon- a SUPERWEAPONCons:- voice lines can get a little repetitive- unforgiving on some difficulties- game can end up having a LOT of ships at once on screen (be prepared for lag)- resource management can get tedious- the explosions for smaller ships kinda suck- diplomacy system kinda sucks- mods can come from some pretty sketchy looking sites (be careful)Overall, it's a good RTS if you like shooting first and asking questions later.

												Lots of boat ships with pew pews and sometimes people win by saying, "Hey let's be friends!" but there's lots of planets for you to name weird things and ships with rather gross sounding names as well. If you want to pew pew more you can research it in the big guns panel. It takes place in a space with christmas lights in the middle and when you tell your boats to move the paddlers get lazy and it takes a while to get to the fight. The game features yar har fiddle dee dees as well that you can pay with honeycombs to go and be jerks to your enemies while you make more breadboxes and boat ships. The game has 3 different types of man peoples they are all different but kinda the same. Some like the fight, and some like to drink wine, and one does a bit of both. This is a good game to bring to your friends so you can play this for 8 hours instead of cards against humans. In the new expansion pecks there are huge boat ships that don't sink like the titanic, they are really strong and pew pew more than normal boats, each type of peoples get 2 to choose from. If your christmas ordaments get under attack by the boats you can buy these duplo blocks with guns to defense but they can cost you a bit of honeycomb and aren't the best defense against large pewpewmadas. The best way to win is build giant houses in enemy christmas ordament range to mess with them and make them feel like they aren't people before bringing your pewpews to the fight. And this is signs of a somber elephant Ripe onion, play this game because it's pretty good!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												One of the greatest 4X RTS games of all time. If you like space, spaceships, epic space battles, and empire management, then this game is for you. I played the original before it was on Steam (have the retail box here) and Rebellion basically combines the basic game with all released expansions; the end result is an amazing game extended with more awesomeness.+ The graphics are beautiful, you can freely zoom from a scale showing the entire solar system down to a single ship, the detail is amazing and space and especially the battles look incredible+ The expansion packs have added a lot, giving more defensive options, more offensive options, and more diplomatic options+ You can make custom maps and many maps have random elements for which planets or anomalies appear where, making for great replay value+ Full mod support+ The scale of this game is amazing+ The interface holds up really well and makes managing large empires easy- The game can be very performance demanding, especially as games drag on and everyone fields fleets of hundreds of ships, paired with hundreds of trade ships- you get the idea- Even though diplomatic options have been expanded, it's still more action focused in general- The three (six) factions all play fairly similar, they are about as different as Nod and GDI in C&C- No campaign, this game is focused on skirmish matches both in Single- and Multiplayer

content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
												Worth every penny. At first glance it might seem like a alot, but given some time you will learn what to research and build first and what not to. After you learn the base game, there are some great Star Trek and Star Wars mods that really change it up nicely. Along with numerous others mods that do as well.I hope to see a sequel to this game eventually, as there is a lot of room for potential once they move to a 64-bit engine.9/10 - One of the best Real Time Strategy Games out there.Why this gets a 9/10 as opposed to a 10/10 is because there is unfortunately no story line campaign to help build interest in learning and playing this game. But I will only afford it a -1, because the game mechanics are solid through out. So, If you ever see this and all of its DLC on sale, you might as well pick it up and try this out, especially if you have an interest in the following big name franchises. Star Wars, Star Trek and Halo. Space Battles won't be any better than this. Until DirectX 12 64-bit engine and making pieces of ships come off, shot after shot until the hull implodes or explodes. And also, No, you don't need the DLC you play any of the mods, etc, most of them are all designed to work with or without the different dlcs enabled/disabled.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
												I bought this game 4 days ago, I have already played it 60 hours...I have to say a lot of things in this game is awesome and that its a great game... but I can't recommended because it becomes an unplayable lag fest half way through every singleplayer match due to the outdated game engine because its a 32 bit engine that is not multithreaded. Out of those 60 hours I played, probably 50 hours of it was just because the game lags to the point where the game plays at less than 1/5 of the ordinary speed. And trust me on this, it isn't my hardware specs since my current rig is up there on the high end charts with an i7-4790K processor, R9-390 gpu, 16  GB of RAM. The vanilla game doesn't even use more than 1 GB of RAM, and it doesn't even make my GPU break a sweat since its just sitting their at its base clock of 350 mHz. Now usually I don't give negative reviews on games simply because they lag due to not being multithreaded (e.g. Total War Series), but the second thing that really irked me was how unbelievably dumb the AI is in this game. As if the lag wasn't bad enough, it just pisses you off even more when you watch the AI just constantly parading their ships back and forth, phase jumping between Solar Systems with over like 1000 ships and never actually fight each other due to their path finding and retreat logic.Not to mention I am the tech savy type of player, where I like to mod my games. And I don't mean I just go onto the steamworkshop or Moddb or the Nexus to download other peoples mods and call it a day. I mean I actually mod the game myself by tinkering with the files... and I got say too many damn things are hardcoded in this game. So while the modding community for this game is a lot better and friendlier than other games like Crusaders Kings 2 and Total War series, there is just so many basic things that they can't do. For instance do you want to build more than one Titan (the end game super ship for every faction)? Well to bad its hardcoded to be limited to 1 ship through ordinary means of building it. Do you want to change the priority of which ships the AI builds to reduce their Carrier spam that causes the game to lag so badly? Well to bad its hardcoded also, and there is no way to simply limit what they build since the game engine requires them to build every type of ship otherwise it crashes. There is no way to limit what they build without creating a specially made factions by duplicating the entire normal faction and removing certain ships from those factions altogether... because there is no way to change the AI's ship building priority weight scaling value.Not to mention the last  minor thing that bothers me in this game is that you can chose what faction the AI plays as, you can chose their faction color, their empire symbol, their play style, their difficulty levels... but you can't manually chose which of the 8 player portrait sets they use... you can cycle through them if you just constantly disable and enable their player slots, but even then the AI can't use the same portrait set as another player slot until 8 of them have been used. Which is annoying because how the portraits are set up is that there is 3 pictures per set, 1 for each race in every set. And there are 8 of these sets... but even when you play a different race from the AI, the AI can't use that portrait set even though you're not even using the same portrait.So in conclusion, the sound design, and graphics in this game is amazing. The concept and game mechanic wise its also great. But I wouldn't recommend this game due to the fact that the game engine is outdated and a poor match for game of this grand scale, which makes the game lag to the point where its unplayable. The AI is frustratingly Dead on Arrival if you play a map that has more than one solar system due to the fact that they will just keep phase jumping back and forth between stars unable to carrying out any actual cross system war. So due to the fact that the AI can't handle cross solar system fighting, you will never really be able to play any grand galactic empire building matches that involves more than 1 solar system. Though I am pretty sure you wouldn't want to anyways due to how badly the game lags. If you're planning to get this game for its modding value... sadly there isn't much to it beyond reskinning ships, planets, and buildings. Changing some of their basic stats and changing up some of their abilities... otherwise everything else is hardcoded. I was wondering why this game didn't have a steamworkshop when I first got the game... and the answer to that is because the game wasn't designed to be modder friendly, and that mod support was an after thought to the developers. So yeah there is still some great mods for this game, but at their core they are still going to be plagued with the problems I stated above, which is sad since I know how much effort and patience all those other modders put into their mods.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2016
												The game itself is great - IF IT RUNS.But it has so many bugs and crashes so often that you will undoubtedly change the settings file so that the autosave time is between 30 and 60 seconds, as the game crashes at least once every 5-20 minutes.Really ridiculous - especially in single player (local) gaming mode.At least you can load multiplayer games properly if you simply copy the savegame file to all others, since it regularly happens that the savegame is not saved on all players and participants of the multiplayer game.(However - opposed to Endless Legends, the game can actually load multiplayer properly 100% IF everyone has the same savegame file.)Of course you can only call it a medium sized 4X when compared to epic and complex (as well as just as badly written) games like Endless Legends.Also note that you need at least the mod for deactivating "experimental weapons" if you play against the AI as it is annoying to constantly have to rebuild the planets, since the AI just spams thos weapons (google it).So considering that it has a lot less to offer than Endless Legends I can only recommend it to people who know their way around settings files and want a real-time strategy 4X for a change, since only round-based 4X can get boring after a while.In a rating I would give Sins of a Solar Empire 3 of 5 points since the bugs are really destroying a lot of the game atmosphere and feeling and are happening every time you play a game - but at least it is possible to play it and end all games (as opposed to Endless Legends).

content:
Posted: July 28, 2015
												over 2oo hours should tell how much I enjoy this game. It is pleasing to see an entire enemy fleet try to launch an all out assault on one of your most defended fortressworlds with your entire fleet stationed in orbit and watch as you and your enemy lay waste to one another. The fear when your capital ships begin to fall and your flagship titan heavily damaged but you come out triumphant. with your victory you launch your counter attack and watch world after world fall under your battlefleet, conquering and expanding as you push deeper into your enemies empire. They surrender yet another challenges you for the right of the sector, so you press on.best for free for alls since nearly every time my ally is pratically useless, everyone always seems to gang up on them before one another. Its always a struggle on huge maps with over a hundred worlds in the webbing of jump lanes as your fleet could be cut off from one end of your empire( unless being the Vasari with phase stabilizers), resting pure faith that the border defences can hold any invaders as you try to break through enemy lines and face thier fleets on the other end of the map.  games can take hours or in a few cases half a day for larger maps. but seeing the victory sign in the end and seeing the stats of your domination is a welcoming feel.The Rebel TEC faction is my favorite as thier extreme xenophobic and hostile actions are purely intended for an offensive assault, they mock diplomacy except with other rebels or pirates. I mean would you be hostile against everyone else after 3 decades of constant warfare, rebellion, and failed diplomacy? wouldn't you just want to tableflip and yell 'thats it, everyone dies!"? I love thier titan flagship as it barges through entire fleets singlehandedly, bristling with gauss cannons and a massive railgun sniping captial ships and starbases from afar.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												This game is probably one of the few reasons I still love and trust the developer Stardock Studios. As a longtime Homeworld fan, this game was a lovely jaunt into a lovely mix between Civ 5's grand scale and planning and Homeworld 2's spaceship combat. I flat out adore this game. Its an excellent epic RTS game with a fantastic amount of depth, strategy, and sheer gaw dropping moments geared into it. Small space scouting and colonization leads to small skirmishes, which depending on how you play can lead to dozens of different outcomes - from skirmishes, to cold wars, to flat out epic space fleet battles, to interplanatary bombardments. Would recommend to anyone with a mind for strategy and eyeballs.

												Lots of boat ships with pew pews and sometimes people win by saying, "Hey let's be friends!" but there's lots of planets for you to name weird things and ships with rather gross sounding names as well. If you want to pew pew more you can research it in the big guns panel. It takes place in a space with christmas lights in the middle and when you tell your boats to move the paddlers get lazy and it takes a while to get to the fight. The game features yar har fiddle dee dees as well that you can pay with honeycombs to go and be jerks to your enemies while you make more breadboxes and boat ships. The game has 3 different types of man peoples they are all different but kinda the same. Some like the fight, and some like to drink wine, and one does a bit of both. This is a good game to bring to your friends so you can play this for 8 hours instead of cards against humans. In the new expansion pecks there are huge boat ships that don't sink like the titanic, they are really strong and pew pew more than normal boats, each type of peoples get 2 to choose from. If your christmas ordaments get under attack by the boats you can buy these duplo blocks with guns to defense but they can cost you a bit of honeycomb and aren't the best defense against large pewpewmadas. The best way to win is build giant houses in enemy christmas ordament range to mess with them and make them feel like they aren't people before bringing your pewpews to the fight. And this is signs of a somber elephant Ripe onion, play this game because it's pretty good!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												This game has been out for several years now and the fact that it still gets content upgrades (although the last few were somewhat less exciting DLCs) shows that is staying power. And honestly it's not coming from nowhere. It is probably one of the best space themed RTS games that you can get currently and the graphics, while a little dated, are still serving their purpose by giving you lots of beamy and exploding goodness when it comes to space battles. What however probably speaks the most for why this game is successfull is it's excellent user interface. All the information you require is easily accessible with the click of a button, if it's not displayed on screen right away. There is no rummaging through submenus and other distracting stuff to find out how many ressources are produced in which colony. The three different factions, which with the addon Rebellion got further split up into Loyalist and Rebel factions also provide many different approaches at how to play the game as each faction has their specialities. Want to have staunch unmoving defenders that will be even harder to remove from a system than cancer? Go with the TEC loyalists. Want a seemingly endless horde of♥♥♥♥♥♥cheap units to drown your enemies in AND be a pirate on top of that? Go with the TEC rebels, and that are just two sides of one race you can play.If you want a space themed RTS with huge space battles, then this is the game to go for.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
												The latest version of the franchise. It improves graphics and mechanics, while adding new ships, technologies, and planet upgrades. its a real-time, 4 dimensional, space strategy game.you capture planets, and gather resources, while building a fleet to defend your territory and making or breaking alliances with the other factions through diplomacy. you can win a diplomatic victory if you get enough points, which only happens if you keep the right factions happy and attack the otherrs. now planets can specialize, which is  a great addition to a game that needed a focus on the planets. now you can focus a planet on industrial or social production, that gives bonuses to ship production and trade or culture (which sacrifices the other two). this lets you boost production at the heart of your empire while spreading culture at the fringes fast enough to push out others. there are also new types of planets that tend to have increased resources, for example a greenhouse world will have a lot of metal asteroids that let you extract metal faster than other planets.then there are the new ships the titan and the shriken corvettes (of the terran players) add a new, somewhat irritating element. if you are caught without a titan, and a small fleet, the game is over, they are massive ships with huge health and weapons abilities that have to be researched first and are kind of expensive (each faction has its version). the rebel and loyalist forces now have differing abilities that give bonues to various aspects of gameplay.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
												If your planning on buying this game be sure to clear your schedule, one match will take quite sometime. But the game is very fun you start off owning a planet and must expand your empire through multiple solar systems fighting enemy's along the way. You can use diplomacy, cunning, and military to win. there is no campaign for this game only the type of mode i was just explaining previously. In this game there are three factions and each has a loyalist and rebel version both with different ships and abilty's. Another great thing about this game is you can get great mods such as sins of the prophet which is a halo mod. I would not suggest buying this game at the 40$ retail, wait till its on sale for around 20$.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												I bought Rebellion eventuality. I'm not planning do it ever.But I like that game from first minutes.I tried many space strategies before. But they was... not what I'm looking.Too hard (not because they really hard. because it's hard to understand them), too overwhelmed - economy, interface, races. Where you need to press 10 buttons to move your fleet.Here everything easy - here your fleet, here your structures. Go! But game not become simple. You still need to think, planning, tactic. And what a beautiful space here! Last time I saw such beautiful space was Haegemonia: Legions of Iron (2002) But that game was really overwhelmed.So if you want to try really good space strategy, then Sins of a Solar Empire®: Rebellion your choice.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												Wanted the game for a while now.Couldn't afford it with the 40 dollar asking price.I pirated it. I know I'm a filthy pirate :c I just really wanted to play this game.Saw that it was on sale for 20$ including all dlc and sound track.Had 20$ in my steam wallet.Noticed the updated the game a bit since my filthy version. Little things like bigger/competitive maps.At first I couldn't find a game in multiplayer but learned that it was because it was only 11 o' clock on a friday.Was really surprised this game even had people playing online.People actually care for the game to, when everyone gets into one lobby they all talk about what they should keep on and off such as locked teams, pirates, random events, etc....Recently learned they support mods.I still think 40$ is still a bit much of an asking price, and honestly the dlc is kind of a rip off if it's not on sale.In my opinion it should be 30$ and you should only buy the dlc when it's on sale.Worth my 20$, wouldn't have minded spending a bit more on it though.8/10 One of my top five games.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												This game is appealing, I had SOME fun with it. The problem is almost no one plays this game online, and the single player AI is way too powerful. As in I am only just starting my fleet up when im getting hit by their titan, 2 capitals, 15 cruisers, and 5 frigates. I cannot enjoy myself because I cannot get anyone else interested in this game to play it with me, and online is incredibly meh. And as I have described single player is right out. So I want to like this game, I really do. I am a big fan of fleet v fleet games, and the graphics in this one are really nice. But the gameplay is severely lacking. I start every session TRYING to enjoy myself, and I always come out dejected and angry. Sorry, but I have to say I wouldn't reccomend this.

												Been A Wile Since I Played, Came Back To A Launcher For A Launcher..... Always A Bad SignDo your engineers really have nothing to do?  I do not care about unsolicited SD news, ads or any other crap forced onto my screen.  I do care that SD has forced something on my machine without any heads up about what the install would do.How about leaving well enough alone and putting your team to work on a real project?Crap like this is usually a bad sign from  the publisher.Seems that SD takes great umbrage calling an application that I did not ask for or give permission to be on my system and force advertisements onto my screen before a product I bought outright will launch (much like the win 10 sneak installs got labeled by various security software producers)..... Malware.  So since this extra totally not asked for install that added an extra layer of unwanted ads and unwanted news (not even going to hypothesize about data collection) is totally not-malware, really and truly.To prevent the totally not-malware launcher from launching the launcher from the launcher  copy the totally not-malware launcher .exe file and the  SoaSE  .exe file  (or rename them as you see fit).  Then delete or rename the totally not-malware .exe file to something like notamalwareinstall.exe or whatever you like, then rename the SoaSE .exe file to the original totally not-malware launcher file name.

												  Well, I'm reviewing now. I will say that while I would recommend the game, yeah, it is very difficult to play.- The computer opponents will sometimes be rendered toothless, by creating no armies on Normal difficulty. - The lack of a workshop is REALLY surprising for a game like this, Modding for this game on steam would INFINITELY make the game more playable and fun, and want to sink more hours into the game. However, as it stands, it is only the same strategy, over and over again, on the AI. I guess it just boils down to poor AI, it's either too easy or too hard, longer matches do not provide a fuller experience, and I suspect multiplayer to be as caustic as Starcraft's. For the amount fo time I have played and already getting bored, I must say that as of Feb. 1, 2016, this game is NOT worth $40.

content:
Posted: April 17, 2016
												Bottome line up front: 8.5/10 game, tons of fun. However I do not recommend purchasing Sins on Steam. The Steam verison is buggy and crashes randomly. Purchase Sins from another third-party vendor, or directly from the developer / publisher.I came across Sins while I was deployed to the middle east, a buddy of mine gave me a pirated copy. I immensely enjoy this game, and I put countless hours into it when I was off-duty. If I had to guess I'd say I played around 8-900 hours over 9 months.I never had any problems with the game, except for the mulitplayer not working due to it being a pirated copy. It crashed around 7-8 times over 9 months, and most of those were when I was intentionally pushing the game and my computer to their limits. Whether it was single player, LAN, small pre-made maps or huge custom ones, the game worked as it should. I would notice some issues with frame rate late-game, when there would be hundreds of ships on the screen during battles, but that's likely my computer reaching it's upper limits and not any issue with the game engine.I recently decided to buy Sins in order to support the developers for making a game I have so thoroughly enjoyed. I Downloaded and installed the game, launched it, and the steam bootstrapper kept crashing and rebooting. I didn't restart my computer before attempting to launch the game, and yes I know you should, but I've never had a problem with running a steam game after installing it without restarting. That was the first sign of something being wrong.I restarted, and that fixed the issue. I get into my first match, a 1v1 on the Gemini medium map, and the game randomly crashes around 20 minutes in. I relaunched and got into another game, this time a 2v2v2 on a huge multi star comp map, and it crashed again at around 90 minutes.I can count on my hands how many times the pirated copy crashed, over the hundreds of matches I played. The official copy of the game from steam crashed twice in a row in the first two matches. And I bet you my next paycheck it will crash again the next match I play.A pirated copy of the game is more stable than the steam release. Absolutely pathetic, Valve.Edit: I have since played 6 more matches, two of which crashed. So Steam Sins is 4 for 8, or 50% failure rate. Going to try reinstalling to see if that fixes the issue for me. Revised some portions of this review, as I wrote this while slightly intoxicated.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 16, 2014
												Where can I even start with this game.......so put yourself in my shoes. A veteran total war player looking to find new RTS games to get away from the dying series that I spent years getting good at. Leaving behind, my friends I'd made, and achievements, to find a new, and refreshing game to take my mind off, if even in a small way. Upon my travels, I venture upon this game......the artwork looks cool, the screenshots look amazing, the description looks epic........but then my eyes wander down to the price tag. For the rather steep price of 39.99.....I can be a galactic tyrant vying for control of the galaxy. I think long and hard on the issue......do I really wanna go back to total war? After some thought, I decide to take a chance....I pay up, and to my hardrive, this magnificant software is installed. I enter the game, and instantly I see promise with a great sound track and breathtaking visuals. I feel so humbled by the new game that has surrounded me in it's atmosphere, and I meekly wander over to the tutorials, where I learn the way of the galactic conquerer. Then I start up a real game, and after only a few adreneline soaked engagements, I am thrilled to know that my money was spent wisely and have no regrets on the risk that I took to experience this game. Ever since that fateful day, this game has been my therepist.....calming my mind with it's awesome gameplay whenever I am stressed. I love this game and have no doubt that anyone with the slightest fanboyism for sci fi and strategy will love this too. I highly recommend this game if you are looking at it's page, wondering the same way I wondered whether or not to take that risk.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2016
												What to say?This game depends on what you paid for it.The original game is meh. Complete, in that all elements are present, but meh.Now, the Star Trek Armada III mod makes the game shine. Except in one area, which I'll touch on shortly.The STA3 mod is fantastic, in fact it's just about the best mod for any game I've ever come across. Whereas the original game was meh, the STA3 makes it shine. Most elements are improved, and in fact the mod is more professional than the original game, IMHO.Of course the one thing that modders can't really do, most times, is alter code. And that's the glaring problem for the meh original game and the brilliant STA3 mod.I've played almost 50 hours on this game, and at least the last 20 have been a struggle.The game is boring.Boring. Once you've explored it, that's it.  I'm used to slow burns playing 4X games, and while this is an RTS game with 4X elements, I'd rather play SEV at 1/4 impulse power than this game, despite the massive difference in graphics between the two.So to recommend or not? Again, depends on what you paid.I got the game at 75% off, so I've got my money's worth. If I'd paid full freight I wouldn't have been happy. So, as the game is mostly full price, no recommendation.  But if you can get it on sale, do it.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												NOTE: I can't claim to have played this to any meaningful depth. Actually I've only slogged through the tutorials and played half of an AI game. Now then:This is an excellent GAME ENGINE just begging for an actual GAME to be written in it. All the prerequisites are in place: well-balanced races, deep technology tree, diverse win conditions, diplomacy and culture. Which makes it a 4X game, but even better, because it's also a RTS. With SPACE BATTLES! There's even a background story presented in a short movie to go with, and while it's mostly standard fare, it would allow for many, many directions. Hell, a good writer could turn it into a five-season sci-fi TV show.Elsewhere I read that the fans have been bugging Ironclad for a campaign practically since the game came out, and they refuse to do one, claiming that the engine won't support the necessary coding. Excuses, excuses. This game needs a campaign to give it direction. To give the player purpose, to make them part of something greater, to have them work towards something they care about. Without that, all we can do is make them up in our heads. Or keep the story and game separate: think tabletop RPGs, but with the story elements done in text outside the game, and the battles inside. And even there this engine doesn't really deliver: you can't create scenarios that would support it, nor can you for example fix the technological level or starting planets and units of a player or AI opponent. Which means it's from scratch every time.If it did have a campaign, I'd probably waste innumerable hours on it, I love my epic hard sci-fi, and the feel is certainly there. But there's no game here. Just an engine.

Posted: April 28, 2016
												Gameplay-wise Sins of a Solar Empire is great (SciFi strategy) and I had lots of hours of fun playing it. The thing that really annoys me about it is that Stardock decided that you need another layer of DRM on it after steam. It comes in the form of a stardock account that has to be created with your email adress and you have to remember it every time you reinstall the game. I am ok with steam because it is a one-for-all account which minimises the hassle of dealing with log-ins and passwords. Thats why this is bothering me so much. Just now when I decided to play another round after a while, the game forced me to log in with the stardock account which password I have long forgotten and I dont want to invest more time to create a new one or restore the old one. If every company did stupid things like these, playing your games would become really annoying. The game itself is good, but I paid for it and I dont want additional hassle. I dont care if Stardock wants to turn their games into facebook, but as long as they add such unnecessary inconvenience, I wont buy another game from them again.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2016
												Who knows if this will get read or not, but I  hope I can provide a word of warning. Sins of a Solar Empire was one of the first games that made me want a gaming computer when it first came out in 2008. Lacking the funds, I was stuck with low-end graphics and abysmal load times. Its been 8 years since I've played the game, and seeing it on sale, I grabbed it for some quick nostalgia. The game runs fine. Any computer from the last 3 years should handle it with zero problems. Technically, its almost flawless, completely delivering on the promise of full scale immersion in a 4x game, zooming effortlessly between multiple star systems down to the individual starfighter. The graphics are decently done, and large-scale battles have the potential to be impressive and pretty, if not awe-inspiring. Thats about where the positives end. My major complaints with this game is that the amount of effort that was put into certain areas of the game is severly lopsided. The tech tree is the biggest transgressor, with tiny, incrimental techs that require constant micromanaging to ensure that you don't get caught woefully behind. When trying to construct a unit or building that you don't have the tech for, it takes many frustrating minutes (ESPECIALLY with a new civilzation) to figure out which tree it is under, and then locate the correct icon. The tech interface is tiny and wastes a lot of space. In fact, nearly every interface is a mess. From simply having to click through each and civilzation to see which are defeated and which are active (maybe a red <DEFEATED> next to their title would help..?", to confusing and unexplained treaty organization, it seems that information is deliberately hidden. Massive amounts of work apparently went into the detailed sidebar which I have never looked at even once while playing. With each of the available civs having completely different icons, names, and abilities for buildings, and totally different sets of units, there is a steep learning curve to just understanding what each of them DO. Upgrading planets is boring and repetitive. The game punished you for expanding, and it takes a lot of time to make new planets worth the investment. So all of this takes MASSIVE amounts of time to learn, and to balance effectively. Which would be fine, except that none of it is fun or rewarding. Its the most frustrating part of the game, but it requires huge amounts of time. I know what you're thinking, 'dude, thisi s a 4x game, micromanaging is kind of a given' Which is true on its face, and for any other game, I'd agree. But its sooo boring. And unrewarding. And this is where Sins breaks down, because all of this should have some kind of payoff, namely in space battles. Battles are basically just jump your ships in, have them attack the largest ships in order... they just sit there. It would be amazing to divide your fleet into squadrons, have flanking options, order all of my bombers to prioritize carriers or support ships first... but no. You have to do each thing manually, and again, if you haven't played the other civs, its IMPOSSIBLE to tell what ships do what. I can't recommend this game. Its just not fun.

												I have played 14 hours of this game and only 14 hours because shortly after that the content broke for me. I have an apprently unresolvable error which appeared out of nowhere. IF you are one of the unfortunate people who runs into an error that can't be resolved via web page directions, be prepared to wait days just to get more than two responses to a support ticket and don't expect anything you didn't already know from reading it.

												A slow paced game with a bit of a learning curve, but the tutorials are decent enough to get you started. There is a lot of strategic depth to this game and the AI is a challenge. It involves very long-term planning. Decisions you make early in the game will have long-lasting effects later on, and things generally don't change very quickly. It's a game which I think does not have nearly the amount of popularity that it deserves.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												When I first bought this game the voice acting really annoyed me.  There are still elements in the voice acting I can't stand.  For example, the sound of water sucked through a straw doesn't count as good sound effects.  It just sounds dumb.  Also the sound of THE SAME voice actor over and over again for different parts, or some of the ridiculous alien monster sounds.I hated it so much that I actually wrote a script to copy those sounds out to be replaced by sounds that were neutral.----- ENOUGH RANTING ALREADY -----That said, there is also some good voice acting, like "I hope this isn't another suicide mission!" and when a new colony is founded "A new colony has been founded" and there's some dramatic orchestral music.  "The price on our heads has increased!"  Those I really like, and the more I play the more it grows on me.The gameplay is simplistic - all the ships do whatever it is they do, and there are minimal choices for changing how they work.  And the capital ships have level caps (maybe that's fixed in some mods).There are a number of mods which I still have to try.What I like about this game: it goes pretty fast.  Unlike SotS or Star Ruler or GalCiv - this feels like it plays much faster.  Maybe I'm hallucinating too.  The tech tree is certainly much smaller than those other games - so the whole game feels smaller.So for a "quick space game 4x" this is one I find myself going back to.

content:
Posted: April 17, 2014
												This game nearly ruined my relationship! In the best way possible though as it is so addictive and engaging. There are only three races to choose from (6 if you count the rebels) but they all have such a well developed back story, and each race has different tactical challenges and opportunities. The space battles are nothing short of epic and the 'God like' abililty to zoom in for a close up of your fleet slugging it out with the enemy is miles better than any sci-fi space movie I've seen. The difficulty levels are steep as you progress through them and you will have to think quickly and tactically at a moments notice to stay competive on the higher levels, but it is ultimately a very satisfying feeling once you master it.The only real drawback to this game is that there is no campaign mode, which would have been nice, and a couple of extra races just to add a little more diversity would have been welcome too. I also recommend spending some time playing through the tutorials just to get a good grasp of the game, as there is a lot to take in initially, which I find is common with similar games to Sins.Overall, I highly recommend this game to fans of strategy and 4x games, you will not be disappointed....

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												Awesome Game.It will have a long life time as it is moddable, and a nice game to relax and play, or panic as you try to save your empire.Great selection of ships, not to much in the way of this kills this, then this kills this, but not this.Dowsides in My opnion, none.No campaing, but that lets me make my own story.I can be trying to save civilian ships from a all consuming alien force as I try to research my titan as a final end the war. Or, im running from them in a rag tag fleet of ships, slowly losing a battle on ship at a time.Has a slight learning curve, and the game can be unforgiving at times, but its worth it. Researching is awesome, as is attacking the merchant cargo ships to destroy that small advantage some one else has. Or making a alliance, just to backstab your ally because they have a weak fleet.I highly recomment this game, its great fun, and is great for making up your own story. Feel free to add me to play a few rounds (or 1, as the game takes long to complete, but keeps you excited all the way.)

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												Do you want large scale space combat with solar systems to explore, conquer and colonize?  Yes please!  Build massive armada's, seize territory across dozens of planets on a single map, fight against space pirates and up to 10 opponents at once.  Play cooperatively or Free For All online or set up the perfect single player challenge.  Pure sandbox RTS gameplay, set your own rules and become the ruler of the galaxy.  Also includes a map designer so you can create your own systems to fight over.  Supports modding and comes DRM free (game does require a one time registration).

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												I was sceptical. I play such games only alone against AI or maybe coop against AI if one of my friends plays such a game. Without a story driven campaign it was some kind of risk for me to buy this game.But if you look at my playtime you can see that i enjoyed this game anyway. I love the big space battles against a good AI. With space stations and the Titans there are explosions everywhere. But that reveals the only big drawback of this game. The outdated engine. With big fleet battles going on and having many AI oponents the game needs a very good CPU with much power per single core because it will only use one core.But besides of this technical drawback i have much fun watching 2 big fleets battling each other, micro manage the special powers of my starship and after the fight extend my Solar Empire. And defend it at the other side of the empire one minute later. The research of the updates and the diplomacy are the icing of the cake.And dont forget the good mods out there. First of all i have much fun with the "enhanced 4x mod". Great work.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2014
												The Base format of this game alone will provide quite a few hours of fun! If you can get your friends to play with you it becomes an even grander experience! Games can last for extremely long times and develop its own history. Periods of war and peace along with large defensive fronts and subtle strikes against production planets. If you ever get bored with the original game the amount of modding content available on the web is crazy. From Star wars to a remake of Homeworld. You can find just about anything. I highly recommend this game to anyone interested in 4x Strategy. However be warned this game does have a high learning curve and the scale of war can get quite overwhelming!
