content:
Posted: September 26, 2015
												So I have hap this game for about 3 years now, and recently I told my friend about that game because it was on sale. (not this sale,but the last one.) He sees it and thinks it's amazing, I tell him that it is. He gets the game and we immediately begin playing. After about 5 hours of teaching him how to play, he gets tired and leaves.Now a little bit ago I say we should play again, he is hesitant, but he agrees to anyway. We start up the game and I set everything to faster so he can play a quicker game (faster training, mining, culture.) Everything is going great for the first 10 minutes or so, until we establish first contact.Now since he is still learning, I have had to teach him up to this point and our technological advancements and colonization have been slow. Not to mention I had to help him learn how to play the Advent as I was playing the TEC. I expected that star to star jumping would be reached within 10 minutes, but they are already here. A couple scouts are not really an issue, so we continue to expand, then my friend is alof a sudden really scared because he had lost one of his colonies. I simply thought he accidentally scuttled it and he was paying attention to his (small) army fighting rebels. It wasn’t until the third colony that I went to investigate. There, I found a HUGE war party in his late colony’s system.Im freaking out and Telling him to Bring his army back to defend his home world, and that's when I notice that the same this is happening to me. With an army of that size, they must have been expanding into the other galaxies without much trouble, and now we were paying for it.About 20 minutes later, and 20 minutes of constantly defending our colonies, I have a great idea. I immediately start rushing siege frigates and my titan (the Ragnarov titan is personally my favorite, which is basically a giant rail gun, with engines and smaller guns all around it) and I tell him to do the same. Confused, he has to listen because he has no other ideas. My idea is to win by sneaking 100 siege frigates and a titan into the enemy territory, and take their home planet before they can gets troops back from the front lines (our colonies). And very soon, the pan is under way. We have literally every single ship, which added together is only a fraction of our enemies army, and send them on a straight shot for his home world. During this time, he has taken almost all of our colonies(be both have about 2 left) and they don’t seem to care that our armies have disappeared. 5 Minutes later, we make the final jump into a heavily fortified system with gauss platforms and mines EVERYWHERE and a fully upgraded starbase. Note that at this point, all of his ships are flying back to save his home planet, but by then it's too late. we destroy his defences and being bombing the planet. Sadly, about half way through destroying it, my friend lost his Capital, and his ships lost all ties with me, but is was too late. The final nuke was fired, sealing his fate as the first of his ships jumped into the system. We had won in probably the most dirty and underhanded way, but we had won.10/10 would accidentally understand the plot to Ender’s Game.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2012
												This is a great space, 4X RTS games.Its in-depth, as you have to explore the galaxies, expand your empire as the Rebels or Loyalist of the three main races, Advent, Vasari, or the TEC, exploit the resources on each planet, as well as artifacts, and exterminate all who stand in your way.Manipulate your opponents, send pirate raids after people that annoy you. Defend your empire with a range of different ships and structures, trade within your own empire, as well as others, and command your massive armadas of ships, with a slick interface, well balanced ships, and an intelligent AI, which seems like it cheats the harder you set it to.(If you watch the replays, the AI literally spawns ships in. D:<)Rebellion is a great addition to the series, and the DLC, while seeming minor, expands on the gameplay in surprising ways.11/10

content:
Posted: July 29, 2013
												Excellent space 4x game. Real-time but no need for a click-frenzy. Choosing between 'Rebel' and "Loyalist" versions of each of the factions is cool and customizes the faction to your own playstyle. Beautiful graphics, tons of maps to play (including random) that can get freaking huge. Pretty good diplomacy options, actually. If you play against AI, the jump from Medium to Hard is pretty large so you'll want to ease into it. Lots of tech to research and each main faction feels really unique. Hard to stop playing.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												Rebellion is not much of an expansion over the original sins. If you do not own sins go aheadand buy rebellion if it looks cool. Its really low on bugs, I cant recall seeing any honestly andis a lot of fun for a great many hours single player. I say rebellion isnt much of an expansionor sequal over sins, because I owned sins. Rebellion as a stand alone adds a few new ships anda modified research tree based on faction.I'm not sure you should buy this "sequal" if you own the original... are you a big fan?Rebellion does not fully satisfy the cravings I still hold for masters of orion 2, but it is the bestplace holder I have seen for now. (or sins, there is little difference)A fan of strategy games will enjoy sins, and it's defininately worth a look if you find it onsale! I find the idea that rebellion is a sequal offensive. There have been no changes tothe engine, almost no gameplay changes. Recommended, but not as a sequal, only if you dont presently own sins.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 1, 2014
												One of the most complex and challenging games I've ever played, just keep catching myself coming back for the large space feel and wanting to test my abilities with new tactics. SINS is a game you must play if you have an overactive brain that wants something substantial to chew on it is the far opposite of Battlefield or GTA5. it has a charm to it's space exploration as you discovering interesting qualities about the planets you colonize and look at how to best tactically control your part of the galaxy. Do not play on large maps until you are familiar with it and expect EVERY game to take atleast 1.5 to 3 hours from start to finish.  Totally awesome, my only criticism is that unlike starcraft's casual and fast gameplay the tech and expansion take SO long, there is no arcade mode so to speak, you really have to invest a whole evening into it.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2015
												What can I say about this game having spent almost 500 hours on it. Well I can start with the huge scale of the game with simply amazing gameplay mechanics and a UI thats easy to navigate. From playing defensive building huge stations and orbital defences to building massive fleets 800 ships strong to conquer your enemies. Ship deisgn is top notch with each race having their own unique look and feel. Wide selection of maps from small 1 vs 1 maps to 10 player maps. Theres maps with just one solar system and a handful of planets to maps with 20+ solar systems and hundreds of planets. (note 10 player matchs can last for 12 hours or more easily but you can save the game at any time and the game also supports a really good auto save system.) Tech tree is really good with good descriptions explaining what dose what. The games AI on the hardest difficulties will give you a run for your money. The game seems to be well balanced with counters to almost every unit in the game. The mods for the game make it even better with the likes of Star wars, Star trek Armada, Battlestar Galactica etc.  Negitives I ran into was the lack of a campaign, Slight slowdowns on the big maps (could be my rig personally) lack of lore and story, Titans can be a little over powered. Other than these small problems the game is amazing highly recommmend it 9.8/10.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
												Do I even need to write a review? Old as♥♥♥♥♥♥ rebellion comes as complete and adds mirror rebel versions of the 3 base factions (giving you 6). Awesome game if you're into space empire building from the leaders seat, ala civ.Very enjoyable for a hardcore-but-also-simple 4X Real-Time Space fleet strategy game. Base building is done inside a planet gravity-well / static defence, planets themselves are your strongeholds. they are capped not destroyed, but similar to lowering a flag and raising a flag, or controlling points (of a galaxy map). Civ in space, in real time, with space ships and planets, pew pew!Maps can be randomly generated and theres already a spew of hand crafted offical ones, there a few map editors (I believe an official one as well) can be found online, some give you way more control then others. Players can choose from 3 base races, 2 variations of tech paths per race, giving you 6 different choices (6 different factions).Ships start as frigates, work up in class/shipsize to mega-capital ships. Capital ships are Hero units (inc. mega-capitals), and cannot ressurect XP once killed/destroyed (obv. can rebuild). Common/Regular Ships themselves come as types, some types are grunts (swordsman/rifleman feel), some are support types (Medic only abilities) some house fighters/bombers of your choice(how many of ea.), obviously there are dedicated carriers as well. Each base race has different ships avialable to them, most mirror one another to create simple balance mechanics.Credits and materials are generated based on a gather rate / time unit. Tech trees are fairly big, espeiclly at first but you learn short-cuts, what you need/don't need pretty quickly after a couple of games with your prefered race. Each race also has different tech options, with different effects- but the rebel factions (mirror factions) have slight modifications to them, mostly for different ships that are available, or a niche tech that really bennifits them and sets them apart. (I mostly play Terran (Traders) and the above written is more so the observed comparrison between the two (traditionalists and rebels))Pirates / Bounties on other players are a thing, can hinder the game, some times break it depending on how aggressive other players don't want to get♥♥♥♥♥♥on at the last moment and how much money they have, and you have, and obviously how much your both willing to rappidly 'dump' by clicking the bounty button, each click ensuring more pirates, and grow a horde (rapidly) thats seconds away from dropping on one another (You'll know exactly what I speak of first game, if you and your enemy have the cash!). The resulting mess of pirates can wipe multiple players out on the way (if in the way) as well as decimate the player who just happened to have the timer close on him (almost like musical chairs!). You CAN DISABLE PIRATES before you begin a match. And also, Pirate come from specific 'homeworld asteroids', if you conquer or wipe out these planets, the Pirates will stop coming- because they are 'much dead'.Matches can last anyware between 1 hours - 12 hours+ (I've never played more then about 12 or 13 hour matches at most). And of course matches can be saved.Depending on number of players, AI, and your system; performance in late game CAN and most likely will take a hit, at least until people start getting wiped all over the space-floor. If you get games just too big for your system though, you can quickly find that in 45 minutes of gameplay your frame rate just peters out and the matches can become 'unplayable', which can become quite suprising if you're just getting into a match  / having 'a blast'.It should be noted that there are quick gameconfig.ini to tweak different effects, max ship numbers, etc. etc., all to boost or lower your performance (If you have some sort of "Mega-Rig" and you just want 100X more ships then the initial release suppored, it's do-able quickly by editing your INI's, but it's mostly on you to figure out what your system can do!).Apparently theres also great mods (Starwars total conversions, etc) available as well, though I haven't had much luck getting them going myself.-------Simple, but can be complex, short or long. massive space battles and some glorious captial ship victories really bring this game together, if you're into the 4X at all!

content:
Posted: August 29, 2015
												What can I say about this game having spent almost 500 hours on it. Well I can start with the huge scale of the game with simply amazing gameplay mechanics and a UI thats easy to navigate. From playing defensive building huge stations and orbital defences to building massive fleets 800 ships strong to conquer your enemies. Ship deisgn is top notch with each race having their own unique look and feel. Wide selection of maps from small 1 vs 1 maps to 10 player maps. Theres maps with just one solar system and a handful of planets to maps with 20+ solar systems and hundreds of planets. (note 10 player matchs can last for 12 hours or more easily but you can save the game at any time and the game also supports a really good auto save system.) Tech tree is really good with good descriptions explaining what dose what. The games AI on the hardest difficulties will give you a run for your money. The game seems to be well balanced with counters to almost every unit in the game. The mods for the game make it even better with the likes of Star wars, Star trek Armada, Battlestar Galactica etc.  Negitives I ran into was the lack of a campaign, Slight slowdowns on the big maps (could be my rig personally) lack of lore and story, Titans can be a little over powered. Other than these small problems the game is amazing highly recommmend it 9.8/10.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												Rebellion is not much of an expansion over the original sins. If you do not own sins go aheadand buy rebellion if it looks cool. Its really low on bugs, I cant recall seeing any honestly andis a lot of fun for a great many hours single player. I say rebellion isnt much of an expansionor sequal over sins, because I owned sins. Rebellion as a stand alone adds a few new ships anda modified research tree based on faction.I'm not sure you should buy this "sequal" if you own the original... are you a big fan?Rebellion does not fully satisfy the cravings I still hold for masters of orion 2, but it is the bestplace holder I have seen for now. (or sins, there is little difference)A fan of strategy games will enjoy sins, and it's defininately worth a look if you find it onsale! I find the idea that rebellion is a sequal offensive. There have been no changes tothe engine, almost no gameplay changes. Recommended, but not as a sequal, only if you dont presently own sins.

number of helpful: 7 of 16 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 29, 2016
Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion is in its core a Command & Conquer type RTS in space with light 4x elements 4x FeaturesLet's start with the 4x elements first. There is almost no planetary development. You can grow population, add some slots for buildings, improve your planet's health all with a couple of clicks. It will take a few minutes to fully develope your planet. The research tree is generic. When you build let's say a frigate factory you will unlock one ship type. There is a research tab for every ship in the game for unlock only purpose.  There are 4 tabs alone for upgrading armor, doing the same thing for every tab. Same thing for laser weapons, 3 tabs where every tab is divided into 2 levels ( need to research 1 tab twice) for every incremental increase in laser damage. There is so much unnecessary stuff in the tree that it is just not tech tree worthy as a whole.Expansion is pretty straightforward take a planet by force or take it over by influence. Panets are connected by phase lanes (strings) over which are you able to move and spread your influence. I'd say diplomacy is the only 4x worthy element this game has to offer and worked out well. You can accept missions to increase their relation with you or you give them a mission to improve your relation with them. If the relation in both ways is high enough the chance of them accepting heavier stuff is more probable.You may ask (missions) a faction to destroy ships, capital ships, structures etc and the amount of it. If they kill 5 or 15 enemy ships for you depends on the relationship. You are also able to join pacts. The better the relation, the more pacts you can join like cease fire, peace, vision or trade treaties. Managing your economy is just as thin as in any other RTS, colonize asteroids for metal and crystal income and max out your population for credits.RTS based gameplayFirst of all there is no singleplayer campaign, it is just pure skirmish against bots and multiplayer. Second point I want to make is that the majority of your game time is spend by battling enemy fleets. Gameplay wise you build up a fleet of mixed unit types. Attack the enemy, lose a big chunk of your fleet, rebuild your fleet and go for the next planet. Flanking does not pay off. There isn't any tactics involved other than timing the activation of your ship's special abilities.There is no stealth, no surgical strikes, no flanking. Every game plays out the same, build a big balanced fleet and overwhelm the enemy. Quick building is your way to succes. This is a casual RTS game with extra bells and whistles (4x elements) which lacks strategic depth. The game has good graphics and the battles are nice to see when you are zoomed in, which rarely happens anyway. I did not expect this game to have such a lack of tactical gameplay, such a shame. For a casual RTS experience this game is good. Good graphics, flashy space battles, lots of cool units, wonderful sound effects, always things to do, mods and the 4x elements , altough very minor, are a plus. I would not buy the game if you expect a 4x game, total war style of gameplay or the ability to use tactics to decide battles. I would only recommend this game if you want another casual RTS experience (with casual I don't mean quality, but there are more of them on the market in terms of gameplay). I will give this game thumbs down however (has nothing to do with rating but with recommendation), the reason for downvoting is the lack of depth gameplay wise and the bells an whistles don't make up for it.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 19, 2016
												It's an RTS with almost no micromanagement, in space, in real time, with lots of glittery fighter swarms and pew pew lasers. The races are all interesting and play fairly differently from eachother... seriously, it's hard not to recommend this game, it fills a niche that desperately needs filling.But, unless you're willing to play for diplomatic victories which use an arbitrary point system (that I found too annoying and silly to try more than once. Everyone spams you with quests and I think you just suddenly win if you make enough friends or something? It's weird, I hate it.), or if you're only interested in vs players (which I know nothing about), I'd pass on this game entirely, even though it looks and sounds really good on paper.The game is paced so unbelievably poorly that I, almost without exception, regret the time spent after I'm done playing... and it's entirely because of the poor AI, it's too smart where it shouldn't be (you have to level up your ships with combat, but enemies run away from any fight they can't easily win) or too stupid where it should be smarter (space stations aren't considered at all when they're sizing up if they can win a fight), and difficulties do nothing more than tell the computer how much to cheat, and then after a point I guess the AI just decides that you've won, because it never attacks you ever again... but it also doesn't hit the surrender button, and sense it's always running away from you the game becomes just hours and hours of bombing planets wondering if anything is going to happen.Spoiler alert, no, nothing is going to happen, the moment you max out your fleet you might as well quit. They don't even put up defenses, it just takes forever to kill them all and then you're done.Not to mention the achievements are some of the lamest busywork tasks I think I've ever seen, "win as [race] researching each and every tech in only [this tree] and nothing else ever", what? That doesn't make any sense, why are there 9 copies of this achievement? This isn't a reason not to buy the game, it just annoys me.A friend of mine has all the DLC, and so long as he hosts I'm able to play with all the DLC. We haven't exactly tested it exhaustively, but none of the above problems appear to be fixed or even improved by them.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												This was the first game of the series that I played, and having been a huge fan of the Age of Empires series, I absolutely loved it. Sins of a Solar Empire takes RTS to a whole new level; you don't just takeover the world, you take over the universe!On the other hand, being new made it very hard for me to get to grips with the game, I'll keep coming back to it of course, but it was very hard to understand what was the better unit. Three classes and six ships within, along with five different branches of a technology tree with near a hundred options for each - what do I choose?!?The visuals were quite amazing - though I disliked not being able to much of the battle graphically, rather than with icons. The interface made sense, and despite a couple of bits I didn't get first off, it worked very well. All in all a great game, well worth buying for any fan of RTS or Sci-Fi nut.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12, 2016
												Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion is yet another example of a space 4X RTS game with a good concept but poor execution. The UI is very badly designed and doesn’t help with locating and keeping track of ships much at all and you’ll be zooming in or clicking to confirm things because the planetary tab interface on the left is ♥♥♥♥ing useless. Combat is clunky and awkward and micromanaging ships will quickly become an exercise in futility in larger battles. The pirate mechanic is kind of neat but ultimately ends up just being a money drain since the AI likes to be frugal in most cases. Also be prepared to switch to manual targeting as your forces will still try to kill “paid off” pirates. Additionally real-time just isn’t a fun thing to have in 4x and I feel like it’s a feature that nobody really wanted but developers are trying anyway “just because”. I guess if I had to say one thing positive about this game it would be that at least the overall pacing isn’t as tedious as in Stardrive, but it could be a lot better too.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2012
												A great RTS for space lovers. Keeps the game play relitivly simple while not feeling boring. If you liked the previous games, you will love this one. If you havent played the previous games, you like space, and like RTS, then check this out.Great blend of resorce managment, building an army, and expansion gameplay. Large space battles are a regular event in this game, where hundreds of ships clash in epic battles over planets. For those who love to just brute force, you will enjoy that part.For those who enjoy more subtle gameplay, the diplomacy and civilian trees offer that. Spread your culture to your enemys worlds and eventually spark a rebellion on that planet, making it ripe for you to come in and colonise it. Ally yourself with those close to you and trade resorces and tech to enhance your own abilities. Or go it alone and give missions to the pirates to have them assault your enemys. No matter how you want to play this game, you can find a way to win that is challanging and satisfying. With the 3 default races, and the 2 factions in each, you can find a race and faction that fits your play style.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
												Back in the day, when Sins of a Solar Empire first came out, it was already quite apparent that what Ironclad Studios had made was unique. Then the Entrenchment and Diplomacy expansions came and changed the game entirely for the better. Ironclad was content to let it be after that, but when a dedicated group of fans started churning out optimization mods, the Sins team took notice and decided to give us exactly what we needed: Rebellion! With a fully custumizable interface and with more than fifty high quality mods (not to mention the ability to create your own maps in the Galaxy Forge), Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion has some of the highest replayability factor in any game I've ever played. The online play is intense, and while there is the occasional crash or two per game, the real time tactics and deep character behind every aspect makes it more than worth playing through. If that's not enough for you, there are some excellent mods that can be easily installed. I would highly suggest using the E4X Mod, the Star Wars Interregnum Mod, and the Epic Scale Mod. However, if Star Wars isn't your thing, then you might be more interested in the various Star Trek, Babylon V, Stargate and Halo Mods! Nothing is impossible with this game; I've actally made a few private mods and skins myself, it's that simple. Next time it comes on sale, I highly suggest you buy it along with all of the DLC. You won't regret it.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
												A great game that combines real time combat with a stunning environment, in depth economy and diplomacy. Since the whole game takes place in real time it adds to the tension and fun of the game. Never gets boring.Edit:This game is very old, could even be considered a classic, but point being that it is one of those games that lasts for very long, an old game that people still love. This game is amazing, even now I would pay double for it, it is just amazing all things considered. To add to this there are some great mods out there (no workshop, mods are external), and the mods I have seen are some of the msot fun and dedicated I've ever seen, and I have used a lot of mods for a lot of games. Altogether, worth a buy anytime, even without sale, DLC isn't nesseccary to the game being great, but if you really wanna there's no downside to it.Altogether, amazing game

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 10, 2013
												Alright, after delving into it a bit, I've found the crashes i was experiencing were related to a bad install from steam, after a quick reinstall, the game seems to work as intended now.to those of you who enjoy a good RTS on a massive scale, It doesn't get much better than this. not only is the base game great, but there is a slew of mods to make this games replay value increase all the more.Some drawbacks... This game does NOT have multi-core support, and it does have native support for more than 2GB of ram. what does this mean? it means that later on in gameplay expect things to really slow down... and hoo boy does it start dragging if theres a alot going on... honestly this is the engines fault, and probably won't be addressed unless they make a sequel of the game on a new engine that can address these issues... i will say this, the game has been really optimized to make the most of the resources it can use, and in that, it gives me great hope for the sequel, as they will hopefully keep up with their resource efficiency and make a well polished game.Despite these massive drawbacks for performance, i believe the game itself outweighs the cons and is still very worthwhile to play. but like most massive RTS games, expect a game to last multiple sessions on bigger maps.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Welp, here goes my first review:Imagine a less complex Civilization, set in space where the main focus is warring the eff out of your enemies, and betraying your allies. There you go. Although you can indeed ally with another civ and win together, the possibility of they stabbing you behind your back is always there. With that interactivity in mind, add pretty graphics for a 2012 game, a handful of civilizations for you to try and master, it is a must for RTS players.Bear in mind though that it does not have a single-player campaign, neither an interactive tutorial.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2013
												I've played Sins since the original 1.0 retail release and I have to say.. I'm actually disappointed in this version.What you have to understand about Sins of a Solar Empire is the effort put into making a game in the style of other galactic empire builders but without the turnbased element which had turned off a large portion of gamers is an extremely ambitious endeavour which WAS delivered... and THAT was awesome! The idea of making a 4X game turnless is just.. mind boggling, enough to rival titles such as the X series in scope.Sins of a Solar Empire, Entrenchment and Diplomacy really upped the ante in each subsequent release and I always felt like they were advancing the gameplay significantly each time (though I always felt like the AI were becomming more and more subdued to the point of being pointless to learn from as 1.0 had very difficult AI that still allowed you to learn from them) to the benefit of the people wanting something new in each release... and then Rebellion was released.I was fairly unsure of what Rebellion would have instore for us: would it provide more ships and much more fine tuned balancing to the existing mix? Will we get more AI modes to play against? What about fixing up the research trees? and seriously, I never felt more let down. Where Sins 1 through to Trinity would allow the player to emmerse themselves into a fairly competitive environment and challenge them to find solutions to what could be a not so standard problem: Rebellion allows you to just spam your way to victory. Novel ideas introduced in the micro-expansions of Sins and in the Trinity pack are now just... a given.The Entrenchment micro expansion gave players the ability to fortify sectors under their control or even build seriously destructive weaponry inside an enemy gravity field to screw them over, there were other advancements but this was a serious turning point as before... there were methods to seriously improve defences for what could be otherwise defenseless zones and really just left some sectors as worthless.The Diplomacy micro expansion did for the diplomacy end of things that the entrenchment expansion did for defense options for each race and really allowed the player to use the economic empire they had build from the ground up to REALLY good use. The game of Sins of a Solar Empire really became a new beast with what had become the Trinity set (it was the game in the 3 incarnations, each separately loadable with the most uptodate version minus expansion content not in that version)Now we look at Retribution... we have 2 versions of each faction to make up a total of 6 playable 'factions'. We have a titan ship unique to each version of a faction as well as some different tech to research but largely remaining the same over all (except for certain faction only advantages which seriously skew the balancing, don't believe me? build 2 starbases to each system and deck them out with trade ports and watch your money grow incredibly fast.) and that's it... unless you buy the 'dlc' which include new system types, new colonizable planetoids/misc objects, random events, etc but the game didn't really CHANGE so much as become more convoluted.Titans are just capitol ships that cost more and have more abilities to learn at each level. Different 'factions' within a faction are the same damn thing with minor differences (rebel TEC can become friendly with rebels and incite rebellion on other worlds, loyalist Visari can strip a planet of resources for a big injection + leave the world dead and useless to all others) The only real differences comes for the Visari loyalists that can use their capitol ships as replacements for monetary income and research tiers.Rebellion felt like Trinity 3.5; Rebellion is just an addition to what trinity already had. I know Ironclad put a lot of effort into this title but it is so not worth the price margin considering the DLC is not free and the expansion on existing Sins stuff is fairly uninspiring. Play the game if you missed out on Trinity or don't mind playing current gen games but if you want a real challenge, something to test you over and over... play the Trinity set instead.

number of helpful: 7 of 17 people (41%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1
												Very superficial and monotonous game.  Also the overall look of everything -- space, planets, stations and ships -- is very generic and cheap.  Of course you could zoom waaaaay in to actually see them, but then you can't actually play.After you colonize a few planets and attacked a few ships, you've done 99% of all you'll ever do in this game.  Same thing over and over.  And you don't actually do anything; you don't place strategic buildings or resources really... you just press buttons, then everything is built automated.  (and the few defensive structures you build and strategically place are more or less worthless and make little difference)  REALLY boring and shallow.I bought this on sale for $14.99, wasn't worth it.  If this is how all these space 4X games are, the genre sucks.At least this gave me an itch to play my old Alpha Centauri.EDIT:  tried playing a few more hrs.  Yeah, this game sucks.  The various difficulty levels and the AI not following the rules of it's own game is another suck-factor.  (Either the factions do nothing, build nothing, and just sit there... or at higher difficulties they'll produce a massive amounts of ships and zerg spam you, far beyond what they're resources would allow.)Another Steam ripoff, due in large part to gushy fanois giving unwarrented positive reviews.  No more reading of Steam reviews for me.  Will look elsewhere, finding those who have actual standards.

content:
Posted: October 17, 2013
												If you like space combat, if you like strategy, or if you like just seeing explosions buy this game. I cannot recommend this enough ecspecially if you're a 4x strategy game fan like myself. Its got immense battles, an immense amount of tech and structures and a good AI to boot. Lets back up though, this is a "standered" space strategy you start out with one planet with a host of other planets to jump to and explore and colonize if you so choose in a universe with multiple galaxies to jump to if you so choose. You can build up massive fleets and defences and watch them clash with enemies in real time in what can be some massive battles (I would recommend a pretty good computer for this part though with a good amount of RAM otherwise those thousand ship battles can be sluggish). The modding community for this game is also amazing, from star wars to star trek to adding hundereds of different planets, ships, factions you name it its probably out there and there easy to download as well. So all in all just go and buy it please, if you like strategy at all you will not be dissapointed at all in this game.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2016
												If you're here because you're in the mood for a science fiction RTS, or Sins is on sale, let me dispense with the formalities and tell you straight out that this is one of the best, most intuitive and fun space RTS games ever.It's hard to believe it came out in 2008 -- the visuals have aged extraordinarily well, the UI is easy to navigate and easy to get used to, the units are responsive, and the research trees are deep, powerful and varied.There's no homogeneity here -- each race has unique ships with unique abilities and playstyles, and they each have research trees that emphasize their strengths. Certain lines of research are proprietary, meaning another race doesn't have an analog or way of replicating it, but you can be sure they have their own singular perks.The races also have different approaches to economy, space travel and fleet logistics. While the backbone of a dangerous Advent fleet is the Illuminator vessel with its devastating beam weapon, amplified by the synergistic effects of Advent's carrier capital ships, the heart of the TEC fleet is the JRM Missle frigate, protected by a front line of heavily-armored warships. Likewise, the Vasari appropriately feel more alien than the other two races, but they have proprietary stardrive tech that lets them cross vast distances quickly, and the ability to ramp up their economy quickly.With the updates (included), each race is further split into two factions each, providing a choice of six different races/ractions you can select from and fight. Additional updates added powerful starbases and more powerful defensive units, in addition to other features that have made the game deeper and more enjoyable.I've been playing Sins since it was released, and probably have a few hundred hours of play time aside from the 95 hours or so I've got on Steam. If you give Sins of a Solar Empire a chance, you'll get more than your money's worth -- and you'll certainly have some late nights as you tell yourself, "Just one more planet, one more capital ship, one more battle..."

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												This is a great sci-fi RTS game. I don't usually like RTS games because they are usually to frenetic for me, but this can have the construction, research etc all slowed down so you can take your time to make decisions and appreciate what is around. From what I have seen the enemy doesnt move that fast on normal difficulty which is perfect for me. The best bit about this game is the massive space battles you fight once you meet the enemy - they are very impressive and you can change to cinemagraphic view with one button click for some great screenshots. The only downsides to the game are that the frame rate can get a little slow in really large battles due to its 32bit structure, and that the Titans are a bit over the top. But it has fantastic GUI that makes managing large fleets a doddle, it is still going strong with plenty of players, some great mods (Star Wars and Star Trek ships for example) and interesting DLC.At the moment I would say its the best space strategy game on the market but such a shame the game engine struggles with very large amounts of ships.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2016
												I like the idea of this game, 4X mixed with RTS. But I just don't like this game, I wonder why.I hate double DRM, but it's not the reason.This game lacks a complete tutorial or campaign/story mode, but well it's OK, I normally only play a few campaign battles in RTS games, then only play skirmish once a while.As a 4X game, SOSE don't give you much time for planning. This game has a big tech tree, and in 4X games I usually take a few minutes to think about which tech direction I want to go at the beginning, but the realtime gameplay just doesn't let me. Well if you played a lot it could become as easy as muscle memory but still, if it is a 4X game, player should have some time for planning.Star development and ecnomics are simplified a lot compared to other 4X games. More like RTS: Build mining drones, improve the population, build factories, build defence platforms. And then, build as many ships as you can.Diplomacy seems totally broken. AI hates you at the beginning if you are a different faction. In most 4X games when you meet alien ship, the first thing is a greeting, but here when your fleet meet theirs, they just start firing at each other AUTOMATICALLY, and it hurts relationship. You have to research technology to communicate with AI, before that you may already at war, and even when you finished that technology and offer AI pacts and trades, they just laugh at you and refuse. The only thing you can do to improve relationship is complete their missions, which are usually to attack others, so there is actually no peace play. (If you don't complete them, relationship also gets worse) And AIs just gradually become friendly with each other, because they don't do missions.As a RTS game, SOSE's battle is very slow paced. It could take a minute to move from one star system to another, with normal game speed setting. And you can only move through certain lanes. So it could take minutes to send reinforcement, and when your fleet gets there the battle is already over.The fleet battles themselves also looks boring: you move fleets into a star system that has enemies there, and ships just automatically move to each other and start firing. You can control ship movement and manually choose target, but it doesn't help that much: Ship maneuver is super slow compared to projectiles and lasers attack range, you always fight in open space, and often get surrounded at the point you enter a star system. You can't see formations in traditional RTS games here, it's mostly just numbers and rock-paper-scissors that matters: You get more ships, you win. One ship type is stronger against another, you build right things, you win. Furthermore, you upgrade to more advanced tech and get more big ships, you win. Once the battle starts, you can only retreat your fleet, or watch the result. That's good if this is a pure 4X turn based game, but RTS elements are added in, and doesn't work as expected.The graphics isn't bad, it's quite good considering this is released some years ago. Problem is, you don't have chances to really see details like the screenshots above, if you're playing normally. You would take half your time watching the star map. Clicking on systems to build ships and upgrades. And another half, controlling your fleets moving from here to there, (and this can also be done in the star map interface) and micromanaging fleet battles. Even when you zoom into a star system to control your ships, they look as small as ants. Ship attack range is super long compared to their size, when you zoom in until you can see details, you can't do anything but only watching.Combining 4X and RTS looks like a good idea, but the 2 elements turn out to be conflicted with each other in many aspects. I think this game did its best, but I don't see it solves all the problems. It's like they put a simplified RTS and a simplified 4X together, and I can't enjoy either of them.

number of helpful: 9 of 22 people (41%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 5, 2014
												Bare graphical improvements over Sins: Trinity, but costs double the price.+ When on sale, it is usually $9.99. Not bad at first glance.- Pre-discount price is still the same as the launch price in 2012: $39.99 (for a small expansion added onto a game going back to 2008). A 75% discount only looks impressive because the price has never been adjusted.- Graphics and gameplay haven't been much improved from Trinity. It's an example of something old given a touch here and touch there, and repackaged and priced as something "new".- It has 'super-capital-class' (aka titan-class) ships that are overpowered and limit the gameplay. All roads lead to building a titan, whether you wanted to use one or not.- It doesn't truly have six factions; more like what should have been additional tech options for each original faction, got marketed to "hey, now you have double the number of factions".'Old Games, Same Debut Prices'Stardock is one of thousands of publishers on Steam that list their old games at ridiculous regular prices. When these overpriced games go on sale, the discount by themselves are high - 50%, 75% -  many of us get distracted by that percentage figure and buy old games at what should really be regular prices, but are advertised as "discounted prices".They have all the advantages (reduced costs, easier marketing, global distribution, greater profits) through Steam, selling copies upon copies of old hits that would receive little attention and garner little sales without this platform. But they do not change their prices from launch and profit even more greatly, all without offering any added value for  customers. I hope Steam's userbase becomes more tight with their wallets - it's the only way publishers that offer good value for their games (both old and new products) will benefit, while publishers who 'double dip' on cost savings and price gouging, will adapt.

												The base Sins of a Solar Empire game is very good and I highly recommend it. Unfortunately, most of the additions that came along with Rebellion detract from the otherwise fantastic 4x empire building experience. Late game is laregly about Titans instead of your capital ships and their support fleet, and the Titans are not especially fun or interesting to play with or against. To compound the problem, killing or losing a Titan is a temporary setback at best as it can be reconstructed again in short order with its level and upgrades intact. The graphics upgrade is nice, but overall, I strongly recommend buying Sins: Trinity instead of Rebellion.

content:
Posted: June 2, 2014
												As a big fan of 4X strategy games, I picked this up on a recommendation from a professor I had.  I've always wanted a really good space themed 4X that gives me a lot of options of play.  Sins of a Solar Empire is not what I was looking for.  The subtle nuances of each faction don't feel unique enough, the combat is fairly monotonous , and the games drag on for quite awhile for a real time game.  It's not a trainwreck by any means,  but it lacks the variety I was looking for.  If you are looking for a game that feels like you're building a galactic empire, this isn't it.  If you're looking for an RTS 4X hybrid then take what I have to say with a grain of salt, but I don't feel that the two genres mesh in an enjoyable way in this game.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2014
												The basics are solid, no bugs etc., although (for me) it felt a bit repetitive after the initial struggle. Take a system, establish yourself in the system, move onto the next system. I imagine that unless you and your friends have a fair amount of free time to do multiplayer matches, only being able to play against the AI provides somewhat limited entertainment.My real qualm is with how the game is advertised though. All of this backstory and lore doesn't really go anywhere. No solo campaign, nothing. And calling the game the "next installment"? It's an update, but one that you have to pay full price for, seeing as it's a standalone release. A real kick in the teeth for anyone who bought the original near or after the release of Rebellion, based on the advertising, and essentially bought the same game twice.

number of helpful: 3 of 10 people (30%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												Sins of a Solar Empire is a game that really feels like it should be good, and that I really want to be good. It has a ton of interesting mechanics, delivers solid space-4X gameplay, and has a lot of strategic depth. What really holds this game back is that there are a few annoyances (slow pace, takes a while to meaningfully interact with other players, minor UI annoyances, etc) and doesn't really excel at anything well enough to be a reason to play the game. If you like 4X gameplay Sins of a Solar Empire is a good addition to your roster and is one of the better space-based games in the genre, but if you're not a large fan of the genre there isn't any particular reason to pick this game up. You can become a rogue planet-devouring mob, so that's pretty cool.

												This game is one that just looks great, from the story line to the combat.  Unfortunately they substituted an infinitely boring tutorial for a campaign so the storyline stops at the intro video.  The combat unfolds into an incredibly slow paced snore.  This is good because you'll be needing all that time waiting for your ships to move an inch to read the explosive research menu that happens to be in no way intuitive and absolutely necessary for victory.  The research is also unique for each race so you'll be spending most of your time in this game reading what things do in this one menu, this one menu, this one menu, this one menu, this whole game is based on this one fing menu. What the f guys?  Want to build a media hub?  Thats simple, just click this button that is nowhere to be found nor is there a suggestion as to where it can be found.  In the hour it took you to find it, your ships have moved 4 whole inches only for the enemy you were chasing to warp away.  Figure out that one menu?  If you did, you got more suprises in store!  Suddenly the enemy ships have 150% hp, so u use that one menu again to research a new ship that looks vaguely competitive.  Its not.  If you get them good, they warp away.  Excercise in futility.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2016
												I bought this game thinking it was going to be a similar experience to Planetary Annihilation. I was so Gaben-ly wrong. I'm not going to evaluate the whole game because I couldn't even get that far into it before I became frustrated. I bought it at a discount Weight and got the 4 Gaben bundle. I can't even give it away because of the painstakingly long gameplay that everyone else seems to be aware of. I'm 13 hours in and I still have no grasp of the game. Even worse, an average game lasts 3-4 hours at regular speed and I have yet to claim honest victory to a single match, let alone completed one. The damage types (or labeling) are different in each faction which makes it hard to compare and the values switch positions from one unit to the next. Their counter for it? All units automatically prioritize targets even if you direct the next attack. There are some cool things about this game which will keep me from giving it a 3/10 or less but I'm so sick of the drawn out matches and time wasted that I don't even want to elaborate and waste any more time writing a review on it. User-friendly will never describe this game. I honestly don't see myself playing it again. EDIT:Since these cult followers feel the need to comment on my review as if I'm stupid rather than letting the numbers speak for themselves (since this game does uphold a very high review status), I figured I would go into more detail about why I don't like the game:░░░░░░░░░░░█▀▀░░█░░░░░░░░░░░░▄▀▀▀▀░░░░░█▄▄░░░░░░░░░░█░█░░░░░░░░░░▐░░░░░░░░░▐▐░░░░░░░░░▄░▐░░░░░░░░░█░░░░░░░░▄▀▀░▐░░░░░░░▄▀░░░░░░░░▐░▄▄▀░░░░░░▄▀░░░▐░░░░░█▄▀░▐░░░░░░░█░░░▐░░░░░░░░▄░█░░░░░░░░█▄░░▀▄░░░░▄▀▐░█░░░░░░░░█▐▀▀▀░▀▀▀▀░░▐░█░░░░░░░▐█▐▄▄░░░░░░░░▐░█▄▄░░░░░▀▀▄▄▄▀░S░░░░░▐▄▄▄▄▀░░░░░░░░░░░ins░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░Rebellion░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░  Tutorials,  ░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░ Campaign,  ░░░░░░░░░░░░░░ and Tech Tree ░░░░░░░░ And I'll bump up my rating since I was a bit sour when I initially wrote this.You're welcome.5/10 for being a finished and cool looking product and not a pay2play game

content:
Posted: December 14, 2015
												I love this game so much, so why am I giving it a negative review? Well the game in and of itself is fantastic, I would have loved the game to death if not for one issue: The Game Runs like Absolute Trash.This might not be extremelly noticeable at the begining or when you play on small maps against  1 to 2 opponents, however on bigger maps with many foes, the game starts to run like a slideshow after 4 hours. Concurrently in a game in a large galaxy with 5 other opponents about 6 hours in, the average fps which I am getting is around 8. Not exactly acceptable.So why is this? Does my computer just suck? No. Its because the game is not at all optimized well for 64-bit systems. The game can only access 2 gigabytes of your ram and for me uses only about 15% of my processing power on average. With mods such as the Large Adress Aware you can make the game use  3 gigs instead of 2, which will give you a couple of frames, but maybe for like an hour after that it will drop to hell again as the sizes of fleets of the AI increase. Conclusion:- Later in Games it runs like a slideshow, if you dont mind the mindblowingly low fps, its a fantastic game in every other respect, in fact possibly my favorite RTS of all time. Save yourself the pain of having to abandon this masterpiece due to the broken performance and buy some other game.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2012
												Real-time 4X strategy with equally deep choices for warfare, diplomacy, and colonization. I haven't played since vanilla but the expansions have added tons onto the base game including: starbases (death stars that can effectively control uncolonizable sectors), "Titan" class ships, new research trees, restructured diplomacy, improved victory conditions, deeper piracy options, more difficulty settings, tons of new maps and map sizes, and who knows what else I haven't discovered yet.Rebellion contains all the previous expansions and new content. I played vanilla Sins for hundreds of hours before it came out on Steam and probably will sink many more into this. I mean, it's basically Civ in space, you should really go play it.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												This game looks good in the video and description, but the actual game is a different matter.The tutorials are unintuitive and don't explain the concepts in detail, and there is no single player campaign, nor any kind of mission or scenario. As far as I can tell you can't even make your own missions. When I tried playing against the A.I., I found that the random sub factions (they have faction labels but don't count as actual factions, so you can't do anything about them) were a lot  more of a threat than the a.i. at the beginning. As you build up your planets and colonize new ones I continuesly got attacked by pirates, despite the fact that the bounty system for controlling them should have made them only attack my enemies, having a 1000 credit bounty on them and none on me. The description of the faction I chose to play as also has in its abilities that it has a peace treaty with the neutral and pirate fleets. TO top it all off, the pirate base was much closer to my enemies than it was to me, but only I seemed to be targeted.Over time that one base grew far more powerful than my entire empire, and had no ship or resource resrictions like I did, making it impossible for me to amass the forces to defeat them. I have never played such an unblanced game before.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2015
												Not what I was expecting.Billed as a fusion between RTS gameplay and 4X Gameplay, I was stoked.  But while the gameplay was fine, I was a bit put off that the only choice I had right out the box for Singleplayer was to basically just choose what type of map I wanted to play on, and how big it was.  I played Trinity first, then this one, but neither gave me much to do when it came to this place's universe.  Civilization can get away with no ongoing story campaign because that story, at least, is already written, and it's fun to see how much any Civilization game with its familiar faces diverges from our own history.  When it comes to a Sci-Fi universe, when there's a blank slate to work with, I'd expect more attempts on the game's part to engage me when it comes to caring about the fate of whoever it is I am playing, but Sins of a Solar Empire disappointingly seems to prefer more of a Sandbox approach.Maybe I completely missed the point here... but I just plain can't recommend this game to anyone looking for a good solo experience.  Maybe give it a try if you know you've got a group of interested friends, or if you REALLY love playing against random strangers.  But for anyone else, you're probably better off passing on this.

												Hi. To be honest I bought this game because of the really good reviews, so I thought it must be a really good game and actually I'm quite disappointed with it. My only advice is to download first Sins of Solar Empire Demo. It is slightly different to Rebellion but you definitely will have a taste of the game and if you like the demo you will like the full game. Otherwise just forget about this game and move on the the different one.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2014
												In my honest opinion Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion is a biggest waste of money so far. Let me tell you why.It's a type of RTS with many features, it's not simple, there's a lot of text to read, which itself is of course not a con. The problem is, that the font is unreadable. Bold letters with almost no spacing between them makes the eyes struggle to read the words. I was forcing myself to play the game in hope i will get used to it. Then the gameplay issues came. Many pointless actions to make while they could be much simplier. To select groups of units you have to zoom out, using the hold&draw option doesn't seem to work as you would think it should. Moving to different planets is also pain in the *ss, why it is not as simple as selecting and clicking the other planet? Half of the game is Zoom out/Zoom in/Zoom out/Zoom in either to do something or see something.Maybe I could use to that someday.. Maybe I would like it.. but I didn't make it that far, it is just too painful and that's where the game fails as entertainment.

content:
Posted: May 7, 2013
												Good visuals and the only real 4x RTS on the market thanks to the current trends (console crowd, I'm looking at you). Other than that, horrid balance, pathfinding and AI, not a big mp crowd on the net. Good for skirmish and mods mostly.If you are into few tactics and many useless abilities, constant patching that breaks the balance even further, ridiculously powerful units that will negate your last two hours of effort in building fleet and defences by some magic gimmicky bs, this is definately for you.It is a step back (a giant leap for a mankind, though) from gems like Homeworld or any good 4xTBS, but there is nothing else on the market that would actually run without constant crashing or at least would try to represent 4x space srategy, so I give it a "thumbs up".The great amount of lore written for this title is wasted, because the game is watered down for multiplayer, so it feels hollow. And since you'd using the same tactic in MP over and over again until a new patch will change it only slightly, you will always win, because if the tactic works literally nothing can beat it. Even the Necrons in early Dark Crusade were more balanced, at least you could win against them if you really tried, here any other tactic except the winning few is useless. No strategic flexibility make this hardly a strategy game.You want a good in-depth strategy experience? Play Supreme Commander.Or better yet, find yourself a copy of Homeworld : Cataclysm or maybe Master of Orion.

content:
Posted: April 6, 2014
												There are better empire building games.I spent a long time looking for something new to play and I have to say, I'm quite disappointed. The game has its fans and plenty of decent reviews, but for me, it fails on several fronts. 'Galactic Civilizations', 'Haegmonia:Legions of Iron' or 'Star Wars: Empire at War' will offer a better single player experience. ( I haven't played it multiplayer)Complex Diplomacy: good & badFleet Management: poorPlanet management: simpleShip classes and tech tree offer nothing newThe diplomacy is new compared to most games on the market. You have to research new options, use planets/starbases to expand influence or send envoy ships to boost good will. But by the tme you've got round to reseaching all those options chances are you'll already be banging heads with the neighbours.Fleets battles are not very fluid to control. Ships can be controlled either by grouping 1-9, specific fleet icons in the command bar, or zooming in at low level. But to select individual ships can be difficult and I found the command interface jumps around too much. Again its difficult to check how much health each ship has. Against lower levels of AI even a small fleet of Capital ships will win most battles.'Homeworld 2', 'Nexus: The Jupiter Incident' or even 'Star Wars: Empire at War' to me, offer better fleet simulators. Not much of an Empire game when your planet construction is limited to two types of Mining Facilities, Two types of shipyard (frigates and capital) and a trading post. Then a small mix of defences and a titan depot. The research tree handles some benefits, but the planetary shield only defends against super weapon blasts and soon fails against a small group of frigates.'Galactic Civ' 'SW: Empire at War' and the 'Total War' series can offer a better planet/city management.The ships range from Corvette, Frigate, Crusier, Capital, Titan (1 max). The amount you can have is limited by 2 reseachable upgrades that boost 'commanders' (needed for capital and titan) and 'supply' that limits you overall fleet size. Titans need 2 commanders and 150 supply, a frigate 0 commanders and 6 supply. Each ship has special abilites, a Torpedo/missile crusier, a heavy hitter, repair.  No stealth abilites though. The capital ships gain experience and unlock extra skills, so you need a mixed bag to win, but similarly just build a lot of big guns and you usually can still win. Coupled with the low survivability and skills of the smaller classes, once you start building big ships, frigates are redundant, and there isn't enough depth to the sytem to micromange the ships properly.

												Hi first of all,I do not hate this game, and it was a hard choise for me not to reccomend this.first of lets start at what this game does right.1 the game has nice grapichs. 2 fun gameplay. 3 intense battles.those are a few of the key things the game does right. but it can be hard at times.the game has you focus on stratagy more then anything else. witch makes it hard. I only recomend this game if you plan to play online with friends.what this game does wrong.1 No singleplayer campain. 2 games can take to long (not neseserly a bad thing. but can be really anoying if you dont have a lot of time to play.)3 Diplomacy is really bad.I did not like this game becouse there was no singleplayer campain. witch was a real downer for me, as you dont get to know why the races battle eachotther. or who they are to begin with.so you dont form a real connection with the races that are in the game.also sometimes the games take to long, even 1vs1 matches. can take you 2 hours. depending on map.it is not a bad thing. but when you have limited time to play can be fustrating,diplomacy is bad, I never got a computer ai to join me the best I got was trade. but then they suddently attack me.even when I trew tons of credits and recources to them. they never became friendly. or when doing their quests.this was reall annoying,so if you want to play with comp allies simply choose, locked teams. and add one to your team best thing to do.that was my review thanks for reading.hope it was helpful.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												THIS GAME HAS NO SINGLE PLAYER CAMPAIGN. ALL YOU CAN DO IS SKIRMISH AGAINST THE COMPUTER OR PLAY MULTIPLAYER WHICH TAKES FOREVER.^That's not the only reason you shouldn't buy this piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥game though. There's a whole lot of game mechanics that don't work as advertised, or are just annoying as hell. For example, if you are playing against all computer opponents and the pirate faction is "on" then trying to place money for a bounty on a CPU player in order to make the pirates leave you alone never ever works because the CPU players are programmed to spend twice as much to have the pirates come and attack you, and they will place the money to do it just a second before the pirates go active. It's completely broken and shouldn't be a part of the game. There are some things you simply can't toggle off, however. The worst example is superweapon spam by CPU players. And no, I shouldn't have to go download a mod that someone else made in order to fix it. That's the game studio's responsibility.The game also takes a LONG time to play a single skirmish or a game with your friends.The only pro I can think of for this game is that a bunch of enterprising modders have made some incredible overhauls for this game like Star Wars and Star Trek. But there again, Stardock doesn't get the credit. The base game you are buying sucks. SUCKS. Do not buy.

												It's too difficult for my taste. I've played 4X's and RTS's quite a bit, but combining them and giving the player a highly unhelpful tutorial, adding extremely complicated processes to everything, and making me pull my own hair out after five minutes in game, only made me hate this one instead of love it. I've requested a refund, and do not plan to touch any of the other Sins games.And before someone decides to berate me: Yes, I looked up a beginner's guide. It didn't help me one bit, as what the tutorial had 'tought' me had decided to completely fail to stick. I even went to YouTube and watched some videos. Not one of them helped either, as everything was too fast-paced for me to keep up with.Basically: This game may not be your cup of tea, especially if you really don't want to spend the next twenty-four hours or so just trying to wrap your brain around just the interface.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2016
												TL:DR;If you are looking for extensive, in-depth 4X type of the game, turn back. This isn't it.Disbelieve all reviews that claim it is epic space strategy like a MoO or something. It's notReview:Sins of a Solar Empire is time and resource management RTS focused primarily on multiplayer.There is no single campaign, only skirmishes.As the game focused in this area it lacks depth pretty much everywhere. Pros:Good graphics.Different factions, ships, techs.Average sound.Overall faction balance, except pirates.Cons:Everything else. Really.- Shallow, silly research trees. - Limits on the space construction in the system.- AI cheats- no Single player campaign- dumbest achievements ever- overpowered pirate faction- ridiculous maps- very severe limits on the amounts of ships in game- price, DLC prices- very clunkly and messy UI. I had to lover resolution on 24" display to be able to read fonts and see icons from a meter away!- diplomacy, totally pointless and confusing as hellConclusion:This is a game for quick online skirmishes, and if this is your thing, go ahead buy it.But if you are like me, fan of strategies with deep elements and ability to manage and plan and conduct spying and diplomacy missions, this simply is not your game.For me, it's money wasted :(

content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
												I really enjoy space rts games like sins. Unfortunatley the game cheats blatantly. if you play against anything other than the normal opponent (aka so easy i beat 8 opponents without losing one capital or even taking any planetary damage) almost all of the opponents will team up and attack at the same time. which is ok it makes it challenging, but for races at war why are 6 of the 8 computer players teaming up on one team??? if you are to drive them back and defend the game finds other ways to screw you. i have played many skirmish games in sins and when you start to beat the computer it will do things like speed up all the enemy ships... all of them, their fire rate goes up and my favorite which happened again today the game will halt all of your ships or let them move very very slowly to defend a world and only let your ships go one at a time and in order of weakest to strongest. what the ♥♥♥♥?? my titan arrived to warp first. all of my other ships caught up and jumped starting with my carriers. then once my first capital ship died my titan finally began charging up to warp... all of my ships were ungrouped and my titan was about 2 minutes ahead of the rest of them. this game has stupid bugs that the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ developers need to fix. hard is fun cheating to this point makes a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ game.

number of helpful: 16 of 44 people (36%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												Well, unlike perhaps most gamers here I think SoaSE can absolutely not hold a candle to MOO2 (Master of Orion 2 Battle at Antares, a 4x turn-based space-strategy game from 1996! ). When starting the game and during the first 10 minutes or so it´s fun to play. The maps are large, you have to scout and to think which building to build next and so on. But: SoaSE just seems to offer more fluent gameplay due to being real time. But the more planets you conquer, the more gameplay grinds to a stop. Since your fleet supply is quite limited, you can only support 2 larger fleet groups and spend most of the time "hyperjumping" between systems looking for a weak spot in the enemys defense. This hyperjumping also being real time makes it a boring experience. Because there is no campaign but mere "missions" or sandbox gameplay, I can only recommend this game for multiplayers when it´s on sale. I have played SoaSE Rebellion and all it´s predecessors, always hoping the next title would be THE ONE that can get near to MOO2...  but I was disappointed all the time in the end.

number of helpful: 6 of 25 people (24%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												This game is just trash plain and simple, who the hell thought it would be a good idea to take a connect the dots RTS Ala Nano war or hyperpath (Which are both better games & free might I add) Then make it needlessly complex while simultaneously taking all entertainment out of it.The game pacing is dreadful, some games take over 200 hours to finish, I swear building my own space armada would be faster. This is not a game where time flies whilst playing like a good strategy game like Civ V or Age of empires, the sensation one gets from playing is much like waiting in a hospital, let this represent the high point of entertainment you get out of this game.Selling this game or any game for that matter based off of 99% cinematic trailers should be banned as they don't even serve to tell story (Which really there isn't any for this 'Game') This is not a game but an exercise in human will, to what length will 'Fans' go to pretend that they actually get any sense of enjoyment out of this god-awful rip-off of a game, this game is not worth the physical space a digital copy would take up let alone your money.Avoid it at all costs if you value your sanity and will to live.This game makes the steam refund policy deserve a rewrite.PS: Stardock/Ironclad don't post reviews on your own product it just looks bad and only serves to strengthen my arguments of the game being an overhyped piece of garbage.(It is also consumer fraud as stated in the comments section, the deletion of such is potential spoilation of evidence.)PSS: If any developer wishes to confront me, do it directly my messaging me on steam.Edit: Anybody who downvotes this without commenting is just proving my point and being part of the problem that is complete and total alienation of the consumer.

number of helpful: 2 of 24 people (8%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 12
												The game is dated. Very dated. Extremely dated. How dated? The orignal game came out in 2008, and even after it became clear that the stats were lacking, the engine was never rebuilt. This game is so dated that at the time, they figured that, despite supporting mods, it would never need to use more than 2 GB of RAM. Rebellion was built as an expansion, using the same engine. These days, the game has been adjusted for modern RAM usage: it can now use 4 GB of RAM. As a result, graphics can be potentially better. Last I heard, Stardock was still facing legal challenges in various countries, so who knows if or when a Sins 2 will be released.In the meantime, this game is being milked for the last little bit of money that can be obtained from it. The Pricing of the "Ultimate Edition" being pushed in some places is a joke. The paid DLC content is something you can easily live without, because someone with a mod has probably already done it. ModDB is the place to check for mods that actually work.All that said, it's a fine old game for its time, with a value of perhaps $20, as a pack, all expansions included. It is NOT a $40 game. DO NOT BUY THIS UNLESS IT GOES ON SALE FOR A SIGNIFICANT PRICE REDUCTION! Just don't. If you can get it for more than 1/2 off (like a 66% sale) buy it then. If you can get it on GOG.com, DRM free (don't try to work the Steam Sync BS), then buy it there instead.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 18, 2014
												A 4X title where you play the role of one of three factions looking for galactic domination in a three way war. This is generally done by killing off the other factions but can be done in a variety of ways such as sending pirates to mess with their planets constantly, spreading your cultural influence and causing rebellions or just blowing their fleets and structures up with massive fleets and/or superweapons. The game itself looks stunning with every ship model looking amazing even when you can have hundreds of these things flying around and in all shapes and size from the tiny Cobalt light frigate to the massive Ankylon titan.Only downsides are there isn't a huge amount of players playing due to the fact that games can take a huge amount of time and it can lag quite badly with just the sheer mass of ships flying around. However if you can overcome these problems, this is a great way to spend a day with friends or just to kill some hours off. 9/10.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 17, 2014
												I give this game a solid 7.5/10.  As far as RTS games go, this one has a lot of customization options that allow you to tweak it to your liking.  I bought it on sale and am glad I did, because for the full price I would have been let down a bit but simultaneously it fulfills that RTS need in my gaming collection better than any other I've ever played.  Pro/Con as follows:Pro:Great look, its amazing to zoom into the battle and see ship fleets just tearing each other up.  Micro is there, and you'll be rewarded for your skill, but its not as in your face as SC and other RTS games I've played before.  Macro in this game is a big part and most of what you'll use as the empire you build can be enormous.There are tons of maps to play, making the game very replayable and exciting.6 somewhat unique races that carry specific abilities to fit your style of play (might i suggest picking one and sticking with it until you understand the game)AI can be set to your liking and believe me, it delivers if you so choose it to.  Downright nasty even.Con:Battles can be so long. Honestly, even a 1v1 match can take more than an hour.  You'll definetely be saving and continuing at a later date with this game more often than not.  Not many people I would think have the time for large 50+ planet battles in one sitting.Huge learning curve if you've never played the Sins of a Solar Empire games, took me several days to even understand what I was doing.  Do the tutorials as many times as need be, it'll save you time in the long run.Maps are diff sizes, you can pick how big the map is and therefore roughly decide how long the battle will be, but know that most of the maps are bigger maps, and I feel the games just take too long.  The complexity of the game favors those that keep at it.  Just a little here and a little there won't cut it.  Those that practice their strategies and stick with their fav race will end up becoming extremely talented while those that play here and there will be left in the dust in online play due to the sheer amount of content you as an empire builder must be keeping track of at all times.  You've been warned.Music is annoying.  Turned it off within the first few hours.In closing, this game has so much to offer.  Those that want a very complex, high maintenance empire will love it.  Again, overall its a very good RTS game that I enjoy and it fulfills that role in my gaming collection extremely well, however, its not worth as much as they're charging at full price, sale price is where its at.  And I can't stress enough: make sure when you start a battle online that you've got some serious time on your hands.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												I'm not a huge strategy game fan, and I'm not very good at them. The reason I love this game is that it comes closer than any other game I've played to making me feel as if I'm leading an interstellar civilization in its conquest of the stars. There are games with better content, more variety, more control, more realism-- but this game just has the feel. I think that comes from the fact that it is real-time and your units are all fully rendered with their own individual positions and ranges, etc... You have to think about the battles as real events where every variable has to be considered, rather than a combat system that plays out more predictably with probabilities and numbers making all the difference. The other thing that creates this sense of authenticity is the camera. The camera can be seamlessly zoomed from a map of the entire galaxy down to an individual fighter craft. This makes the game feel as if it has real things in a world, and not pieces on a game board. While people still play this game in multiplayer, it can be hard to get a match going, and hard to keep everyone playing for the 8 or so hours it can take to finish a match-- and it can take much longer if you want! When you do get one going though, it can be pretty glorious. Playing offline with the AI is very enjoyable though. This game has lots of options when setting up a match and you can create all kinds of interesting scenarios for yourself. There is no campaign mode though, so players will need to be self-directed. The variety of gameplay is further increased by a map editor, random maps, and mod support. I would recommend this game to: someone who wishes starcraft was in space and on a grander scale; someone who wants a streamlined 4x game with lots of action; someone who wants to lead vast space armies in their conquest of the stars. If you're looking for the end-all be all of micromanagement and simulation you might be dissapointed. If you have the itch for epic space battles however, this game will surely scratch it.
