Posted: June 16, 2014
												One of the grandest scale RTS games out there, it plays like a larger version of Star Wars: Empire at War with increased micromanaging and interactions between factions. It runs reasonably well on mid-grade systems with smaller maps, though the sheer scale of larger campaigns will bog down all but the most powerful machines. Unlike SW:EaW there is no ground component, so defend your planets carefully as you won't have the opportunity to repel invasion once the system falls to enemy naval forces.Great if you have a friend to play it with, but the games tend to run too long to just find a match online and play it. Be prepared to sink five hours into a medium campaign or even more into a larger one.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 12, 2012
												"A very suprising game. Definitely a good purchase, spent quite a few hours in the game and had fun playing against AI. Can't wait to get better at this game and play some online some time."This was my original review when I only had clocked a few hours of game time. After having played more games I would definitely recommend this game to this anyone who is fan of the RTS or 4X genre. The strong points of the game come in the form of great research trees, wonderful diplomacy aspects and an interesting pirate mechanic. There are 3 seperate research paths for each race, with some unique upgrades to each race. Diplomacy has to researched in the respected research path, with the ability to offer pacts and agreements to other players. The pirate system in the game works by having a neutral race (which can be toggled on and off) attack the player with the highest bounty on their head, this often leads to bounty war in order to get the pirates attention off you and onto the enemy. One of the downsides to the game is that each game takes an eon to complete. We can be talking hours to finish a medium to large game.Overall I would highly recommend this game to anyone who is interested in Sci-Fi RTS games.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 16, 2014
												From an RTS fan to other gamers, this is one of the best Sci-Fi RTS games out there! If you don't have it yet, you must add it to your collection.Sins of a Solar Empire's story is that the Humans (Trade Order, Trader Emergency Coalition) was living in a millennia of peace where the only ''real combat'' was light skirmishes with pirates and such, until a menace called the Vasari arrived and began exterminating Human worlds one by one, until, of course, the Humans converted their vast trading fleet into a military asset. The new fleet held the Vasari back until a long forgotten enemy - the Advent - arrived back and stormed the other side of the TEC colonies and that's about it. The three sides have been at war for decades.The story for Sins of a Solar Empire could be a lot longer, but it's gameplay is fantastic! You research new technologies using materials like credits, metals and crystals, and to unlock new ships you must research their hull design and then build them using the appropriate shipyard. There are multiple types of Capital ships in the game, ranging from a Battleship and Battlecruiser to a massive Dreadnought that can annihilate planets.The smaller ships are also of different type. The most basic frigate is a light frigate, a multi-purpose combat vessel that serves as the bulk of ANY fleet in the game. The light frigates can be supported with support frigates, like ones equipped with Flak cannons or planetary bombardment frigates. Then come the cruisers. The cruisers are heavier, more durable ships than the frigates, but are still divided into support roles and combat roles. The heavy cruisers are close-range combatants that close the distance between the ships and fire with their punishing close-range weapons. The support cruisers include light carriers, starbase constructors, diplomatic envoys and command cruisers.Light carriers, as the name implies, are smaller than the carriers in the game and they are lightly armed, however, when in bulk, their swarm of fighters can chew down even a small fleet of enemy ships. Starbase constructors are ships that assemble the mighty starbases - outposts of your empire that can serve as military superstructures in orbit around your planets, distant trading outposts or as an auxiliary government. The diplomatic envoys are ships used to establish and improve relations with other factions and they are unarmed and lightly protected. Command cruisers are ships used to improve fire coordination among the ships of a fleet. It can increase accuracy to all ships, but they do not sport heavy guns themselves. Only ones used to protect against fighters and bombers.The game also has a diplomacy aspect of the game. Relations in the game are improved using the envoy-type ships. When the relations between factions are ''warm'' enough, both sides can establish treaties among themselves and eventually form an alliance.All in all, the game is a wonder in today's gaming world.P.S. If you don't like the vanilla game, you can apply mods to it. For Halo fans out there - there is a Halo mod called ''Sins of the Prophets''.

Posted: June 19, 2014
												Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion doesn't fundamentally change the series; however, it brings together the concepts developed in the trinity that came before it and prefects them. Each faction feels unique, with both strengths and weakness. Take the galaxy with an armada of capital ships, use swarms of fighters and bombers, or dig in with giant defense stations and slowly advance through cultural domination; the choice is yours. Sins of a Solar Empire is a fast, intuitive, and beautiful RTS that shouldn't be passed up by anyone interested in the genre.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												I really enjoy 4x strategy games.  While I am usually more focused on the turn based 4X games this game really appeals to me for 2 reasons.  The research mechanics are still there and are timed like most RTS games however the tech tree is vast and I find myself changing my tech tree choices from game to game, rather than falling to a single pointed strategy each time.  The only downside I can really see if that the UI (particularly the empire overview) can be very hard to follow for a new player.  Another downside is that Combat is slow and battles seem to lumber on.  While I don't see that interfering with my enjoyment I can see how that migh prevent some people from enjoying the combat.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
												One of the best games I have ever played, and most definitely the most impressive space based RTS/4X game I've ever had the joy of playing. Stunning visuals and solid gameplay make this game a must have.This game is made great for any playstyle, with versatile early game units to quickly rush your opponents, and beefy end game starships for trully epic encounters and turtling. For those with quick fingers and reflexes, every single unit has some kind of ability that is great when auto-cast, but even better when manually timed making micro a viable option. On the other hand, by late game you can bunch up a ton of poweful units and capital ships with abilities on auto-cast to make short work of any traget or fleet of any size.The three factions are balanced to a key. The Vasari are built around hit-and-running lightly defended planets, and completely strip mining less useful planets. The Advent are good for more tactical and micro-managerial attacks, relying on shields and debuffs to overpower opposing fleets. The TEC are built around smashing bulky and heavily armed and armored ships against even the strongest defenses and fleets while remaining safe behind powerfull starbases. On top of that, each faction is split into a Loyalist and Rebel faction creating even more diversity with six different abilities and ultra-ships, the titans.With solid action-filled gameplay and thought out lore (found mainly in the research you do) this game will provide a satisfying experience for anyone; casual or skill-based, turtling or rushing, fast or slow, strategy and action, visually and technically it is one of the best investements in a game you can make.

												A fantastic game that will give you hours and hours of enjoyment, this includes all of the previous games and expansions for this 4X-lite series. Epic space battles and armadas and strategy on a multi-galactic scale, the only slight problems I have with this title are the fact that there's very little micro-management (so don't be expecing a 200 APM Stracraft 2-alike) and the research trees are a little bit lopsided. However, if you want a game with tactical thinking, a strong cast of 3 different races and some truly brilliant in-game systems as well as some very, very pretty graphics (just watch a battle unfold!), then look no further. For fans of the sci-fi RTS genre, I wholeheartedly recommend this title.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 16, 2014
												From an RTS fan to other gamers, this is one of the best Sci-Fi RTS games out there! If you don't have it yet, you must add it to your collection.Sins of a Solar Empire's story is that the Humans (Trade Order, Trader Emergency Coalition) was living in a millennia of peace where the only ''real combat'' was light skirmishes with pirates and such, until a menace called the Vasari arrived and began exterminating Human worlds one by one, until, of course, the Humans converted their vast trading fleet into a military asset. The new fleet held the Vasari back until a long forgotten enemy - the Advent - arrived back and stormed the other side of the TEC colonies and that's about it. The three sides have been at war for decades.The story for Sins of a Solar Empire could be a lot longer, but it's gameplay is fantastic! You research new technologies using materials like credits, metals and crystals, and to unlock new ships you must research their hull design and then build them using the appropriate shipyard. There are multiple types of Capital ships in the game, ranging from a Battleship and Battlecruiser to a massive Dreadnought that can annihilate planets.The smaller ships are also of different type. The most basic frigate is a light frigate, a multi-purpose combat vessel that serves as the bulk of ANY fleet in the game. The light frigates can be supported with support frigates, like ones equipped with Flak cannons or planetary bombardment frigates. Then come the cruisers. The cruisers are heavier, more durable ships than the frigates, but are still divided into support roles and combat roles. The heavy cruisers are close-range combatants that close the distance between the ships and fire with their punishing close-range weapons. The support cruisers include light carriers, starbase constructors, diplomatic envoys and command cruisers.Light carriers, as the name implies, are smaller than the carriers in the game and they are lightly armed, however, when in bulk, their swarm of fighters can chew down even a small fleet of enemy ships. Starbase constructors are ships that assemble the mighty starbases - outposts of your empire that can serve as military superstructures in orbit around your planets, distant trading outposts or as an auxiliary government. The diplomatic envoys are ships used to establish and improve relations with other factions and they are unarmed and lightly protected. Command cruisers are ships used to improve fire coordination among the ships of a fleet. It can increase accuracy to all ships, but they do not sport heavy guns themselves. Only ones used to protect against fighters and bombers.The game also has a diplomacy aspect of the game. Relations in the game are improved using the envoy-type ships. When the relations between factions are ''warm'' enough, both sides can establish treaties among themselves and eventually form an alliance.All in all, the game is a wonder in today's gaming world.P.S. If you don't like the vanilla game, you can apply mods to it. For Halo fans out there - there is a Halo mod called ''Sins of the Prophets''.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												This is an amazing game. It's great for playing with your friends, and for skirmishes with the AI. Unfortunately that's all there is to this game. Multi-Player and Skirmishes. There is no campaign, and that in itself is very disappointing. But don't let that put you off from buying it. It's gorgeous, challenging, entertaining, and loads of fun (albeit a bit difficult at times). Unlike Endless Space and Galactic Civilizations, Sins is real time. So every split second decision counts. The AI is a juggernaut of difficulty no matter what setting you have it on, so every little plan makes the difference of success or failure. Unless you're a master of strategy, this game will frustrate you at times. One moment you're blasting away at the galaxy, the next moment there are Titans coming at you from every angle.There are lots of different research topics for each and every civ you choose, and each one is vastly different than the others. Ship options are quite large, and every ship has it's own abilities and strategic usefulness. The buildings have a build limit, until you start to expand your empire. Each new planet adds new resource bonuses, building caps, tech options, etc.Unlike games like Age of Empires, Sins sort of forces you to expand and explore, otherwise you won't get the necessary amount of buildings certain research items require, the resources needed to build massive fleets, and so on. You also can't just sit around and let your stockpiles grow, build a battalion of ships, and expect to win in one attack. You'll soon learn that the enemy has already colonized 4 planets, each with it's own armada, and enough spare ships on it's way to wipe out your home planet.Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion is an awesome experience, and a very challenging one. If you like that sort of thing, you will absolutely love this game. The only disappointing thing about this game is the lack of a campaign. Everything else is a work of genius, a real masterpiece. I highly recommend any RTS lover to buy this game right away.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												Awesome 4X RTS. Imagine an entire solar system at war... Fleets of Frigate and Capital class duking it out in the gravity well of a planet... The surface of a planet being scoured with nuclear fire... Solid shot, missiles, lasers, plasma bolts and particle beams zigzagging accross the void of space. This is Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion.A must have if you love space RTS with an excellent selection of balanced races, ships, space and planetary improvements to constuct. Starting out from a single undeveloped planet, you expand and conquer your way through entire solar systems with the help of industry, technology and lots of big ships and guns of course... There are also nice diplomacy features which can really cement and improve your standing amongst the allies you definitely will need to create the foundation of your space empire (remember to keep your friends close, but your enemies closer).  I must also fondly mention the Starbase aspect (mostly static super defensive structures) and Titan Class ship (unique super ships) which really turns the late game into quite a battle for domination.I heartily recommend this game to anyone who wishes to sit for 4 hours playing a game without actually noticing the time going by... because they are having a blast (or too busy watching a planet getting scoured by dozens of nukes (or orbital laser weapons) ;-) )

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 17, 2013
												Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion attempts to enhance the overall gameplay while also adding in new factions (Rebels) and new units called TItans that Ironclad Games hopes will make the gameplay all the more enticing. Coming in at $40 (USD) and cheaper during sales, Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion tries to be more than just a simple expansion pack, but can it keep the gameplay as engaging as ever?Well, first off, don't go into this game thinking "oh it'll look MAGNITUDES better than Sins of a Solar Empire". Sure the game is still quite a looker, even this long from release, but, in the end, the game just refines the graphics from the original. Though one has to say that the Titan's designs makes them look not just unique, but intimidating. You KNOW when bad news is coming when you see a humongous Titan burst forth onto the scene. This, coupled with the overall improvements, helps make Rebellion look as good as it ever was.Sound wise, the soundtrack here is still outstanding. It keeps the change in tone based on what is going on in your field of view that made the soundtrack in the original Sins so good. Needless to say, there is rarely a bad song in this soundtrack, so it is almost entirely recommended to buy the soundtrack to this game when you pick it up (either at full price or during sales). Audio design si also really good, as you have the loud explosions along with the various "pew pew(s)" that each ship does when firing on enemy. Granted, unless you zoom almost all the way in you won't hear the rumbling of the engines, but overall the sound design in this game is really good.Which takes us to quite possibly the most important aspect of this game: the gameplay. The game gives you a variety of different win conditions. Some of these include: last flagship standing (turns games into more of a "hunt for the enemy's flagship" than outright domination), last capital standing (not the best of modes, considering you can easily win just by rushing the opponent's homeworld with bombers), and research (which, to be honest, is really only good for single player games). While it doesn't offer the ginormous ways of winning in, say, Galactic Civilizations II or even Civilization V, the modes still serve to help make each game feel different.In terms of maps and scenarios, well..Ironclad separates them into four categories: small, medium, large, and the user-created Galaxy Forge (which I'll get to in a bit). Each size drastically changes how each game plays out. Say you want a simple 2v2, you can pick small or medium-sized scenarios and each will require a different set of strategies. Take small, for instance, this map size nearly requires rushing the enemy as soon as possible, and games usually end fairly quickly (well for a 4X game at least). Medium sized maps offer the most variety as you can go for heavy defense, but also succeed with rushing. With large-maps, building a gigantic army and grinding the opponent down almost always takes precedence. The scenarios themselves offer up a great variety of gameplay. One puts you in a system with only three (four?) planets, but grant you the relic that allows early wormhole usage, but at the cost of the wormholes being about the only way of travelling across the map. Another may give you a lot of resources, but put you in what can be technically called a giant arena. While another splits one half of the map into ice planets and the other into lava. Needless to say, you can easily spend hundreds, if not thousands, of hours just playing each scenario by yourself.The fundamental gameplay is improved upon from Diplomacy. The advent of Titans changes things up enough to where you now have more than just three ways to play the game (attacker, defense, resource). Now you can play the part of someone going straight for his/her Titan and building strarbases for others. The new factions as well change up the gameplay. Each faction has around six technologies (as well as one Titan) that makes them play out differently from each other. Even factions of the same race (like Advent) can play differently from Rebel to Loyalist. Take the given example of Advent. While you would still be going for the culture victory (which is what Advent is strong with), the fact that the Rebels have a technology that pracitcally gives you a free replacement ship (though the chances of it happening are not very high) when one dies, changes things up to where you don't have to worry as much about your fleet being decimated. You will still be going around and playing it 4X style, however. But, the fact that this is in real time (like the original Sins), changes things up as well. Now you have to always be concerned about enemies knocking at your door no matter what you are doing, as playing the game as a turn-based 4X game will only lead to failure. RTS skills (and copious amounts of micromanagement) literally win the day over slow, methodical movements.The aforementioned Galaxy Forge practically guarantees an endless supply of new maps...if it worked like how it did in Command and Conquer. Sadly, sharing these maps with friends is a huge pain in the rear, despite the ability to make different types of galaxies. Also, the in-game editor leaves a lot to be desired, as you only get to set planets, map size, and such from pull-down menus. There is no custom placement of planets and phase lanes in-game, though if you run it outside of the game, you can technically make some amazing maps. Though, again, it is rather unfortunate that sharing said maps can't be done in-game with a downloader to encourage more people to use the Galaxy Forge.Mod support for this game is hit or miss. There are amazing mods out there, yes, but most of them (Sins of a Galactic Empire (the Star Wars mod) comes to mind), are broken beyond belief because Ironclad broke the finely-tuned mod support. Now, despite finding a mod that is SUPPOSED to be amazing, you have to read comments to make sure it doesn't crash like crazy. Granted, some of the blame CAN be put on the modders themselves, but, the game is still pretty broken for mods in general.Average game length once you get started varies by map size. The smaller maps take, at most, two to three hours to complete; medium is around three to four; the biggest can take upwards of eight or more hours to complete, leading to some rather epic (in length) games. This basically means you should NOT go into this game thinking that the games would be as long as, say, Command and Conquer or Starcraft 2. However, for those of us who love these types of games, Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion satisfies that itch almost as good as a good game of Galactic Civilizations II.Should you buy? Well, yes and no. It all depends on what your tastes are. If you love 4X games, and don't mind them being in real time, then Sins is a must-buy. However, if you want an RTS game that doesn't take forever to complete, then avoid this game. Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion is a finely-tuned, and (despite the broken mod support) great blend of the 4X genre and real time strategy games. With plenty of differences to make this game feel different (but not unique) to Diplomacy (and the original Sins, at that), Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion offers a lot of value for the dollar. Plenty of scenarios to keep you engaged for a long time, gameplay that stays engaging even ten hours into a single game, and graphics that, while not mindblowing, are still a treat for the eyes makes this game an easy buy for anyone who may be curious about it. Though, as I said before, avoid this if you don't like RTS games with matches that take hours to complete, as you would only be wasting your money.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 26, 2013
												The best of a Real Time Strategy game that went under radar. It is what a RTS is and should be. This makes any other known RTS games like young kids play. You start of so small to first conquer adjacent planets and steroides of many types, then conquer the solar system to finaly conquer the galaxy in the biggest largest scale ever seen. You can zoom out your camera to see all galaxies up to zooming in to the single vessel all in HD quality and very very detailed especially when 200+ ships are in combat and they're all firing in the same time makes the battles so very satisfying.In this game, you do not simply building an army. You develop your culture, religion and anything socialy related or you can also develop your industries to manufacture ships, weapons, stations. You can concentrate on your resource retrival effectiveness. So many things to do all so important! Space pirates are a constant threat especially is your opponents have bribed them to attack your planets.One negative thing about it: Even if it's a 1 on 1 on a small scale map againts the computer, one simgle game may last an hour or two. So huge games where it's a 8 on 8 with half a dozen galaxies could take days even weeks to finish. But if you ever wish the game to accelerate it is possible to adjust the speed of the game.There's default maps where it's always the same planetsat the same position  with the same resources or you can radomize the map making it different every time you play a game.I can give all my money that this is the best RTS ever made so far.** 9/10 **+ Lots and lots and lots of diversaty+ Supberb graphic and very detailed on ships and planets+ Maps of all sizes are small to impresively huge- Long matches

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 13, 2014
												Having played SoaSE since its original release in 2008, I can say that this game is the definitive iteration a space RTS. It is a bit sandbox, since no campaign exists, but the back-story sets up skirmishs well enough. Rebellion has gorgeous graphics, and scales well on older machines (I had a budget laptop from 2010 that could play this on low, no dedicated graphics card).The Titans are glorious beasts without being too overpowered, and the new Stellar Phenomena DLC adds more ambience to Rebellion. The sense of scale is astounding: you can go from managing a single colony ship, to watching a massive fleet duke it out over a resource-rich terran world.Each race has a different UI, which helps with immersion, as well as very well-made musical pieces that is played during gameplay.

												I can't stop playing this game, too good. A lot of people complaining are complaining about a lack of story/campign or that it's too hard to get into. I did hope there was a campign when i bought it, but nope. BUT it doesn't need one at all. Regaring the difficulty playing or getting into it, those people MUST be trolls honestly. I didn't even do the tutorial, I've never played the older Sins game, I've never played 4x  before this and from the Gecko i figured it out in like five minutes. Do degress I played Civilization V without tutorials, it was pathetically easy and that game is greatly more in depth.Get this game!On a side note the only dlc worth getting is the forbidden worlds, the stellar Phenomena is all right, it just adds like random events like these magnetic clouds that stop abilities or strike crafts and these really annoying rebels that come off the map to like undefended worlds. 												An awesome space RTS. Gorgeous battles and a deep strategic game that unfolds over several distinct phases through out the game. This is 4X game pace, with RTS controls, which can take some getting used to but feels natural for this game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 12, 2012
												"A very suprising game. Definitely a good purchase, spent quite a few hours in the game and had fun playing against AI. Can't wait to get better at this game and play some online some time."This was my original review when I only had clocked a few hours of game time. After having played more games I would definitely recommend this game to this anyone who is fan of the RTS or 4X genre. The strong points of the game come in the form of great research trees, wonderful diplomacy aspects and an interesting pirate mechanic. There are 3 seperate research paths for each race, with some unique upgrades to each race. Diplomacy has to researched in the respected research path, with the ability to offer pacts and agreements to other players. The pirate system in the game works by having a neutral race (which can be toggled on and off) attack the player with the highest bounty on their head, this often leads to bounty war in order to get the pirates attention off you and onto the enemy. One of the downsides to the game is that each game takes an eon to complete. We can be talking hours to finish a medium to large game.Overall I would highly recommend this game to anyone who is interested in Sci-Fi RTS games.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 12, 2014
												Great strategy game.   *****  9/10Good fun when playing online with friends or singleplayer against computers (which get cry-yourself-to-sleep tough). there are 3 factions each having a loyalist and rebel choice with there own style of play and awsome abilities. From big♥♥♥♥♥interstellar nuke weapons to moving starbases to crusiers that dwarf the smaller planets. The scale of the game is massive.  Not to mention the fact that you can create your own multi star-system maps and customise every detail about them: from Planets to Pirate bases and Asteroids to Antimatter pools floating about in space.The game is huge. Mindbogglingly huge. There is so much detail and so much fun that it can easily take up half your day.There are 2 issues however;The first is that it's highly addictive... OK that isn't really a problem. However the lack of a campaign limits the depth of which you can play. Although you can still crank out a good 6 hour game with virtually limitless variability. Also, if the gameplay doesn't win you over, then the simple beuty in the detail of everything from the intensity of the laser weapons right down to the windows on the moving fortresses are sure to get anyones engines rolling.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												I have over 100 hours into this game, and here's my thoughts if you're thinking of getting it.Your gameplay experience will evolve in real time from starting on your home planet, scouting nearby worlds/asteroids/gas giants/etc, and gradually expand your empire.  Most of your fleets will consist of one to a few capital ships (basically your hero units that can level up) supported by anything from light attack frigates to carriers to support ships with unique abilities.  You'll quickly come into contact with other races, and you can try to work with or against them.  You'll start working on your tech tree and focus on unlocking new ships, defensive structures, or diplomatic measures.  All items can be researched, but you'll probably focus on a few core areas. Routes into your empire can be fortified, or you can spend that money on another fleet and attack.  It's really it up to you how you dictate the flow of the game, and that's a strong part of it.There's communities you can join if multiplayer is your scene, but I would approach this as being a single player game.  There's no story or campaign though, just various maps you can adjust to play on.  There's an editor to create your own maps, or you can find ones made by others online and play theirs.If you enjoy space based games, you'll love this.  The visuals work well together, and the music adds to the ambiance.  There's lots of pew pew laser/missle/drone/cannon/etc battles you can zoom in and watch, while directing your various armadas.  There's ships that range in size from recon to destroyer of worlds.  I've tried other similar genre 4x space games, but after playing this, I can't get into them. The easiest comparison I could make is to Civ V, but both games are different.  Sins Rebellion has the 3 main races, and these are divided into two groups, giving 6 different "empires" to play with.  They all have different strategies and styles.Tech, trade, diplomacy, war, both offense and defense, culture, or combonations of strategies are viable (against the AI).There are two mini DLC's available, and they both add slight depth, but not essential to the experience.  You can always get them later on, and I do reccommend them.Cons - Space battles can feel like they can drag on at times.  They game time itself can be hours long, anywhere from 2-6, depending on how aggressive you are and largely on the map size.  If you want a quick game, this may not be for you.  I would really like to see more fluff or story built into the game, but the game experience itself isn't lacking because of that.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												I've played Sins of a Solar Empire since the first iteration, played the expansions, and now, I've had some time to play Rebellion. On the basis of gameplay alone, I'll say 5/5. Highly recommended.GAMEPLAYThe gameplay is intuitive and interesting. The learning curve is rather steep at first, and I would recommend anyone completely new to the series or to 4X gaming to spend some time against a single easy AI opponent on a very small map. Once you get the basics down, though, you'll be on your way to conquering worlds and repelling the vile alien (or human?) forces.Of all of the games I own, Sins has some of the most depth in research, economy, and planning I've ever seen. It's my go-to strategy fix when I'm kinda in a turn-based mood (ala Civ V), but I want things a little faster paced than that.COMPARISONSI'll do a couple of comparisons first, starting with the one that many people are making:SINS vs. StarCraft II: Whereas StarCraft II has become more of a "twitch RTS" requiring fast reaction and very rapid buildup and expansion, SINS doesn't require nearly as quick reaction, rapid buildup, or quite as quick thinking. StarCraft II is played on the basis of "minutes into the match", but SINS is moreso based upon "hours into the map". StarCraft II matches may take an hour to complete, while SINS is a multi-hour investment. I've had very large games in SINS go on for weeks, playing an hour or two on it a day. (which is phenomenal in and of itself, considering this is an RTS game)SINS vs. Civilization V: Yes, I know Civ V isn't an RTS, but SINS isn't a typical RTS, either. I think that players of Civilization V who enjoy science fiction bases will probably also enjoy SINS. The pacing is very similar. One of the primary differences is that you don't advance ages in SINS the way you do in Civilization V. Technology in SINS is meant to bolster and improve existing principles, not create entirely new gameplay as one advances technologically. Some things come about as technology improves, but don't expect something as major as going from spears to gunpowder to laser beams, for instance.

Posted: January 3, 2013
												*I have purchased Trinity from the Stardock/Gamestop store prior to buying Rebellion on Steam. You will not need trinity if you have purchased Rebellion as it seems to include all the contents from Trinity.Sins of a Solar Empire is an amazing real time strategy game that focuses on 4x gameplay (eXplore, eXpand, eXploit, eXterminate) across the stars.Highs: Absoultely phenomenal space battles as you wage war across the galaxy to put your empire on its march towards galactic supremacy. Simple learning starts and basics, but incredible depth as you attempt to conquer the galaxy at large.Graphically, it is very good! Probably not going to knock you out if you must compare it to games like Crysis or Far Cry. But when you're looking at literally HUNDREDS of ships duking it out in space...Lows: No campaign/story mode.*Not really a minus, given that you basically select a map and start the game and each game goes for HOURS at a time if you are not worried.I cannot comment on MP as I haven't grown tired of the AIs in single player.I am not ashame to admit it, I can sit hours at my chair and play this game (I think my longest 1 sitting session is between 6 or 7 hours in one go WITHOUT completing the game).If you like turn-based strategy games, I highly recommend looking at Galactic Civilization 2: Ultimate edition (Also from Stardock). I have poured countless hours into that game as well after purchasing it years ago and have it registed on my Gamestop account.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2014
												One of my favourite games. Three totally different factions fight endless interstellar war. Normal humans focus on economy, lots of ships and a lot of punch. Aliens have advanced phase technology and they can strip planets bare, fleeing from unknown enemy. Psi-humans focus on lasers, shields and mind over matter. I've played all factions, but my favourite are Vasari Loyalists. With them I'm able to play Battlestar Galactica style games on highest difficulty, where I'm quickly conquered and remnants of my fleet (VL can survive with no planets as long as you have necessary techs and a Titan-class ship) have to fly from one planet to another to escape their destruction, regroup and crush their enemies. In some games I was left with only one, badly damaged Vorastra Titan and no other ships and after many hours of mostly running away from my enemies, finally crush them :) With right techs, Vorastra has the ability to "construct" ships in deep space, so as long as you can find resources, you can rebuild your fleet. Other factions are fun too. Advent with their psi-technology was my favourite faction until Rebellion expansion, which introduced Titan-class ships and Vasari Loyalists enabled BSG-style games. Try to survive.

Posted: January 4, 2013
												Fans of space combat strategist, REJOICE. For this game will bring your desires. This game is strictly strategy with no story and or campaign. Everything starts as a set-up senario where you choose allies, vicctory options, and how fast you want the resource to be given to you.Rebellion has only a few noticeable differences to Trinity. Graphics is more improved as the game is using a better graphic engine. Another differences I've spotted is AI are responding very well. They are a challenge to fight against. This game a lot can be seen as a cinematic space-combat simulation. Ever wonder what Star Wars would be like with you being able to control the camera? Well you can fully see the entire battle as if you were in SPACE, without the "cannot breath" thing. You can a lot follow ships by zooming into the ship, then the camera will follow where ever it goes. More fun when u zoom in tiny units like bombers or fighters. Great for someone who would like to make a movie.Regardless, this game will get repetitive, It's addicting but it is repetitive. When you dwell into it, you see a lot of options and a lot of things you can do. Sooner or later, you'll be taking the same step over and over as each game starts. Upgrading are pretty fun too. Discovering what each race have and their advantages along with disadvantages to exploit. This game is WORTH it if it is on sale. It is a stand-alone so you do not need Trinity to play this. Have fun in space, fair warning, there will be tons and tons of debris. Space combat is never not-boring to watch. Unless you are losing the battle, of course.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												A really fun game to waste time on. However theres not much indept tactics during a battle. There's basic strategy, choosing how to move your fleet and ships around, but during actual combat it basically comes down to how many commaning ships and titans you have. Theres almost no line of defense as an enemy fleet can warp to your planet then just rush to warp to your next planet before your ships even get to them. Theres a mode where if you lose your capital you lose the game, it mostly involved how many turrets i can put around the thing and actually being able to leave it alone. Strategy games need to have two things during combat- strategic fighting and tactical fighting.Strategic involves placement of buildings, moving fleets to critical locations, and being able to interact with the enviremont to decide your decisions. At this rate it doesn't matter where anything is because theres really no way of defending it unless you wrap your planet with turrets, the enviremont is basically point to point and doesn't have much change. Strategy gets a 5/10 for me.Tactical involves micro management. You have unit of army fighting against the other fleet. You should have multiple amounts of tactics to choose from, different angles to come at, just dozens of ways of approaching an enemy to create endless battle tactics. In this its quantity over quality, and based on how many titans, commander ships, and frigates you can squeeze together. Every time i want to micromanage the ship stops outputing damage and takes a while to move as the enemy is still shooting you. This is common because it makes sense- but then what. I've moved my ship but it didn't do any good, it doesn't accomplish anything other then, "oh look i moved it." The only tactic that really works is just put the fleet in let them auto target the enemy- if I try doing anything else there's not much of a bother. I even tried pinceriing or moving my ships around the fleet- it doesn't stop them from retreating or does more flank damage. I would give tactical a 2/10.I won't go into the tech tree, pirate buying, or even the market (because no matter what or how long you wait the market will always be expensive). That stuff is basic research and buy. The economy handling is rudimentary (like all games).Really I've seen nothing special from this game. It's move army, fight other army, and hope you have better tech and more troops than they do.Despite the crap I've been giving it- the graphics and art design are legit. I hooked my pc to a HDMI cable to my flat screen TV, put the game in theater mode, and watched a massive battle. It's like seeing that space battle scene in Ender's Game towards the end. 10/10.My overall quote on this is probably a 6/10. The graphics really saves it, and I still enjoy the game- even though it'll get boring and repitive after an hour. If I were to buy it again I probably would, but I don't see myself playing it for long periods of time. It's that one game you use to video the scenes or play if you run out of other games to play.Hope this helped to anyone bothering reading it and considering buying the game.

												I've played Sins of a Solar Empire since the first iteration, played the expansions, and now, I've had some time to play Rebellion. On the basis of gameplay alone, I'll say 5/5. Highly recommended.GAMEPLAYThe gameplay is intuitive and interesting. The learning curve is rather steep at first, and I would recommend anyone completely new to the series or to 4X gaming to spend some time against a single easy AI opponent on a very small map. Once you get the basics down, though, you'll be on your way to conquering worlds and repelling the vile alien (or human?) forces.Of all of the games I own, Sins has some of the most depth in research, economy, and planning I've ever seen. It's my go-to strategy fix when I'm kinda in a turn-based mood (ala Civ V), but I want things a little faster paced than that.COMPARISONSI'll do a couple of comparisons first, starting with the one that many people are making:SINS vs. StarCraft II: Whereas StarCraft II has become more of a "twitch RTS" requiring fast reaction and very rapid buildup and expansion, SINS doesn't require nearly as quick reaction, rapid buildup, or quite as quick thinking. StarCraft II is played on the basis of "minutes into the match", but SINS is moreso based upon "hours into the map". StarCraft II matches may take an hour to complete, while SINS is a multi-hour investment. I've had very large games in SINS go on for weeks, playing an hour or two on it a day. (which is phenomenal in and of itself, considering this is an RTS game)SINS vs. Civilization V: Yes, I know Civ V isn't an RTS, but SINS isn't a typical RTS, either. I think that players of Civilization V who enjoy science fiction bases will probably also enjoy SINS. The pacing is very similar. One of the primary differences is that you don't advance ages in SINS the way you do in Civilization V. Technology in SINS is meant to bolster and improve existing principles, not create entirely new gameplay as one advances technologically. Some things come about as technology improves, but don't expect something as major as going from spears to gunpowder to laser beams, for instance.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												This is an amazing game. It's great for playing with your friends, and for skirmishes with the AI. Unfortunately that's all there is to this game. Multi-Player and Skirmishes. There is no campaign, and that in itself is very disappointing. But don't let that put you off from buying it. It's gorgeous, challenging, entertaining, and loads of fun (albeit a bit difficult at times). Unlike Endless Space and Galactic Civilizations, Sins is real time. So every split second decision counts. The AI is a juggernaut of difficulty no matter what setting you have it on, so every little plan makes the difference of success or failure. Unless you're a master of strategy, this game will frustrate you at times. One moment you're blasting away at the galaxy, the next moment there are Titans coming at you from every angle.There are lots of different research topics for each and every civ you choose, and each one is vastly different than the others. Ship options are quite large, and every ship has it's own abilities and strategic usefulness. The buildings have a build limit, until you start to expand your empire. Each new planet adds new resource bonuses, building caps, tech options, etc.Unlike games like Age of Empires, Sins sort of forces you to expand and explore, otherwise you won't get the necessary amount of buildings certain research items require, the resources needed to build massive fleets, and so on. You also can't just sit around and let your stockpiles grow, build a battalion of ships, and expect to win in one attack. You'll soon learn that the enemy has already colonized 4 planets, each with it's own armada, and enough spare ships on it's way to wipe out your home planet.Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion is an awesome experience, and a very challenging one. If you like that sort of thing, you will absolutely love this game. The only disappointing thing about this game is the lack of a campaign. Everything else is a work of genius, a real masterpiece. I highly recommend any RTS lover to buy this game right away.

												Love this game every time I fire it up over the years. This one is on top of my favorites list in games I have played (and I was playing games since the Atari was new....).  There is nothing negative I can really say about this one.... Only the things most would say after playing a lot of time on a game. Sins is running at $10 right now and worth every penny. If you like 4x and strategy this is $10 you want to spend. All the DLC and Expansions are worth it as well.The modding community is also great for Sins.... a LOT of mods and conversions out there that are high quality and can add whole new levels to gameplay in case you get to the point of putting it on the shelf after a LOT of play time.

Posted: December 29, 2015
												The game has a great idea to it, but falls short of the expectations. It is a extremely slow paced game and takes even longer to play. The few hours i have spent on it seemed like a eternity due to the gamepace. The online is not much better, if by chance you actually get into a game most people will leave before you can do anything!If you are looking for a space RTS try out Star wars Empire at War! its pretty good and you can download a amazing mod called republic at war! If you enjoy a slower paced strategy game that takes entire days to complete, you should get this. be warned though it might possibly be a soul crusher!Pros: Great Graphics! Great Concepts! Great Civs!Cons: Takes forever to play, Not a active online base.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												I truly love this game. I did my research and decided to shell out the $10 during the fall sail. This really suprised me. Though there are plenty of tutorials, I sped through and decided to take on a small map in order to decide whether this was a waste of cash or not. I was quite suprised to find my relatively peacful neighbor building a trade empire of 'one'. My barbarian hordes overwhelmed him and secured a satisfying victory. I decided to delve deeper, and found that I could pick the strategy of the AI, the difficulty, and the victory conditions, which made this feel like a positive return. I also picked up the dlc (worth it) and this gave me a broad set of scenarios, maps, and stellar disasters that made for particularly delightful  gameplay. I plan to sink in many more hours into this game and I would support a whispered 'resurrection' of the game for stronger rigs.
